Hermione blinked while Barty, confused, demanded, "HimÂ who, Reg? What are you talking about?"

"The Dark Lord."

The words were whispered, torn from Regulus in a quick hiss. Upon speaking the words, it felt like all the air had escaped the room and the temperature plunged rapidly into freezing territory. Hermione wrapped her arms around her chest and fought back a shiver.

"He was at the wedding?" asked Barty, blinking incredulously. He paused and then asked, "Do you think he brought a wedding present?"

Hermione snorted, imagining Tom Riddle as she knew him at the Battle of Hogwarts in 1998, nose-less with red eyes and pale skin, handing over a pretty wrapped wedding gift with a bow and telling Narcissa how beautiful a bride she made.

Regulus, however, shot to his feet, letting the blanket fall. "Don't joke about him! Don't!"

"Easy, mate." Barty nervously licked his lips as he held his hands up in a placating gesture. He stepped to the side, so it didn't look like he was blocking Regulus in. "It was a jokeâ€“"

"Don't joke about it, please," begged Regulus in a torn voice. His eyes darted between Barty and Hermione. "Don't, okay? Gods, it was like â€“ it was like he knewÂ everything. I swear I almost pissed myself."

"Knew? Did he use legilimency on you?" asked Hermione urgently. She reached forward, her hands gripping Regulus' shoulders tightly. She stared hard at him. "Regulus - did he?"

"I-I think he did," muttered Regulus, turning inward as he thought back to the experience, "But â€“ but he wasn't looking for - forÂ that. Just - just thoughts on â€“"

"Mudbloods and blood traitors," finished Hermione, her lip curling up.

Regulus gave a jerky nod. "He knows about you."

Hermione jerked back, her hands pulling off Regulus like she was shocked. "Me?"

"He has other Slytherins - other students - pledging themselves to him," whispered Regulus, glancing at Barty as well. The taller teenager curled his hands into fists at his side and a low noise rumbled from his throat in response to the threat. "They weren't quiet about a Ravenclaw who wrote two NEWTs in her fifth year."

Hermione's eyes narrowed. "He does know that I'm a dirty mudblood, though, right?"

"Can you stop calling yourself that?" bit Barty, glaring at her. "You're so much more than that - than what they think!"

"You're sweet, Barty, but as far as his purebloods and this Dark Lord go, I'm a magic-stealing lower-than-dirt bitch," retorted Hermione, cutting Barty some side-eye. "I could be Merlin, Morgana, and Nimue reincarnated and I doubt it would change anything."

"You might be further off your mark than you think," sighed Regulus as his colouring slowly returned. He bent and picked up the blanket, absently folding it to keep his hands busy as he spoke. "He's interested in you now. It doesn't help that we're friends, and he wants me to keep an eye on you."

Hermione goggled. "What, like a spy?"

Regulus nodded.

"Fucking brilliant," swore Barty, turning his back on the two as he ran his hands through his hair, making thin pieces stick up in his agitation. "Hermione's now in the spellsight of a crazy Dark Lord!"

"So are you," muttered Regulus. Barty swung around to stare at him. "Your dad is Head Auror, and you're smart. He's recruiting, Barty. Half of the men in that room with himâ€¦" Regulus shivered. "Half of them I knew from my father's dealings at the Ministry. He's already deep there."

Hermione slowly sat on her bed, a tiny frown between her brows. "But - what did he want with you, Reg? You were introduced to him for a reason, other than to check on you. What was it?"

"The first was to learn about you and Barty," sighed Regulus, moving to Hermione's desk and spinning her wooden chair around to sit on it. For the first time in a long while, Regulus was not well composed: he leaned forward, resting his elbows on his knees and buried his hands in his short, curly hair.

He closed his eyes and let out an aggravated sigh. "Everyone knows we're friends. We've never hidden it, and both Barty and I are well known in the pureblood circles. Having a -Â mugglebornÂ - as a friend is enough of an oddity that he wanted to know why."

"And then he learned how smart she is." Barty crossed his arms and planted his feet in the middle of the room, glaring at a poster of ABBA on the bedroom wall - a leftover of Petunia's.

"I - I showed him some of our sessions," said Regulus, glancing between Barty - who was scowling fiercely at the floor - and Hermione - who was frowning in contemplation but keeping her eyes fixed on Regulus as he spoke. "He thinks I keep you around to improve my grades. To learn more magic. He's not too impressed that a muggleborn is uncovering magical shortcutsâ€“"

"So, he's interested enough in my abilities that he thinks you care more about the magic than our friendship," summed Hermione quickly, leaning back on her hands as she tilted her head up to the ceiling. "He always did like to collect unique things."

Regulus narrowed his eyes. "Always?"

Barty quickly jumped in, asking, "What unique things?"

Hermione took the distraction, sighing. "Like the Diadem of Ravenclaw."

"That lost thing?" chuckled Barty. "What doesâ€“"

He stopped, glancing between Regulus' slightly guilty face and Hermione's tired one.

"You found it?" he squeaked, then shook his head, muttering, "OfÂ courseÂ you found it, Hermioneâ€¦"

"He alsoÂ destroyedÂ it," hissed Regulus, catching Barty's attention. "He turned it into a Horcruxâ€“" at his friends' look, he continued quickly, "He put a piece of his ownÂ soulÂ in the diadem. If he dies, he loses his physical body, but a part of his soul remains, and he can get a new body if he completes a ritual."

Barty paled and wobbled a bit where he stood, shock making him stumble until he reached the edge of Hermione's bed. He sank down on it slowly, one arm extended absently as he used it to stabilize his descent. "He'sâ€¦ he'sÂ immortal?"

"Partially," confirmed Hermione with a twist of her lips. "Horcruxes can be destroyed. Just not easily."

"How?" asked Barty through thin, bloodless lips. He stared at Hermione like she was offering a starving man his favourite meal.

"Fiendfyre and basilisk venom, for sure," confirmed the witch, curling a piece of hair around her fingers. "There might be other ways, but I know those work."

Regulus narrowed his eyes. "You've seen it. Just like you know he has more than one Horcrux."

"More than one?!" yelped Barty, this time falling off the edge of the bed.

Hermione waved an absent hand. "The diadem is the only one we can access since it's at Hogwarts. The others areâ€¦ too well protected."

"Yeah, well, we might have access to another," muttered Regulus darkly, leaning back in his seat and folding his arms tightly against himself.

"What do you mean, Reg?" asked Hermione slowly, just as Barty stared up at him from the floor, frozen.

"He - the Dark Lord - he wants me to send Kreacher to him next week, on, and I quote, 'a very special mission,'" the Black teen offered with a slight sneer to his voice. "I can only imagine what he needs a house elf for - and a way to ensure my cooperation through blackmail. Offer me - the official heir to the Ancient and Noble House of Black - something precious, something that if it goes missingâ€¦ well. Why would a Black betray the Dark Lord with my mother and cousins so deeply involved?"

"But," there was disbelief in Barty's hoarse whisper, "But you're purebloods. Part of the Sacred Twenty-Eightâ€¦"

"It won't matter." Hermione stared at Regulus in mounting horror. "He'll kill them if you betray himâ€“"

"Maybe not 'Meda herself, but she has a Muggleborn husband and half-blood daughter now," said Regulus, shaking his head. "And he'll go after Sirius for sure and Narcissa, too, to send a message, maybe even her husband to clean the house. And I'll bet every last galleon I have that he'd order Bella to do it and she would, happily."

"Fuck," whispered Barty, eyes wide. "Fuck." He turned those eyes to Hermione. "What do we do? Gods, whatÂ shouldÂ we do?Â DoÂ we do anything? We should go to my father about this â€“ or, even Dumbledoreâ€“"

"No."

Barty and Regulus stared at Hermione.

"No," she repeated. "Iâ€“"

I bled red once before,Â she had thought, a long time ago.Â Never again, was what she promised herself.

And there was no way she'd drag Barty and Regulus into it; Regulus already died defying Voldemort in a previous timeline, and Barty had gone mad as a loyal Death Eater. Those men from her previous life were theÂ what-could-bes of this newer reality, but Hermione was not going to let that happen. She would not see Barty - her loyal, funny, hot-tempered best friend - turn into the twitchy, Dark Arts practitioner and sycophant that helped kill Cedric Diggory.

Nor would she see her cool, assessing but deeply emotional Slytherin turn into one of Voldemort's Inferi, thinking he had to be brave alone, that he was all alone without a support system because he was a Slytherin and not a Gryffindor, thinking he had to live up to being SiriusÂ to make a differenceâ€“

No. She would not have them turn to Dumbledore, have them turn into his pawns, his soldiers to do with at will. She was under no illusion that Dumbledore was an innocent man; he was, at best a general, and at worst, poorly suited for the role. He kept secrets and maneuvered people into positions that would lend to optimal results - and most of the time, someone died in the process.

"I already knew about the Horcruxes." Hermione's mouth was moving, words emerging before she was fully cognizant of it. "I already had some ideas on how to destroy them. You don't need to do anything. I'll handle it."

"Pardon me," bit out Regulus, affronted, just as Barty snapped, angrily as he jumped to his feet, "WeÂ don't need to do anything?"

Hermione glanced between the two. Barty glowered at her and Regulus was staring at her flatly. Both had unimpressed frowns on their faces.

"What do you mean, you'll 'handle it'?" Regulus' mouth turned down further. "Was mail-ordering basilisk venom your way ofÂ handling it, Hermione?"

"It was a start," she mumbled, glancing away.

"ButÂ alone?" barked Barty, straightening to his full height. "If you think for just one second that I'll let you go off alone on your own without meâ€“"

"I don't want to see you get hurt!" cried Hermione, jumping off the bed to face off against Barty who snapped his mouth shut. "Either of you! I know what Horcruxes can do to someone about to destroy them â€“ and it's â€“ it'sÂ horrible. I don't want you going through that."

"Oh, like we wantÂ youÂ to do that?" scoffed Regulus, slowly rising from the chair as that all three were standing, in a loose triangular pattern, staring each other down. "And don't think I've forgotten that you know all this Hermioneâ€“"

"Oh, it doesn'tÂ matterÂ how she knows!" snapped Barty, "She's thinking of being a stupid Gryffindor right now, Reg! Planning on running off without us!" He glowered at her. "Why, Hermione? Why you? Why do you get to play the fucking martyr?"

"Iâ€“" Hermione stared at Barty; her mouth open. Not so long ago, she had beenÂ so sureÂ that she wouldn't get involved, that she would sit at the sidelines and let the war go on without her. She would privately grieve but she would be removed from it, from those dying because she hadn't planned on getting involved with James Potter, or Sirius Black; and it would only be Lily to mourn privately.

But then she began tutoring James; she spent more time with Sirius; and she and Lily had their blow-up but here, in this time, Lily wasÂ her sister, and she couldn't let things lie as they were without Lily knowing that she still loved her â€“ it was as inconceivable as fighting with Harry and Ron in her third year, or their fourth, or during the Horcrux hunt, and not making up. Like someone had cut off one of her limbs and she was forced to make do around it but still feeling its phantom mark on her soulâ€¦

"Iâ€“ I don't want to make this difficult," sputtered Hermione, catching Regulus' dark look only to turn and see Barty's scowl deepen, "But you don't need to do this â€“ you're both sixteen â€“"

"Like you aren't?" muttered Barty.

"I once thought I could ignore this. Butâ€“"

Regulus sighed, something like understanding crossing his face. "But then Diagon Alley happened."

Hesitantly, Hermione nodded. "Then Diagon Alley happened."

"Youâ€¦ you fought Bella." Regulus held Hermione's gaze, looking for confirmation. She nodded again, just as hesitantly. Regulus muttered something under his breath. "Does she know it was you?"

"I don't think so," replied Hermione.

"She'll figure it out though," said Barty, his voice pitching up in fear. "If not her, someone else working for the Dark Lord."

"He's already suspicious enough as it is," confirmed Regulus, "With how powerful you are. If Bella tells him what happenedâ€“"

"What?" snorted Hermione. "That she was badly trounced by a teenager?"

"And three Potters," added Barty quietly, "One of which is her great-aunt, and the other â€“ well, Potter fancies youâ€“"

"I know!" Hermione's voice was strained. "IÂ know. James and I â€“ we â€“ I know, Barty."

"So, they'll figure it out sooner or later," said Regulus after a few moments of quiet. "And then they'llÂ reallyÂ want me to spy on you."

"You're not taking the mark!" snapped Hermione.

"Mark?" repeated Barty.

Regulus looked sick. "HeÂ marksÂ them?"

Hermione let her shoulders drop. "Pretty, unique things. He collects them, remember? They'reÂ his. And nothing says that better than a brand."

Regulus' face paled and then took on a green tinge.

"We really can't tell anyone, can we?" whispered Barty in horror. "Who'd believe us? And even if someone did, we'd get them killed. Gods, Hermione, with what you knowâ€“"

Hermione didn't need to speak. Instead, she sank back down on her bed, shoving her hands between her knees. "I thought I could ignore this. I could ignore him. And thenâ€¦ when Diagon Alley happened â€“ Iâ€¦ well, I thought I could do it on my own."

"But why?" asked Barty, plaintively, taking a few steps forward until he was perched on the bed too, reaching forward and grabbing Hermione by the shoulders to force her to look at him. "Why would you need to do it alone?"

"We've been here the whole time," added Regulus. "You already trusted us with wandless casting and your transmutations, Hermione. Why is this so different?"

"Because â€“ because â€“ I can't ignore him. I can't ignore what he's going to do," she stuttered, looking from Barty to Regulus, and then strangely, at her left arm. She fixated on it for a long moment, her right hand coming up to trace a finger down from her elbow to wrist, pressing into the blemish-free skin.

"Sometimes, I wish I could." She laughed quietly, humourlessly. She shook her head. "My life would be a lot easier if I could ignore it!"

"A lot of things would be easier if we could ignore them," agreed Regulus quietly. He crouched so he was before Hermione and reached out, placing a hand on her knee. "But Blacks don't ignore their problems. They make them go away."

Barty snorted. "By throwing money at their problems, or by killing them?"

Regulus's smile was all teeth. "Whichever works."

"I don't think we can pay off the Dark Lord," replied Hermione with a weak smile.

"No, but we can kill him," replied Regulus, "One piece at a time."

Barty stared. "You want to go after the Horcruxes?"

"One's at Hogwarts," the Black teen said. He turned to Hermione "And you still have the venom, right?"

She nodded, slowly. "I hadn't decided the best way to destroy the Horcrux before you asked me about what I was up to."

"Andâ€¦ wellâ€¦ I'm pretty sure that he's going to take Kreacher somewhere or give him another," added Regulus. "We can wait a few days and then go after it ourselves."

"And when he inevitably checks on it?" asked Barty, raising his eyebrows. "He'll know you - or at least, a Black - betrayed him."

"Hopefully that won't be until after all the other pieces are gone," replied Regulus, although there was a flicker of worry in his grey eyes.

The three were silent for a long, long time, remaining as still as statues as they were lost in their own thoughts of what they were planning.

"Are we really doing this?" Barty finally whispered.

Hermione pursed her lips. "I guess we are."

"Holy shit," muttered Barty, licking his lips nervously as he ran a hand through his straight hair. "Holy shit."

Grimly, Regulus added, "Let's kill a Dark Lord."

Regulus' letter came late on Friday evening, through Hermione's open window while her parents and Lily sat downstairs and watched the television. It simply read:Â He took Kreacher.

Hermione's mood was sour, and she realized that she would need to implement something like her Protean-charmed galleons. Owl mail was going to be unreliable going forward, especially if her friends were dead set on killing Voldemort with her.

Less than six hours later, in the middle of the night, Regulus sent the second owl:Â We were right. I have a location.

Dawn found Hermione standing in the back garden, a lighter in one hand and the letters in the other. She lit one edge and watched the flames lick up the side of the thick parchment until she dropped the burning papers in a bucket at her feet. There could be no paper trail â€“ nothing to tie her, Regulus, and Barty to what they were planning.

Wrapped in a warm shawl and still in her pajamas, Hermione sat on a cold wrought iron seat, part of a bistro set, and began to write a reply to Barty and Regulus when another owl interrupted her, landing on the back of the second seat.

Hermione stared. "What do you have for me?"

The owl hooted and extended its leg, where a letter was tied. Hermione undid the rope, unfolding the parchment. Her eyebrows rose at the glance of the signature at the bottom, even as she settled in the seat, pulling her sock-clad feet up and tucking them underneath her as she sat cross-legged on the chair.

Dear Hermione,Â the letter began, in a messy teenage boy's scrawl that hinted at penmanship lessons, with little flourishes on certain letters.

I hope this letter finds you well and that you are enjoying the summer break from Hogwarts. Things are never dull here at Potter Manor with Sirius staying over permanently now; he's moved in and claimed the bedroom he's always used when staying over but now he has his posters up on the wall. Mum's not too impressed by the Muggle models, but she's not "pitching a fit," as Sirius's mum would've. So I guess that's something!

I realize that when I last saw you, at Petunia's birthday, we didn't really discuss any plans. And by plans, I meanâ€¦ What comes next? Are we together now? Dating? Because I would like to take you out on a date, a proper one. And maybe not in Diagon Alley - I don't want to risk a repeat of our last meal there. Maybeâ€¦ maybe you could show me something Muggle? In London? We could meet at the Leaky.

When would be good for you? Owl me back.

The letter then finished with,Â Yours - James, and something in Hermione's stomach fluttered as her fingers lightly traced over the signature.

"You, Mr. Potter," she murmured, "Are not what I was expecting."

The owl hooted again, reminding Hermione that it was waiting for a reply. Considering that the plan would be to go after the cave Horcrux as soon as possible - something Hermione didn't know the full details of, as Harry had been cagey about whatever happened that night - Hermione did not want to meet up with James too soon.

After finishing her identical letters to Regulus and Barty, confirming that she and Barty would take the Knight Bus to the seaside village that Kreacher told Regulus the cave was nearest for the following afternoon, Hermione wrote her reply to James.

Dear James - how does next Friday sound? I'm a bit busy with a project at the moment, but I'll be free then, I think. Meet at the Leaky for 11? I know a place in London where we can go for lunch.

She dawdled on how to end her letter, tapping her fountain pen on the bistro table a few times before finally writing, a bit splotchy in her hesitancy, Yours, Hermione.

The owl took James' letter, leaving the other two, and Hermione packed her supplies up. The only other owl in the house, Lily's Jackie-O, was in her sisters' room and Hermione was loathed to enter Lily's room before the teenager was up and had a few cups of tea in her system. With a sigh, Hermione resolved herself to a rather boring morning.

Then again,Â she told herself with a wry twist to her lips,Â right now - boring is good. Tomorrow won't be boring at all.

Barty met Hermione on the Knight Bus when it picked her up in Cokeworth, near the abandoned quarry. He was sitting in one of the rickety beds, hanging onto one of the poles that stretched from floor to ceiling with a white-knuckled grip and somewhat round, wide eyes.

"I think the ride has got worse," he mumbled to her when she wove her way down the aisle and to his side.

"Since the scratch you mean?" she asked, plonking down next to him. Neither had anything with them other than their wands, so Hermione wrapped her own hands around the metal frame of the bed and held on tight as the bus launched forward with a resoundingÂ bang.

The landscape around them blurred.

Barty nodded, a green tinge to his face. "I don't think moving vehicles agree with me."

"Try looking out at the horizon," suggested Hermione, wondering if Barty's partial lycanthropy was reminiscent of dogs in cars. Barty had gained some abilities - increased strength and senses - from the scratch, despite not becoming a full werewolf. It was enough that the pureblood was still scarred from the encounter, having grown up in a culture that vilified werewolves. Hermione was certain that he and Remus would never be friends, despite having quite a lot in common.

"Where are we getting off again?" he muttered, eyes firmly fixed on the blurry horizon.

"Seaford," replied Hermione, her voice low as she looked around the bus. While not full, there were still several people in various states of rest, some hanging onto bedposts like Barty, or those who were fully immersed and snoring loudly.

Barty frowned. "You're sure?"

Hermione nodded. "Regulus asked Kreacher to find the nearest town, and it's only an hour from London by train. Doable for seaside day trips."

Barty cut her a look, askance, at her knowledge but kept silent until their stop was announced. They ended up on a rural road, with only the ocean ahead of them and a few isolated cottages spread out atop a hill, overlooking the dramatic view. Behind them was a long stretch of grassy hills and the mouth of a shallow river that fed into the ocean. To their left, Cuckmere Haven jutted up and out from the ground with sheer cliffs.

"This isn't it, is it?" asked Barty, looking around with a twitch of his nose in distaste. "It's a bit barren and open. I don't see how a Dark Lord could hide a Horcrux here."

"It's not here," agreed Hermione, also looking around. She deeply inhaled the salty air. "But it's close. Can't you feel that?"

"Feel what?" Barty began to ask, but then paused and did as Hermione asked. He closed his eyes and slowly, he stilled. For a moment he was frozen, and then his eyes flew open. "Thatâ€“"

"Let's start walking," suggested Hermione. They were early enough in the day regardless that they had the time, but Hermione didn't want to linger out in view of Muggles, wondering what two teenagers were doing out in a desolate park.

They walked the beach, toward the gap of the river, and then found the shallowest part to waddle across, getting the hems of their pants soaking wet. They kept walking, both silent, as they followed the hint of magic in the air. They passed the first cliffside, surrounded by squawking and cawing seagulls, for another hour before their passage was cut off by tumbling rocks breaking the beach. The cliff cut into the ocean directly, leaving them only one direction to go: up.

"We should've brought a broom," muttered Barty.

"Well, it's a good thing one of us did, then!" shouted a voice, thin and reedy.

Both looked up, Hermione's throat burning as she tilted her head all the way back. Several hundred feet above them, Regulus leaned over the edge of the white cliff. A smaller figure was next to him.

"Or he could just have his house-elf pop up us," muttered Barty â€“ just as Kreacher appeared beside the wizard, making him shout and stumble back.

Hermione burst out laughing.

"Yeah, yeah, laugh it up," the Ravenclaw sneered in her direction, but visibly shook off his fright by pulling on the bottom of his jacket - all three had gone in Mugglewear - as a reflex.

Kreacher glared at both Hermione and Barty balefully; Hermione was pleased to see that if there was one thing she hadn't affected, it was Kreacher, as the old house-elf - while not as old as she remembered from her time in the future - was just as misery as ever.

"Master Regulus says Kreacher must bring the halfbreed and mudblood to the top of the cliff," he began in a low, rumbling voice. His eyes darted between Barty and Hermione, almost flinching on her before moving back to Barty, who growled.

"Oi now!" he started, glaring at the elf, "Who're you calling a halfbreed and mudblood, elf?"

"That would be us," sighed Hermione. She rubbed at her forehead. "Barty, just take his hand. We've got a lot to do today."

Barty scowled at Hermione, making it obvious he was put out at her order but extended a hand for Kreacher to take. The elf did so with a matching scowl and then reached out with his other hand to take Hermione. Unlike Apparation, which was like being squeezed through a tube, house-elf transportation was more like squeezing through a tube while spinning uncontrollably.

Barty landed on his butt when they appeared at the top of the cliff, and Hermione teetered, trying to regain her balance.

Regulus politely waited until they both could focus on their friend. He was grim-faced though, pale and solemn as he stood with his hands in the pockets of an oversized black canvas jacket. Once he caught Hermione's eyes, he asked, "Can you feel it?"

She nodded, slowly. "It's close, isn't it?"

Regulus jerked his head. "About four hundred feet in that direction. Right in the middle of where the cliffs go straight into the water - and away from the beach. It looks like there was a passage to the cave at some point, but much of it was washed away."

Hermione leaned forward, eyeing the slick white rock that plunged straight down. There were a few tiny outcrops along the cliff face where birds had managed to make nests, but otherwise, it was bare - except for a tiny ledge that was washed back from years of erosion and the partially hidden gaping mouth that led into the cavern. Harry and Dumbledore had visited the cave during the late afternoon, during a storm; there was no way they would've seen it.

"How are we going to get down there?" asked Barty, kneeling on the springy grass beside Hermione as he too peered over the edge.

"Broom," answered Regulus. "Kreacher will bring me down there, but you two will take a broom."

Hermione made a face. She still wasn't fond of heights this time around, either.

Regulus withdrew a broom was a shoulder bag, which Kreacher enlarged. He handed it to Barty, the only other Pureblood of the group who had broom training while growing up and waited until Barty had straddled the broom and was hovering above the grass at the top of the cliff.

"C'mon, Hermione," he said, looking comically overly large on the broom, due to his height and lankiness. He jerked his chin over his shoulder. "On you get."

Hermione's mouth twisted but she gingerly swung one leg over the broom and settled near Barty's back, snaking her arms around his waist to clutch at his jacket tightly. "For the record, I hate this idea."

"For the record, I hate that the Dark Lord split his soul and we have to do this," countered Regulus snarkily, "But we're still here, aren't we?" He nodded at them both, Kreacher reaching up to take Regulus's hand with a miserable look on his pale grey, elfin face. "See you at the cave's mouth."

"Berk," muttered Barty, but slowly took the broom over the cliff's edge.

Hermione sucked in a sharp breath the moment the grass was gone from underneath her, leaving nothing but air for several hundred feet until the dark, cold, crashing ocean.

Although no Quidditch player, Barty expertly handled the broom in tight maneuvers, keeping them close to the cliff face but not so close that they were brushing up against the sharp rocks. Instead, their controlled descent meant that Hermione could marginally relax by the time Barty had them low enough to slip in parallel to the cave's entrance.

A sharp wind pushed at them and Barty eased the broom into the cave. Only the barest sliver of light reached the cave's mouth, leaving much of it in the dark. Hermione shivered as she slipped off the broom, glancing around warily.

Barty absently handed Kreacher the broom, his nose twitching as he reached a hand up to cover the lower half of his face. "Ugh, what's that smell?"

Regulus swallowed thickly, his Adam's apple bobbing in his throat as he croaked, "Dark magic."

Hermione's mouth tightened in a thin line as her arm began to throb with the reminder of something that never happened to her: the effects of Bellatrix's cursed knife had bled into her soul, leaving its mark and despite it never happening to HermioneÂ Evans, HermioneÂ GrangerÂ certainly remembered the sick, insidious feeling of it.

"Where - where first?" asked Regulus quietly.

"Forward," answered Hermione, a bare breathy reply. The three humans and one house-elf remained as silent as possible as they crept forward, letting only the lightest of touches guide them further into the cave.

Kreacher suddenly stopped. "Here," the elf said in his low, croaking voice.

He snapped, and a burst of light hovered above their heads, illuminating the small part of the cave which abruptly ended. However, there was a dull, blackish spot at waist height on a sharp outcropping.

Barty stared at it. "Is thatÂ blood?"

Regulus paled. "We need to make a blood sacrifice to enter?" He turned to face Hermione. "You didn't tell us that!"

Pale herself, Hermione retorted, "I didn't know!"

Kreacher did his best to slip into the shadows, away from the three teenagers as they awkwardly looked at each other, silently deciding what their next move would be. Inwardly, Hermione was cursing Harry for keeping this part of the night quiet and hidden from her and Ron, as the knowledge would've been useful to have.

Grimly, she knew that worse would come - so either Barty or Regulus would have to bleed for entry. Hermione cut an eye at Barty and then discounted him. His blood was no longer fully pure, diluted by Remus' lycanthropy. It would have to be - "Regulus. It has to be you."

The teen sighed, having already come to the same conclusion. "Very well."

"Butâ€“! Master Regulus!" protested Kreacher, staring up at Regulus in keen worry.

"It's fine, Kreacher," soothed Regulus, although his tone was resigned. "I won't hurt myself too much."

"And certainly not your palm," agreed Hermione. "I don't know why people slash their hands. You don't need to be dramatic about this; just a shallow cut on your arm or even your leg will do." She peered at the blackish mark of dried blood. "I think we just need to smear some of it here."

"That's better than I was thinking," sighed Barty, this time in relief. "I thought we'd have to sacrifice a cow or something."

"A Mudblood would be better," grinned Hermione, letting her smile and joking tone take the sting out of the slur. "That would be right up a Dark Lord's alley."

Barty snickered as Regulus took off his jacket and rolled up the sleeve of the jumper he wore underneath. He held his arm out toward Kreacher, who with a very sour look, pressed a thin, gnarled finger against his pale skin and then dragged it down. A line of blood bubbled up underneath and Regulus quickly twisted the arm over the old patch of blood.

The three watched, holding their breaths, as the blood dripped onto the rock. With each drop of blood, the rock hissed and spit until steam rose. The wall rumbled and bits of loose rock fell as a loud grinding sound emerged from the dead-end of the cave and the rocks parted.

Regulus drew back his arm and Kreacher immediately healed his master. This time though, his hand was shaking.

There was a pause, and then Hermione muttered, "Once more unto the breach, dear friends - once more," and she drew to the front of the group, stepping through the new entrance and into the darkness.

Barty scrambled behind her, just as Regulus called as he brought up the rear, "You know, the next line to that is 'Or close the wall up with our English dead', which might be a bit too on point for me right now!"

Hermione swallowed a laugh, despite being completely consumed by inky, black darkness of the inner cave. She stretched her arms on either side, touching the thin passageway and let her eyes adjust to the dark with each hesitant step forward and down until a pinprick of light turned into a massively large inner cavern.

The roof of the cavern was impossible to find - the cave disappeared into the darkness above and below, just steps from where Hermione emerged, was an eerie, black underground lake. Light did filter in through hidden shafts, bouncing off pale, milky stalactite that hung in sharp clusters from the ceilings and sides of the cave. Stalagmites, large, thick and murky brown, rose from the dark water, some wider than Hermione's entire body. The brown of the stalagmites and the off-milk colour of the stalactites above bounced the light around the cavern, but instead of lighting it up, it created a claustrophobic feel of the inside of a coffin: brown, confined, and very, very quiet.

Barty whistled as he emerged from the passage, and the whistle echoed. "Look at this place."

Regulus, as he appeared, dryly added, "Look at the boat."

Blinking, Hermione turned and realized it was easy to miss: a small, two-person dinghy bobbed gently in the still waters of the lake. It blended in well with the stalagmite it was moored against.

"We won't all fit," said Barty, inching forward and surveying the tiny boat. "Maybe Hermione and someone else, and your elf if he goes with you, but not all of us."

"Someone will have to stay here," sighed Hermione.

"Where are we supposed to take the boat, anyway?" asked Barty.

Regulus jerked his chin as Kreacher pressed against the back of his legs. "There. That island."

Island?Â Hermione turned back to the lake and, moving to stand next to Regulus, saw the island. It had been partially hidden from her by a column of natural rock.

The island itself was small - again, barely large enough for two full adults to stand on comfortably, with an extravagantly carved crystal podium with a large, matching basin situated directly in the middle. Conveniently, a thin shaft of light from the ceiling bore down on the basin, highlighting it for all who ended up in the cave.

"Kreacher, what did the Dark Lord do when he came?" asked Regulus, turning and kneeling to face his elf.

Kreacher was now shaking, his bulbous eyes large and panicked as they darted around the cavern. He clutched at Regulus's arm. "Master must not go! Master must not drink!"

"The Horcrux must be in the basin then," surmised Hermione, moving to stand next to Regulus. "And one of us will need to drink the liquid in it to drain the basin. I doubt it'll be as easy as a simpleÂ accio."

"Or a smash-and-grab," muttered Barty as he walked toward them. "Although I am in favour of that."

Hermione, hands on her hips, turned to her friends. "Here's the plan: Regulus, Kreacher and I will take the boat to the island. Barty will stay here with the broom as backup.Â IÂ will drink the liquid since this was my idea."

As both Regulus and Barty went to protest, Hermione raised her voice and continued speaking over them. "AndÂ Regulus has the most experience with Dark Arts out of the three of us. Kreacher listens to him only and has been here previously."

Barty scowled, crossed his arms, but turned his head away, indicating he wouldn't argue.

"You don't know what that in the basin could do to you," began Regulus slowly, staring at Hermione.

She shrugged. "You're right, I don't."Â But I have an idea given how badly shaken Harry was when he told us how Dumbledore begged Snape to kill him.Â "But I'm also a mudbloodâ€”"

"StopÂ calling yourself that!" snapped Barty.

"â€”and if something happens, it's better than it happens toÂ me," she continued, ignoring Barty's furious face at her side, "than the son of the Head Auror," she nodded at her fellow Ravenclaw, "or the son of a Black," she finished, looking at Regulus. "As much as you two might disagree, I'm expendable."

"Not to us," muttered Regulus, a light spot of blush appearing on his cheeks as he glanced away. "You're our friend."

Hermione reached out and squeezed Regulus' hands, silently conveying her thanks. She waited until his grey eyes were on her again, and after holding the gaze for a moment, she then let go.

Kreacher unshrank the broom and passed it to Barty, sullenly and quietly, and then Hermione, Regulus, and Kreacher were in the small dinghy, trying hard not to rock the boat.

"Be careful!" admonished Barty as he paced the shoreline in a tight circuit, clutching at the broom's handle in a white-knuckle grip.

The boat began to move on its own toward the island and everyone fell silent.

When it bumped against the island, Hermione and Regulus stepped out together, Kreacher scrambling after them. As soon as the dinghy was empty, it began to float back across the black lake.

"Well, that's a problem," muttered Hermione.

"We could swim?" suggested Regulus, hope in his voice.

Hermione shook her head, kneeling and examining the crystal-like pedestal of the basin. There were intricate, almost delicate-like snakes coiling and spiralling upward and around skulls or wands â€“Â Voldemort didn't really do 'subtle' well,Â Hermione thought â€“ but she was more concerned about the Inferi. How had Regulus originally died from them? Did the pedestal call them? Did they fall from the roof of the cavern?

"Hey â€“ Hey guys?" called Barty from the shore. "Um â€“ not to scare you or anything â€“ but have you looked into the lake?"

Regulus turned and called back, "No! But we were thinking of maybe swimming backâ€”"

"I wouldn't," replied Barty, a nervous lilt to his voice as it rose and cracked. "Because, um, yeah. So. There's dead people in the water?"

Regulus froze, then turned to face Hermione. She kept her face forward, toward the basin, despite feeling the heat of Regulus' eyes on her profile.

"You knew," he whispered at it. "You knew there were Inferi."

Hermione shrugged, rising to her feet. "Yeah, but I didn't know they were in the lake." She frowned and peered at the still waters, fighting back a shiver.

God, how terrible were Regulus' final moments?Â She wondered, trying to imagine the young wizard at her side, frightened, terrified even, as he knew he was about to die; she tried to imagine him being dragged into the murky water by rotted, undead hands, and this time, Hermione did shiver. She turned her back on the lake and went back to facing the podium.

"Kreacher, can you conjure me a glass, please?" she asked, and although Kreacher did not have to obey her, he snapped a Black family goblet into existence, handing it to Regulus first.

Regulus did not pass it over. "Why can't we just grab at it?"

Hermione stared at him, and then without breaking eye contact, slammed her hand down. Had it connected with the liquid, it would've splashed up and soaked the wizard, but instead, her hand slammed into an invisible barrier that rippled and made a dull thud.

"Oh," he said quietly, grimacing. "It has to be all drunk to get to the Horcrux."

"Yes," replied Hermione, just as quietly. "Now you know why it has to be me. Soâ€¦ cup, please?"

With a sigh, Regulus extended the cup to her, but Hermione hesitated briefly before taking it from him. He quietly said, "It's not cursed, I promise."

"Thanks," she muttered and took the cup. She held it tight in her grip, letting it hover for a moment or two above the water of the basin, which sparkled in the filtered light. Wavering at the bottom of the basin, something silver glittered: Slytherin's locket.

Then, before Regulus could say anything, she took a deep breath â€“Â you were once a Gryffindor, you can do thisÂ â€“ and submerged the goblet until it filled.

She extracted it and noted that the liquid inside was barely touched. Grimly, she said to Regulus without looking at him, "This is going to take awhile. If I ever want to stop â€“ don't let me. No matter what I say, or what I try to do, Reg.Â Don't let me stop. Not until the last drop is gone."

Solemnly, Regulus nodded.

Hermione brought the goblet to her lips, paused, and then chugged the drink down.

At first, it was sweet â€“ like honeyed syrup â€“ and it slid smoothly down her throat. A part of Hermione even went,Â see, this won't be so bad, but then something curdled in her stomach as she refilled the goblet and brought the second cupful to her mouth.

The second taste was a bit bitter, like a fizzy drink that went flat, but still palatable, except for her stomach's roiling. The third was like cough medicine, and Hermione began to feel nauseous, like the contents of her stomach were going to come up.

By the fourth, Hermione was gripping the side of the basin tightly with her free hand and forcing herself to quaff down the magical potion as quickly as possible despite it beginning to taste like battery acid.

You can still walk away,Â a sibilant voice hissed at her.Â You don't need to drink anymore, Hermione. You can stop. You can stop at any time; no one is forcing you.

"Have to," muttered Hermione, her hand shaking as she dipped it in again to the basin, "Have to keep going."

No, no, you don't. Haven't you done enough? Sacrificed enough for the wizarding world? Sacrificed enough forÂ Harry?

"Don'tâ€”don't bring Harry into this," she muttered angrily against the rim of the cup, squeezing her eyes shut and tilting her head back as she drank. It was vile going down her throat, thick and sludge-like, and Hermione coughed and choked, dribbles of liquid running down her chin and throat and into the collar of her shirt.

She dropped the goblet, and somewhere, distantly, she could hear Barty shouting something.

The voice didn't stop, though.Â You gave this world everything when you were twelve. You never wavered from Harry's side. When is enough, enough? How many trolls, basilisks, dementors, werewolves, Death Eaters, giants â€“ how many will be the one that makes you say, "no more"?

Hermione wheezed, her other hand gripping the basin tightly. None, she wanted to say, Never. Her mouth formed the words but "no more," breathed out.

"Hermione? C'mon Hermione, you need to drink," said Regulus, although he sounded far away. "I'm sorry, but you have to drink more."

The rim of the goblet was placed at her lips and a smooth hand curled around the back of her neck, supporting her head as the goblet was tipped and â€“ with help â€“ she began to drink more of the potion.

The voice roared in her ears, changing from playing on her Gryffindor tendencies â€“ or saviour complex that she learned at Harry's side â€“, and around her, the shadows of the cave elongated and warped into vague shapes from her past â€“ the future â€“ into the figures she knew well.

LOOK WHAT YOU'RE DOING TO ME, HERMIONE,Â roared Harry, his emerald green eyes dulling to hazel and then a warm amber.Â YOU'RE KILLING ME.

YOU ALWAYS THOUGHT YOU WERE SO CLEVER,Â screamed Lavender, her throat shredded,Â BUT WHERE WERE YOU WHEN GREYBACK SAVAGED ME AT HOGWARTS? WHY DIDN'T YOU KILL HIM WHEN YOU HAD THE CHANCE AT MALFOY MANOR?

DIRTY BLOOD, DIRTY WITCH,Â declared Draco, sneering at her.Â YOU'LL NEVER BE ANYTHING TO US. NOTHING YOU DO WILL BE GOOD ENOUGH. IT DOESN'T MATTER HOW MANY HOUSE POINTS IF YOU'RE THE FIRST TO CAST A SPELL. YOU'RE STILL A MUDBLOOD.

Ron, looking confused, slightly lost, just stared at her like he didn't know who she was â€“ and, maybe, she didn't.Â I always knew who my friend was,Â Ron said, shaking his head.Â That was Hermione Granger. She always did what was right. What areÂ youÂ doing, HermioneÂ Evans?

"I'm sorry," sobbed Hermione, salty tears streaking down her cheek as Regulus tried to shush her, patting her curly hair with his hand between forcing her to drink the potion, "I'm so sorry, Harry. I don't mean to!"

But youÂ wantÂ to,Â he hissed, sounding so disgusted, so snake-like, Hermione struggled to breathe for a moment.Â You like James. You are going to go on a date with him. Couldn't stand to be considered theÂ second-bestÂ Muggleborn witch? Thought to take my mum's place instead?

"Ron! Ron, please!" begged Hermione, turning her eyes on her other friend, but he shook his head and turned his back on her. "You know me! You do â€“ I wouldÂ neverâ€”!"

"Just a few more, Hermione, I promise," a tortured voice whispered at her side, but she barely heard them, barely knew who was standing next to herâ€”

The voices began to run over one another, climbing higher and higher into a thundering crescendo that echoed around the cavern:

You never did believe in me; you never believed in my creatures, why should anyone believe in you now

You're stealing my life, I'll no longer be the son of Lily Evans

Brilliant, but scary How about just scary

I fought bravely at the Battle of Hogwarts â€“ I killed the snake â€“ I wore a burning hat â€“ what diD YoU dO

WHAT DID YOU DOâ€”

"Luna, Neville," moaned Hermione between gasping breaths and thick sobs, "Not you too, please, noâ€”"

There was a loudÂ snapÂ and Hermione collapsed to her knees, fingers clawing uselessly against the crystal, leaving bloodied streaks from ripped nails as she tried to pull forward, reach toward Harry, the closest of her friends who was in a squat at the edge of the island, hands hanging between his knees as he stared at her with bright, almost gold-like eyes.

"It's the last one, Hermione," someone was saying, drawing her back against a warm chest and wrapping a tight arm around her chest to keep her upright. "C'mon, Hermione, one last drink, okay?"

"No, no!" Hermione twisted her head away as the rim of a cup came to her lips, nearly upending it. The person holding her was stronger, nudging he cup forcefully at her mouth, so Hermione clamped her lips together.

In return, they pinched her nose shut.

When she had to finally breathe, gasping, the cup was tilted down and bits of the potion spilled over the rim and into her mouth, making her sputter and choke. But it was done, and the person behind her disappeared, leaving her to curl up in a ball.

"I've got it!" they said, and then they shouted, louder, "Barty! I've got it! It's done!"

"Great!" a voice shouted back. "But what about Hermione? How's she doing?"

If she was Hermione â€“ and she thought she was â€“ then the answer was "not well," and she was more interested in staying curled into her ball than face the judgemental faces of her friends and family over her decisions in the war.

Something was happening around her, but she didn't lift her head or peer beyond the curtain of her thick, curly hair to see what was going on. Instead, she caught brief snippets of conversation and a loudÂ popÂ of something disappearing via Apparation â€“ or what she thought was â€“ and mutters.

Someone strong hauled her up and she stumbled, her throat burning from her exhaustion, the purging of tears, and the potion she was forced to drink.

"Pease," she rasped, looking up at a familiar, black-haired and grey-eyed face, "water. Please, water."

"Not yet, Hermione," the teenager replied, eyes darting around, "Not until we're gone."

"Please!" she moaned.

But the teen shook his head and turned her, so she was facing away, at another familiar face and figure, gangly and all arms and legs hovering several feet above the island on a broom.

"Take her," the black-haired teen instructed, helping her as the other teen pulled her in front of him on the broom. Her legs dangled uselessly over one side while he clutched at her around her waist. She kept her eyes on the ground, not wanting to raise them to eye level and see Lavender and her ripped throat.

"What about you?" the broom-flying wizard asked.

"Kreacher will pop me to the shore. He just went back to return the goblet and bring some water for Hermione," the other replied.

Hermione felt something brush against the back of her head â€“ maybe the teen nodded? And then they were flying, hovering above the inky, black lake. Hermione's eyes slid down and stared at the water, only to see it ripple and something move close to the surface: a pale, smooth face with vacant eyes, before it bobbed once, twice, and then sank back down into the dark waters.

Then they were at the shore of the underground cavern, away from the island, and the teen was helping her off the broom. A pop â€“ which echoed â€“ had her flinch and stumble away.

"It's okay, it's okay," the teen beside her soothed, catching her and drawing her into a hug. "It's just Reg and Kreacher."

"Water? Please?" begged Hermione, turning and keeping her eyes on the black-haired â€“ Reg.Â Regulus, her mind supplied.

Regulus nodded and handed a new goblet to her, which she eagerly took and began guzzling until the front of her shirt was soaked.

Hermione's eyes closed and she sighed in happiness as the scratchiness in her throat began to ease. The voice in her head quieted, and each swallow and breath she took no longer hurt. But her limbs began to feel heavy and there was a pressing weight behind her eyes like a growing fatigue headache.

She blinked a few times as Regulus began to blur and double.

"Reg?"

"Hermione?" he replied, stepping closer.

"I don' feel so good," she slurred, swaying a bit. Behind her, Barty â€“Â yes! Barty! He's here too!Â â€“ tightened his grip on her. "I think â€“ I think â€“ I think I'm gunna beâ€”"

Whatever she was going to say, neither Regulus nor Barty would know. She immediately went limp in Barty's grip, unconscious, and it was only his heightened abilities and increased strength that kept her from hitting the rocky cavern floor.

The two wizards stared at her, and then each other.

"Well, we can't stay here," complained Barty, jiggling Hermione in his arms a bit to get a better grip before he finally hauled her up and into a bride's position.

"Right," agreed Regulus with a tight mutter.

With Kreacher leading the way this time, the group left the cavern and entered the tight, tiny passage with Barty keeping Hermione's feet and head away from the sharp walls; once they were back in the mouth of the cave, the clean scent of saltwater around them, did they stop and pause.

"I've got the Horcrux. We need to get somewhere safe," said Regulus, turning to look at Barty.

Barty shot Regulus a dirty look. "Of course. But where do you suggest?" His tone took on a mocking, sarcastic tint. "We can't take her to either of ours.Â YourÂ mum would murder her for being who she is, andÂ myÂ father would murderÂ meÂ for bringing home a girl, looking like this!"

Regulus grimaced. "We can't take her back to her Muggle family like this, eitherâ€”"

"And," added Barty, rolling his eyes expressively, "Merlin knows Potter would kill us if we showed up at Potter Manorâ€“"

Regulus twitched, glancing down at Kreacher before looking at Barty. "Iâ€¦" he began, hesitantly. "Iâ€¦ might know where we can go. To someone for help."

"Where?" asked Barty slowly, staring at his friend.

In response, Regulus began to fidget with the ends of his jacket sleeves, pulling at them nervously. "Do you trust me?"

"With my life," replied Barty immediately. He glanced down at Hermione in his arms. "And I trust you with hers, too."

Heat filled Regulus' cheeks and he puffed his chest out in pride. He glanced back at Kreacher again and focused on the long-faced house elf. "Kreacher. Can you take the three of us? I don't want to use a broom or the Knight bus for this."

Kreacher stared balefully at Regulus before glancing at Barty and Hermione. He then replied, clearly unhappily, "If Kreacher must."

"Then we're going to Muggle London," announced Regulus, carefully not looking at Kreacher or Barty. "Knightsbridge."

"Knightsbridge?" echoed Barty incredulously. "What's in Knightsbridge?"

Regulus did not reply, instead holding out his hand for Kreacher to take. The house-elf himself was scowling, an impressive sight on his long, grey-washed face that clearly stated his disgust.

With a grumble, the elf took Regulus' hand in one of his and then grabbed at Barty's leg, bunching the fabric.

"Oi, watch itâ€”" Barty yelped and then was whisked away until the odd group appeared between two, towering red brick buildings, next to a white-framed window with drawn curtains blocking their arrival. He stumbled a bit with Hermione's extra weight but maintained standing, while Regulus took the time to thank Kreacher.

"Kreacher does not like this," he mumbled, "Kreacher does not like this at all, Master Regulus."

"You don't have to like it," replied Regulus loftily, "But you can keep it secret from Mother."

"Where are we going?" asked Barty, drawing Regulus's attention away from his house-elf.

The elf popped away, back to Grimmauld Place, leaving the magical teenagers alone in the darkened alleyway. The sounds of London â€“ honking cars, a vague noise of people's voices, and even a few radios â€“ reached them despite how far they were from the entrance.

"This way," instructed Regulus, leading Barty away from the entrance and further down the alley until they passed several well-kept flower boxes and stopped before a thin, nondescript metal door with some peeling paint.

Barty stared at it dubiously. "Where's this, then?"

"Barty," began Regulus, "Welcome to Black's Haberdashery."

The Slytherin turned his back on his friend and knocked on the door, in quick, perfunctory raps. He stepped back, drawing even with Barty and Hermione, and waited.

After a few moments, Barty began, "Well, this is very excitingâ€”"

But the door swung open, outward. A tall man stepped out, lingering in the doorframe as he surveyed the three with one hand on the frame and the other tightly clutching his walking stick.

He had longish black hair, streaked with white, that was pushed back over his forehead rakishly, looking eerily like Sirius's favoured style and that complemented the Black wave. A well-trimmed beard mimicked his hair, although it was more grey than black. His eyes were a pale grey, piercing at them from under straight brows, and his nose was slightly crooked, to the right, like it had been broken and not set properly.

And although they were nearly a century out of style, the man was dressed entirely Muggle: he wore a dark purple velvet jacket over a matching vest, pinstriped with silver, and a lighter purple cravat in a fancy knot at his neck. Dark black trousers, thin in the leg and tailored straight with silver stripes that matched the vest added to his personal style.

The man's grey eyes widened as they lingered on Regulus, darting every so often at Barty and Hermione's unconscious form. "Reggie! I say! What are you doing here? It's been an age since I saw you last. In fact, I saw Sirius just the other weekâ€”"

A resigned look shuttered across Regulus's face, but he stiffened his shoulders, throwing them back a bit and said, firmly, "Uncle Alphard. I'm sorry to interrupt, butâ€¦ wellâ€¦ We need your help."

TBC...

The Future Influences the Past

Chapter Notes

I continued to be humbled and awed at the amount of love so many of you have for this story. Between here and FFnet, I am bowled over by the number of likes, kudos, booksmarks, alerts, and favourites that this story generates. Thank you so very much for taking a chance on this stupid time travel story that was supposed to be a crack one shot and evolved into this.

Yesterday is Tomorrow (Everything is Connected)

FIFTEEN

Black holes are considered to be the hellmouths of the universe. Those who fall inside disappear. Forever. But where to? What lies behind a black hole? Along with things, do space and time also vanish there? Or would space and time be tied together and be part of an endless cycle? What if everything that came from the past were influenced by the future?
â€” H.G. Tannhaus,Â Dark

July 1977

Alphard ushered them in, only stepping back far enough for Barty to go first with Hermione still in his arms, and then for Regulus to enter. He looked up and down the alleyway before shutting the door, leaving the four in the tight, narrow and dark hallway.

"This way," he said with a frown on his face. He strode down the hall, his walking stick tapping rhythmically as he did so, although Regulus winced with each slap it made as it hit the concrete floor. His shoulders were tight with tension.

At the end of the hallway was a step of steep stairs. Alphard was already partially up when Regulus stopped at the foot, warily looking at the narrowed passage.

"Are you going to be able to carry Hermione up those?" whispered Regulus toward Barty, glancing back at him over his shoulder.

Barty eyed the stairs, scowled, but nodded, turning sideways and taking little hop steps as he went.

At the top was another metal door. Alphard's walking cane began to shrink until it was revealed to be his wand. Alphard tapped his wand against the door, and it swung in on silent hinges, revealing a bright, masculine waiting room. The walls were lined with dark maroon wallpaper; the floor was a dark hardwood - almost black - and at one end of the rectangular room stood a large fireplace with an elaborate, decorative iron grate at its mouth. Surrounding the fireplace were built-in wooden panels, in the same near-black colour as the floor. The decor was similar to Grimmauld Place, in Regulus' mind, with the Victorian trims and heavy on the wood.

Two large bay windows, framed by heavy velvet drapes, overlooked a quiet inner courtyard, filled with trees, shrubs, and flowering pots in a riot of colour. The light from the window bathed the dark room, creating a coziness that Grimmauld Place could never replicate.

"Place her on the couch," directed Alphard, waving a hand at one of the two long leather couches that faced each other, running perpendicular to the fireplace.

Barty did so, laying her gently down on the couch that faced one of the bay windows. He carefully arranged her limbs, ensuring nothing was out of place or at an awkward angle. He hovered at Hermione's head, kneeling beside the couch. Regulus stood at her feet, nervously biting at his lip and wringing his hands as his eyes travelled from Hermione's still form to his uncle.

Alphard, however, kept moving and went to the other end of the room, away from the fireplace. He crouched behind a long wooden wet bar, rummaging for a bit before finally sighing and summoning what he wanted, nonverbally.

An ice bucket - clinking the whole time with loose ice cubes - and towel came floating up and around the bar and toward Alphard, who directed it toward the two teenagers. Barty grabbed both items out of the air, tucking the bucket at his knees. The bucket was mostly cold water, and Barty immediately dipped a corner of the towel in and then began patting at Hermione's sweaty hairline and neck.

Stopping nearby, Alphard waited several long moments, silent. His eyes fixated on Regulus, who did his best to ignore his uncle's gaze and focusedÂ hisÂ eyes on his best friends.

Finally, Alphard cleared his throat and asked, "Regulus, m'boy, is there something you want to tell me?"

Panicked, both Barty and Regulus sent each other looks - which Alphard saw. His eyes narrowed.

"Well," began Regulus, eyes meeting his uncle's and then darting away, "the thing is-"

"Regulus. Don't insult my intelligence," began Alphard, his voice cool. "I want the truth. If you think I don't know what the effects of Dark Magic look like, then you are more of a fool than I'd ever have thought."

Regulus blanched.

Alphard moved to sit in a very large, square leather armchair by the second bay window, one of a matching pair with a table between them. He crossed one leg over the other, resting his wand in his lap and steepling his fingers together as he peered at the teenagers. In his dapper, Victorian outfit and set against the elegant but dark decor, Regulus had no trouble imagining his uncle as an 1800s gentleman, sitting in his private gentleman's club. In fact, a part of Regulus was waiting for his uncle to whip out a smoking pipe.

"I am a Black, Regulus," the man continued, raising a single eyebrow in emphasis. "I know Dark Magic. But what I'm more curious about, my boy, is howÂ thatÂ girl reeks of it? Because unless I am mistaken, she's Muggleborn. AndÂ MugglebornsÂ do not seek out Dark Magic - unlessÂ someoneÂ has cast it on them."

Now his other eyebrow rose to join the first, and his eyes flicked between Barty, who was slowly rising to his feet, to a frozen Regulus. "Now, I could tell you that it's entirely possible that you cast something on her-"

A noise of protest wrung itself from Regulus' mouth without his permission.

"-given what my brother Cygnus' daughters are up to," the elder Black continued, raising his voice just a smidge, "but I wouldn't want to put the Pegasus ahead of the cart, here." He levelled a straight, hard look at Regulus, and then at Barty. "So why don't you tell me what's going on?"

There was a hard look to Barty, like he was ready to gather Hermione up and fight his way out of Black's Haberdashery single-handedly and bare-fisted. He had even moved to stand in front of the girl on the couch, blocking her from Alphard's view.

"Just tell him," a thin, reedy voice groaned.

Regulus and Barty spun around. Barty gave a startled yip of, "Hermione!"

Hermione was trying to push herself up on shaky elbows, but the pale, green-tinge to her face and her closed eyes meant she was struggling; one elbow slipped out from under her and she fell back to the couch, a grimace of pain rippling across her face as she brought one hand up to shakily rub at her temples.

"A-Are you sure?" stuttered Barty, glancing nervously at Regulus.

Hermione's features pinched a bit more and she muttered out a terse, "Yes. Tell me." She forced her eyes to open; they were two narrow slits that focused - although blearily - on Regulus. "You still have it?"

"You remember?" blinked Regulus, shocked. "You were out of it-"

"I might not have been in the right headspace," she muttered crossly, "but I know what we were doing and where we were. If we're out and survived without being dragged to our deaths by the Inferi, I think we're okay-"

"Inferi!" sputtered Alphard, eyes wide as he jack-knifed up in his seat. "Regulus!"

The black-haired teen winced, eyes moving between Hermione, who was reclining back on the couch again, and his uncle. "Erm-"

"Do it," groaned Hermione.

Regulus sighed and, after running a hand through his hair in agitation, swung his bag around and reached in. He pulled out a bulky silk handkerchief, oddly wrapped and practically tossed it on the circular table between the two leather chairs.

"Be careful with that," he muttered, rubbing a hand around his mouth before glancing away.

Alphard frowned, looking between the three teenagers in his shop before shifting forward in his chair, turned toward the side table. He poked at the silk with his wand, murmuring revealing charms and counter curses under his breath. When nothing happened, he reached forward and unwrapped the silk, and then stared.

"Reggie - I say - Regulus - is this - is this what I think it is?" breathed Alphard, eyes wide.

Regulus took a few wobbling steps and all but collapsed in the other leather chair, while Barty warily sank into a crouch at Hermione's side, absently reaching for the towel and drinks bucket.

"If you're asking if it's a-"

"Slytherin's locket!"

Regulus blinked. "Well. Yes. But-"

Alphard frowned, looking around. "You went on an adventure, like a Gryffindor, for a Founders heirloom piece?" His frown deepened. "Reggie - I must say, chap, I wasn't expecting this-"

"It wasn't an adventure-" Barty began.

Regulus fought the urge to stamp his foot. "I'mÂ notÂ a Gryffindor, Uncle!" He paused and stared at Barty. "That'sÂ what you want to take away from this?"

Barty stared back. "WhatÂ is itÂ with you Slytherins and hearing 'Gryffindor' that automatically makes it an insult?"

"I-" Regulus pinched the bridge of his nose and closed his eyes, turning away from the Ravenclaw of the group and back to his uncle. "It wasn't an adventure, Uncle Alphard."

"You found a lost artifact from a Founder, m'boy," said Alphard, his voice dry. "I'd say that's an adventure."

"Not when you're pretty sure you're going to die," muttered Barty, shifting so he was sitting cross-legged on the plush carpet beneath the couch.

"Well, there's usually an element of danger in an adventure-"

"You heard us, Uncle," sighed Regulus, "when we saidÂ inferi. Regular sixteen-year-olds don't encounter inferi on a daily basis, less so on adventures."

Alphard looked troubled. "True." He sat back from the locket, although his eyes kept straying toward it. "So what did happen?"

Barty looked steadily at Regulus, mentally nominating him as their designated speaker while Hermione remained on the couch, eyes closed and mouth drawn into a tight, pained line. One arm was crossed with the forearm over her eyes, blocking much of the light from the bay windows.

Regulus sighed. "It'sâ€¦ it's a horcrux."

Alphard stared at Regulus for a long, long moment. Then he painfully wheezed, "Horcrux?" while clutching at his chest as the colour drained from his face.

Regulus nodded mutely, a grim expression on his face.

Alphard turned back to stare at the locket, looking at it with new eyes. Sunlight bounced off the silver of the locket face, and Alphard shivered as the room suddenly felt much, much colder.

"Howâ€¦?" he asked, his voice a low whisper, as he turned to look at the three teenagers.

With a thick swallow, Regulus began recounting Narcissa and Lucius' wedding and the meeting he was drawn into by Bellatrix and her husband. When he revealed that the Dark Lord wanted him to host something for him, he faltered, glancing at Hermione.

Alphard's eyes trailed to her. "I beg your pardon, but how does a Muggleborn know about horcruxes? And enough to recognize one?"

Without moving her arm, Hermione replied, her own tone dry, "I read a lot."

Barty snorted.

Moving her arm slightly, enough so she could peer from underneath it at Alphard, Hermione sighed and explained, "It's not the first horcrux I've seen."

Sensing she was not going to speak further, Alphard nodded slowly. "And you want to destroy this? To stop the Dark Lord?"

"Mmhmm."

"Yeah."

"Yes, uncle."

The three positive responses threw Alphard for a loop, reeling him back into his chair as he blinked in surprise. Then, he leaned forward and tried again: "He's aÂ Dark Lord. He's already begun killing people - if those disappearances are due to him. He hasÂ followers. And he's split his soul after committing a murder and a ritual so foul that no sane wizard would attempt it. And you - a group of sixteen-year-olds - think you can stop him?"

Regulus turned to Hermione, just as Barty did. Feeling their eyes on her, she opened her own and sighed. "It can be done. Not easily, but it can."

Barty beamed and Regulus turned back to his uncle with a determined look, jaw firmed and jutting out just so in stubbornness.

Alphard shook his head, then brought a hand up to clutch at his beard. "There are only two documented ways to destroy a horcrux-"

"Basilisk venom and Fiendfyre," interrupted Regulus. "Yes, we know."

"Yes. Right. Well," sputtered Alphard, "One is hard to obtain and the other takes mental strength-"

"We have the venom," spoke up Barty, with a slight curl to his lips that made him look rather smug. "We've had it since just after Yule."

Alphard stared at them. "Well. Well then. Is there anything you actually need fromÂ meÂ then?"

"They fight back," said Hermione from the couch in a tired voice. Her face was pale, but she was slowly sitting up, pressing down hard on Barty's shoulder to haul herself up. Against his solid form and increased strength, she barely made a dent or shove at him. "They know when they're being destroyed. Having more wands on hand to step in, so to speak, is a good idea."

Something passed across Alphard's face as he stared at the girl in the group, but he nodded all the same.

"Yes," he said, his voice low, "Yes, I can see how that would be important."

He took some time to survey the three teenagers, before expelling a long, low breath of air. He slapped his hands against his knees with some sort of finality to the movement. Clutching his wand, he stood from the chair. There was something hard in his eyes, in the lines that pulled at the corner of his mouth and eyes.

"Very well, Regulus," the older Black said, and then looked at Barty and Hermione to include them. "Very well. You have my help. Whatever you need, whatever I can provide. My wand; my life if it comes to it. I am here."

Relief spread across Regulus' face at the pronouncement and he nearly sagged in on himself in the armchair. "Thank you, Uncle Alphard," he muttered, reverently. "Thank you."

Something softened in the man's face as he stared down at his nephew. "Of course, Reggie." He cleared his throat, turning to the couch. "Now - how about you introduce me to your two friends, and we find a room for this young lady to rest in? You'll need some potions to purge whatever you ingested, and somewhere quiet to rest."

"Uncle, may I introduce my best friends, Bartemius Crouch Junior, son of Bartemius and Winifred; and Hermione Evans?" grandly said Regulus, standing and making some type of sweeping gesture as he did so.

Alphard nodded at Barty and gave Hermione a much deeper dip of the head, but there was a strange, inquiring look on his face at his nephew's choice in friends: the son of the Head Auror and a Muggleborn!

"Come, Miss Evans," began Alphard, moving toward the couch as Barty stood from the floor, helping Hermione to her feet. "I have a small annex room you can use where I've had clients - or even, I must admit - myself! Have chosen to sleep when amidst a project."

As he wove down the far side of the room, opposite the grand fireplace, he led the teenagers through a short hallway with many closed doors until he opened one, revealing a tiny, overfilled room. There was a single bed piled with pillows, a circular stained glass window high above it, and several shelves along the opposite wall overflowing with mismatching jars of buttons, needles, thread spools, and coloured chalk; crates of oddly-shaped cloth, along with several wrapped bolts of cloth in different fabrics precariously leaning against one another; and a mannequin with an unfinished smoking jacket in honey yellow with black, jagged lines and an unrolled white measuring tape draped across its shoulders.

"It's not much, my dear," began Alphard apologetically, almost flushing at the appearance of the busy room, "But it'll do for now."

He did some discrete swishes with his wand and some of the bolts of cloth rearranged themselves to be neatly stacked, but that was about all that happened. He sighed.

"It's wonderful," sighed Hermione, letting Barty lead her to the bed, and to which she gratefully slipped out of his grasp and onto the squishy mattress. "I could use a kip."

"We'll wake you up in a bit," agreed Regulus.

"Yes, you'll need to take some rather horrendous potions, I'm afraid," added Alphard.

Hermione shrugged and Barty drew up a blanket for her. "S'fine."

"Should we owl anyone, Hermione?" asked Barty in a faux whisper, staring down at her worriedly as he chewed on a lip.

Struggling to stay awake, Hermione blinked and mumbled, "Maybe 'Tuney? S'pose to meet with James l'terâ€¦"

"Okay," whispered Regulus, doing a better job and sending Barty a glare when he went to open his mouth. "We'll owl Petunia for you to create some sort of cover. Just sleep now."

"Okayâ€¦"

Then she was out, gently snoring.

Alphard had already turned and walked back to the main lounge, leaving Barty and Regulus staring at their sleeping friend.

"I'll owl Petunia," offered Barty, "Since we already know each other."

Regulus nodded. "What will you say?"

"That Hermione got a bit injured and needs magical help to recover but it's nothing serious," he said, then glanced wide-eyed at Regulus. "You don't think itÂ isÂ serious, do you?"

"Uncle Alphard would've said so," replied Regulus. Then he frowned. "Well, I hope he would, anywayâ€¦"

Barty, however, was now looking around the small room and was gently fingering the honey yellow smoking jacket. "This is nice! I didn't know you had an uncle that worked."

Regulus scowled. "It's a side project. Blacks don't work-"

"This haberdashery would say otherwise-"

"It's aÂ hobby-"

"I really think it's not; I mean, did youÂ seeÂ the effort and quality put into this jacket? D'you think your uncle will make one for me?" Barty grinned at Regulus, wiggling his eyebrows.

Regulus' scowl deepened. "No."

"Oh, c'mon, Reggie!" wheedled Barty, turning to face his friend fully. "It could be, like, my superhero costume." His eyes lit up and he mock gasped. "D'you thinkÂ we'reÂ superheroes now, like that Batman on the Muggle telly? Or Superman?"

Regulus stared at him. "Don't. Please, for the love of Merlin,Â don't."

"What-" Barty nudged him in the shoulder. "-Don't fancy the idea of wearing tights and fighting crime with a secret identity?"

"Of course bloody not!" he snapped, then guiltily shot a look at Hermione, who moved on the bed but remained asleep. "By doing this, by throwing my lot in with you and Hermione, I'mÂ marked, Barty! If he finds out-"

"He won't," argued Barty confidently, "Hermione'll never let that happen-"

"He might, and I'll have to join!" retorted Regulus, "And you heard what Hermione said: heÂ marksÂ them, like a brand-"

"That won't happen," repeated Barty, his voice low and eyes fixated on his friend. "Hermione won't let that happen. AndÂ IÂ won't let that happen. You won't everÂ haveÂ to join him."

Regulus let out a watery, wobbling laugh that was half a choked sob as he raised a hand and ran it through his hair. "Merlin, I hope so. I really hope so."

The two fell silent. Then, Regulus said, quietly, "She knew about a lot of the things in the cave."

"Did she?" replied Barty, his voice deceptively light.

"She knew about the inferi," continued Regulus, watching Barty carefully. He knew something, Regulus was sure of it. "And she said the Dark - that, erm,Â heÂ - has seven horcruxes."

"Okay, so?" rebuffed Barty, but he had turned his body and eyes and was facing the mannequin and not looking at Regulus.

"How?"

Barty shrugged. "Why don't we think about how many of the horcruxes we can get and destroy before this all goes tits up and we die a very long and painful death?"

Regulus stared, and he knew Barty knew at the stiffening of his shoulders. "I thought you said Hermione won't let that happen."

Barty spun around, a wide smile on his face that didn't reach his eyes. Yet the smile was frail, fake, and Regulus' heart clenched at the sight of it.

"She won't," the Ravenclaw confirmed. While the words were confident, the tone wasn't, and Regulus knew, deep down inside, that things were going to change in ways he couldn't predict. The thought worried him, even as they left Hermione to sleep in the room and went back to the lounge to speak to Alphard.

He looked up from his place in front of the lit fireplace, having been staring into the flames in thought. "Is she sleeping?"

Barty nodded and Regulus went to sit wearily on the couch Hermione had vacated. Barty sat next to him, hands hanging between his knees.

"There's parchment and ink on the bar, lad," instructed Alphard, jerking his head toward the item. "For you to send an owl."

Barty mumbled his thanks and got up, hastily scribbling something on the parchment with some pauses of deep thought regarding what he wanted to convey to Petunia. When he was done, he blew on the ink for it to dry and waited until it soaked in to fold the parchment in two and then rolled it up. He looked curiously at Alphard for the next step.

"My owl is back through the hallway, and on the third door on the left. You'll find her amiable enough to carry the letter."

After Barty left, Alphard waited a moment, then cleared his throat. "Your friend wasn't what I was expecting, Reggie."

Regulus stared at his uncle. "Oh?"

"Well, I mean, I never expected you to be friendly with a -" he broke off, clearing his throat again. He fiddled with his wand-turned-walking cane, rolling it between his two hands. He glanced nervously at his nephew.

"Friendly with a mudblood you mean?" he asked, narrowing his eyes and crossing his arms.

"I didn't say that, m'boy," retorted Alphard, affronted.

Regulus said, pointedly, "You implied it."

"Yes, well." He looked away again from his nephew's pale eyes. He tried a different conversation route. "It's strange that she knew so much about horcruxes. Muggleborn don't know about that kind of magic."

"I know," agreed Regulus. His mouth pulled down into a frown. "She won't say how."

With a glimmer of humour in his voice, Alphard suggested, "Maybe she's a seer."

Regulus snorted. "She hates divination.Â LoathesÂ it."

"It would be a good cover story." Alphard wiggled his eyebrows. "Think about it, m'boy - she says she hates the subject, but secretly is a seer. It's to protect her-"

"Hermione can lie and act," began Regulus, "But I've known her too long to fall forÂ that."

"Hmm. So you say."

"I do so say."

The two fell into silence. Then, Alphard began, "Who's this James she mentioned?"

"Merlin, you're such a gossip," sighed Regulus, rolling his eyes.

"Well, how else am I supposed to stay involved with the magical world, Reggie?" asked Alphard. "I get all my information from those I tailor-"

"IÂ knewÂ this was a cover," muttered Regulus under his breath. "Ha! TakeÂ that, Barty!"

"-and this is something new and exciting for me," continued Alphard blithely, undeterred from Regulus' interruption. "So. Who is this James, hmm? Your rival for her affection?"

Regulus reeled back, eyes wide. "What? Me andÂ Hermione? Uncle - Merlin! No.Â No!Â Just - no." He shook his head. "What a terrible idea - no, no."

"I concur," added Barty's prim voice as he re-entered the room from the hallway. "And James is James Potter."

Alphard's eyebrows disappeared under his curly fringe. "Potter? Dorea and Charlus' son?"

Barty nodded, his brows furrowed.

"Well now," murmured Alphard, stroking his trimmed beard thoughtfully.

"Well now, what?" asked Regulus, slowly uncrossing his arms. Barty moved to join him on the couch.

"The circles were saying that the young Potter was interested in a witch named Lily," began Alphard slowly. "Several ladies were quite upset - you know how they get when a young, eligible wizard seems to show interest in someone, not their daughters-"

"Lily is Hermione's sister," replied Barty with an edge to his voice as he began to slouch against the cushions. Regulus shot him a glare that plainly saidÂ shut up you fool, but Barty was falling into his misery and missed it completely.
