"Here," he said, forcefully. As soon as Hermione took it from him, he shuddered. "Happy birthday."

Hermione stared at the box. It rattled a bit. She then looked at James. "Should I be scared? Are you trying to tell me something? Is this a prank?"

"Gods, no, not a prank," he shuddered again. "Justâ€¦ I think you'd like it?" his voice rose at the end, and he winced. "I hope you'll like it."

Cautiously, Hermione peered at the box again, noting that the box was not wrapped normally: the bottom was wrapped in birthday paper with bursting fireworks of blue and bronze and smoky clouds and drifted lazily across the wizarding paper. But the top of the box â€“ its lid â€“ was separate, and separately wrapped in matching paper with only a bow on top. There were several punctured holes along the top of the box.

Air holes, Hermione realized as she lifted the lid.

Something inside hissed.

Hermione froze, dragging her eyes from the dark interior of the box to James. "I really hope you didn't get me a snake, Potter."

James stifled a snort, feeling a bit more courageous now as he moved to sit beside her on the couch in their living room.

"Heaven forbid I do such a thing,Â Potter," he replied, emphasizing their shared last name.

With a grin, Hermione turned back to the box and removed the lid entirely. The creature instead hissed again, but this time added a growl when Hermione peered over the lip of the box.

"Oh, my God, James!" gasped Hermione, blinking back tears as she stuck her hands in the box and withdrew the small, squirming ball of orange fluff. It mewed pitifully when it realized it couldn't escape her grasp.

Beaming from beside her, James asked, "You like him, then? The store owner said he was the last of his litter, and no one wanted him, and I just thoughtâ€”"

Hermione turned the kitten to face her and at once nearly burst into tears upon seeing the familiar, squashed face.Â "Crookshanks!"

"Crookshanks?" repeated James, amused. "Is that what you're naming the beast?"

"Oh, he's adorable!" continued Hermione, ignoring James entirely. The kitten was settling as Hermione ran a finger over the top of his head, between his ears and then down his back where she could reach. She moved to settle the kitten against her chest, who began to purr and knead.

"Well, I see he's found my favourite spot," grinned James, looking down at the kitten curling against the top of her breasts.

"Shut it," replied Hermione without heat. She reached over and pressed her lips against James's cheek, and then he turned his head and they kissed properly. She let her lips linger over his, once, twice, and then drew back. "Thank you. This is a wonderful birthday present."

Hermione spent the next several hours playing with or gushing over Crookshanks, while James watched on; at one point, he began playing with his snitch, only for the glint of gold to catch the kitten's attention â€“ who then launched himself at James's chest, claws out as he scrambled up the wizard's body for a perch on his shoulder to bat at the snitch.

"Fucking hell!"Â swore James, scowling with his glasses askew as he tried to pry the kitten off his shoulder. Crookshanks' claws dug in and James cried out.

Hermione, crying tears of laughter, tried to feel bad, but instead wheezed, stuttering out, "I-I'm going t-to start d-dinner."

Hermione preferred to cook with a mix of magical and non-magical means: while the prep work was done by magic, the way that Molly Weasley taught her â€“ the chopping of vegetables, for instance â€“ Hermione preferred to cut her meat by hand, as well as monitor the sauce, even if she twitched her wand to remind the wooden spoon in the boiling pasta pot to stir every so often.

She was humming, absently, as she moved from counter to stove and back when a gong echoed throughout the ground floor of their townhouse.

"I'll see who it is!" called James from the sitting room, moving to the entrance hall where, off to the side, was an Apparation point warded against entry without permission. For wizards, it was the equivalent of knocking on a door.

When no sound followed, Hermione stilled, her hand clenching on her wand as she slowly turned to face the kitchen entrance. Her mouth pulled down in a frown, and she slowly slid across the floor, uneasy.

Had someone attacked them? Attacked James in their own house?

"Hermione," called James, his voice a bit terse. "Can you come here please? The Headmaster is here to see you."

TheÂ headmaster?Â thought Hermione, her breath hitching. She narrowed her eyes and absently wiped her hands down the front of her jeans but left the kitchen and entered the living room.

Crookshanks was curled on an armchair with his eyes half-lidded and fixated on the headmaster â€“Â I have no idea how he got there unless James put him there,Â thought Hermione, given how small the kitten way â€“ and James was sitting on the couch with Albus Dumbledore sitting in the other armchair, his hands folded in his lap. Between the two armchairs and the couch was their coffee table was a tea set, one HermioneÂ knewÂ they didn't have; Dumbledore must have conjured it.

Hermione glanced at James, who patted the couch next to him. Hermione made her way and sat on the very edge of the seat, deliberately slipping her wand into her sleeve.

Dumbledore smiled at her. "It's good to see you again, Ms. Evans â€“ ah, excuse me. Mrs. Potter. Congratulations on your marriage as well!"

"Thank you," she replied, in a pleasant tone. She tried to keep her face gentle and soft, despite how much her heart was thundering.

"Tea, Mrs. Potter?" asked Dumbledore, reaching forward, and pouring from the teapot into one of three delicate china cups he had arranged. "Do you take yours with sugar or lemon? I can't seem to remember seeing you drink tea during your time at Hogwarts."

"I prefer honey," said Hermione, fighting the urge to scowl. HowÂ dareÂ Dumbledore play host in her own house? "Although with supper soon, I won't indulge."

"Ah, of course," the headmaster nodded, turning to James. "James?"

Her husband squirmed in his seat but shook his head. "No, thank you."

Dumbledore seemed mildly disappointed but ended up making the tea to his preference while vanishing the two other cups. The three sat in silence.

"What brings you by, Headmaster?" asked Hermione eventually, a part of her aware of the pasta and sauce bubbling away in the kitchen.

"I wanted to speak to you about yourâ€¦ kidnapping, Mrs. Potter," began Dumbledore evenly, looking at her from over the rim of his cup as he held it delicately between the thumbs and middle fingers of both his hands. His blue eyes twinkled. "You did something that few can claim: survive Voldemort."

Hermione shrugged. "I already gave my statement to the Aurors, Headmaster."

"Yes," agreed Dumbledore, slowly, even as he put his cup down. "You were quite brave, Hermione. All of you were."

Hermione's eyes narrowed. Did he have access to the Auror statements? She cut a glance at James, who was glancing between her and Dumbledore, a rather serious expression on his face. Or did James and Sirius tell him? Orâ€¦ Caradoc Dearborn?

Dumbledore seemed to realize that she wasn't going to speak, so he continued. "Your bravery is inspiring, my dear. Being able to stand up against Voldemort, and his Death Eaters, and come out on the other side is an achievement! It takes skill to utilize the magic you wielded that evening."

"My OWL and NEWT scores demonstrate my skill, I like to think," said Hermione carefully. "Pardon me, Headmaster, but I have dinner on the cooktop, so I must ask: what is this about?"

Dumbledore peered at her, and then reached into his robes to withdraw a golden envelope. He handed it over to her, across the coffee table, and with trepidation, Hermione took it. She flipped it over and saw the red wax seal with a pressed phoenix in it.

She sighed, almost disappointed. She workedÂ so hardÂ to stay under his notice! At what point did it seem like sheÂ wantedÂ or even cared to be part of his group?

"That is an invitation to the Order of the Phoenix, a group of individuals who are dedicated to ridding the world of Voldemort," began Dumbledore, launching into his pitch.

Hermione interrupted. "How?"

"I'm sorry?" sputtered Dumbledore, blinking in surprise.

"How are you ridding the world of Voldemort?" Hermione asked, doing her best not to mock. Because out of the two of them,Â sheÂ had done far more than Albus Dumbledore had managed in thirty years.

"Hermione!" blurted James, mouth agape.

Hermione did not look at her husband, focusing on Dumbledore, but his forehead instead of his eyes. She didn't want any Legilimency attacks, thank you.

"No, no, James. Hermione has the right to ask that! Ms. Evans was always an inquisitive one," chuckled Dumbledore, physically waving a hand as though he were waving off her concerns, as well as acknowledging her maiden name instead of her married one to separate her from those in his group. "We stop any Death Eater attacks on innocents."

"Mm." Hermione pressed her lips together. "So, you're reactionary. But what about Voldemort? What are you doing about him? It's one thing to stop or arrest his Death Eaters, but what about their leader?"

Dumbledore now pressed his lips together, the twinkling in his eyes growing a bit dim. "That is something I am working on but would prefer not to say at this time, Ms. Evans."

"Potter," she broke in sharply, annoyance licking at her. She felt her magic begin to stir in response, nearly vibrating like an energy that surrounded her.

Beside her, she heard James inhale sharply.

The twinkling disappeared altogether. "My apologies, Mrs. Potter."

Hermione looked down at the invite. She turned it over a few times and but did not break the seal. Instead, she passed it back to Dumbledore.

"No thank you," she said, as politely as she could. Her tone was still cool, and both James and Dumbledore could tell.

"I am planning on stopping at Sirius's after this to invite his brother," began Dumbledore, carefully. "Mr. Regulus Black will be offered the same opportunity based on his experiences that night. Afterward, I plan on speaking to Mr. Crouch as wellâ€”"

"They'll say 'no' as well," interrupted Hermione calmly. SheÂ knewÂ her friends.

"Because you will tell them so?" asked Dumbledore shrewdly.

Hermione rolled her eyes. "Because they're not interested. You can tell them of this conversation, too, if you'd like. I don't need to dictate what my friends do."

"But they do follow you," pointed out Dumbledore, his eyes narrowing the tiniest bit.

Hermione shrugged, pointing at herself. "Ravenclaw. We tend to have good ideas."

James closed his eyes and turned slightly away so neither Hermione nor Dumbledore could see his face. He had a hand covering his mouth.

"I see." Dumbledore sighed. He used his wand to vanish his teacup and teapot, and then slowly stood. "I am disappointed, of course, but I do not force people to join the fight if they do not want to."

Hermione held back a snort; she wasÂ neck-deepÂ in the fight!

"I'll show you out, Headmaster," said James, rising to his feet. He cast Hermione a look that readÂ we're talking when I get backÂ but turned to the wizard and led him from the room. Hermione went back to the kitchen, wand already out and frantically swishing to get the neglected spoon to begin stirring the sauce again.

James appeared a few moments later, staring at her from where he leaned against the kitchen doorway. His arms were crossed, but he wasn't closed off; there was something curious in his brown eyes as they followed her around the kitchen, despite the neutral look he wore.

"Do you wanna tell me why you declined the offer?"

Hermione glanced at her from the stove, the steam from the pasta pot curling her hair. "Do I have to?"

James grimaced. "Noâ€¦ but I like to think that I'd understand your reasons if you do want to share them with me."

"Why doÂ youÂ think I said no?" asked Hermione curiously, turning from the stove.

"Oh â€“ uh â€“ I dunno," blinked James, wrongfooted. "I, uh, I guess you don't want to be involved because of the kidnapping?"

Hermione slowly shook her head.

James frowned. "Then why?"

She bit her lip, glancing away. Finally, she turned back to the sauce, adding the neglected chopped vegetables, and said, quietly. "I don't trust Dumbledore."

James slipped from where he was leaning against the wall, completely surprised by her admission. He caught himself on the frame instead, hauling him upright. "You don't trustÂ Dumbledore?"

Hermione shook her head. "I don't like how he handled things after theâ€¦ Shrieking Shack."

James made a pained noise.

"And there were things that I saw, as a Ravenclaw, that you wouldn't see from your end of things," she continued carefully. "He plays favourites."

James frowned, stepping further into the kitchen. He caught her eyes and held him in his gaze until he was within touching distance. He reached out and gently took her hands in his. "Hermioneâ€¦" he began, glancing down and then back up at her. "Look â€“ I â€“ don't take this the wrong way, okay?"

"Whatâ€”"

"I know you're not telling me the truthâ€”"

Indignation rose in Hermione. "I am telling the truth!"

"Okay, then theÂ fullÂ truth," amended James quickly, tightening his grip on her hands. "I know you're not sharing everything with me."

Hermione swallowed thickly. Had she messed up somewhereâ€¦?

"I'm not going to ask you to tell me," continued James. He quirked a grin at her. "Not yet at least. I'll be patient."

Cautiously, Hermione ventured, "You might be waiting a while."

James wriggled his eyebrows. "I think we both know how patient I can be when I want, Hermione. And weÂ bothÂ know that when I want something, I go after it with everything I have. But I'm also not going to push you to tell me if you're not comfortable with telling me."

Hermione's mouth dropped open.

"I'll admit," continued James, hurt creeping into his voice, "That I don't like that you're keeping secrets from me. It hurts that you feel like you can't trust meâ€”"

"Regulus, Barty, and I have been working together on our own to stop Voldemort," blurted out Hermione, half-horrified that she just spat it out like that, and half-relieved that she was no longer keeping it secret from James.

James blinked. Then, he squeaked, "I beg your pardon?"

Well, in for a penny,Â thought Hermione. "We'veâ€¦ we've been working on this since we were in fifth year."

"I beg your pardon?!" James's voice rose higher, even as his eyes widened further. His hands clenched around hers.

"Things are kind of up in the air, right now, but I think we're going to start a business together and use it as a front for continuing our work," added Hermione in a rush, almost shaking James's hands. "Reg inherited his uncle's shop â€“ the Haberdashery â€“ and with Alphard's old contacts, and between what Barty can find out through his father â€“ and my skills â€“ well, we've been doing alright?"

James looked like Hermione had just told him she was in love with Snape and was leaving him for the greasy git. "I â€“ and this â€“Â fifth year?"

Hermione nodded slowly.

James took a step back, and Hermione let his hands slip from hers. He didn't go further, though, just a foot away and staring at her. His brows furrowed. "I â€“ I don't understand â€“ why wouldn't you want to pool resources with the Orderâ€¦?"

Hermione gripped her arms, curling a bit in on herself. "As I said," she mumbled, "I just don't trust him."

James was silent, and Hermione felt the weight of his eyes on her. Behind, on the stove, the sauce bubbled and popped.

Eventually, James let out a loud exhale. Hermione looked up at him. "Jamesâ€¦?"

"Hermione," he sighed, looking up at their ceiling and then shaking his head. "I love you. Nothing will ever change that."

Hermione's knees wobbled in relief. She reached out blindly, grasping the side of the counter to keep herself upright. James's warm hazel eyes landed on her and he gave her a tiny grin.

"I â€“ I know that Gryffindors tend to get Dumbledore's attention more than anyone else, so maybe you don't know him as well as I doâ€¦ so while I don't understand why you won't join the Order, I respect your decision," he finished.

"James!" Hermione beamed at him, launching herself at him and hugging him tight around the neck. She laughed wetly into his neck even as his glasses cut into her temple.

James gripped her back just as tightly. "I won't be able to tell you what I get up to. But I want you to share what you feel comfortable with, with me; and I'll do the same."

"I promise!" replied Hermione, drawing back but staying in the circle of his arms.

"Me too," he murmured, nose brushing hers. Then he drew back further, and said, a bit sternly, "Just â€“ just don't get arrested, okay? I'm not sure how I could explain away that one with my colleagues in the Departmentâ€¦"

Hermione laughed.

October 1979

Despite the carriages beingÂ the exact sameÂ â€“ minus the wood accents and a bit more metal and chrome â€“ the train Hermione, Regulus, Petunia, and Sean departed on from King's Cross looked remarkably like the Hogwarts Express. And yet, Regulus kept moving gingerly around the space, perching himself on the very edge of his seat and using an embroidered handkerchief to touch things.

"You're such a snob," teased Hermione as she flopped in the seat next to him.

"If you don't want to be here, mate," began Sean as he took the seat opposite Regulus, "Then why'd you come?"

"Was James not available?" asked Petunia pointedly, glancing at her sister as she sat, clutching her large tote bag to her chest.

"Or Barty?" added Sean.

Regulus and Hermione shared a look. Hermione shook her head when she turned back to her sister and brother-in-law. "Barty's dad has him shadowing him at the Ministry. He wants him to join the Aurors, but we'd rather just go in business together at the Haberdashery."

Sean made a face.

"And James?" pressed Petunia, narrowing her eyes the tiniest.

Hermione squirmed. "He uhâ€¦ vaguely knowsâ€¦ what we are going to doâ€¦ but he's at work today. Obviously. That's why he couldn't come."

Regulus turned in his seat to face Hermione, his eyes wide. "JamesÂ knows?!"

"Noooo," drawled Hermione, glaring at Regulus and hoping he'd keep quiet. The train left the station, jerking the tiniest bit before moving out through the heavy tracks and urban center. "Not quite."

"Excuse me," bit out Petunia, glaring at Hermione. The two looked eerily similar, despite the difference in hair and colour: the way their eyes were slit, the flaring of their nostrils, and the pursing of their lips were the same.

Sean's eyebrows popped up and he sat back, crossing his arms. "Blimey, this ought to be good," he muttered, catching Regulus's eye.

The train turned north and began to move out of the urban area into suburban, colours flashing by as it picked up speed, mixing the browns and greens against the early morning and bright blue sky.

"Tuneyâ€¦" began Hermione, mumbling a bit as she tried to placate her older sister. "It's uh â€“ it's not like thatâ€”"

"Then what is it like, Hermione?" asked Petunia sharply. "Because it sounds like you asked Sean and me to help you with your Tom Riddle problem for a weekend excursion, and yet yourÂ husbandÂ doesn't know what you're up to."

"He kind of knows," she muttered, looking away and out the window, although that meant looking past Regulus who was staring at her.

"'He kind of knows,'" mimicked Petunia nastily, "Is not the same as knowing and thinking this is a good idea.Â WhatÂ did you get us involved in?"

Hermione slid down the seat a bit and hunched her shoulders. "You won't have to do much â€“ Reg and I will do the work â€“"

"Oh, ohÂ no," interrupted Petunia, a heavy frown on her face. "You are going to tell us. We've got a four-hour train ride, so best start talking."

Hermione shook her head. "Too public."

The other three glanced around the carriage and the three businessmen, the two couples, a group of uni students looking very bleary and hungover, and then back at Hermione.

Petunia spoke through gritted teeth. "Fine. You and I are going to have a chat, later when we get to Little Hangleton, then, miss."

Hermione slouched further down the seat. "Erm. Okay," she mumbled, her chin touching her chest even as she thought:Â God, she makes me feel six instead of nineteen. I'm bloody married!

Sean eyed her, brows raised, before shaking his head and turning to the window. Petunia considered the matter closed and retrieved a bawdy romance novel from her tote to read, ignoring everyone around her as she opened the book.

Regulus looked at Hermione, then Petunia, and shook his head. "You're on your own," he muttered and turned to look out the window as well, with his arms crossed.

Hermione sighed.

The four stood on an empty train platform after the train left, looking around at the abandoned ticket station and rotted wooden sign that proclaimed "Little Hangleton", barely hanging on to the roof by a single, rusted chain; they had taken a transfer from Greater Hangleton an hour earlier on a smaller train, and by the look on Petunia's pinched face, she wasÂ notÂ amused. Sean's glower was aligned to that of his wife's.

"Well," began Regulus in false cheer, drawing everyone's attention. "Maybe we should find a place to stay?"

"If there is something," muttered Petunia, but the four pushed through the passthrough at the station and turned down the gravel path to the village, nestled alongside the train station at the bottom of the valley.

There was a low-lying fog that swirled around their legs as they walked, and the looming bare branches of the trees that lined the path arched over them. Leaves crunched under their boots, and the lights from Little Hangleton appeared distant and muted despite not being that far away.

Distantly, Hermione saw the monstrosity of the Riddle Manor at the top of the valley hill, overlooking the village and station. It was dark and ruinous. The shadows from the afternoon autumn sun â€“ already low in the sky â€“ created long, twisting shadows of the manor's wings and angled roofs, lengthening as they drew her eyes toward the church. Adjacent to the manor property, it had a single steeple and the patch of land at the top of the valley that was the graveyard.

A single, wooden sign, a makeshift arrow, noted the graveyard in faded paint as the four reached a fork in the gravel road.

Toward the graveyard, the trees began to thicken and duplicate in number, creating a tiny forest of thick, leafy foliage despite the late season. But there was something heavy and dank in the air that made Hermione shudder.

"This place is really creepy," muttered Sean, inching away from the path, and closer to the village. "Can we go?"

Regulus and Hermione shared a glance; down that path was not just the route to the Riddle House, but potentially the Gaunt house, too. It would explain the atmosphere and feeling of ill will.

"Later," mouthed Hermione, and Regulus nodded.

Quickening their pace, the group made their way into Little Hangleton barely twenty minutes later, and Sean sussed out a B&B with a "vacancy" sign. Turning to face the group, he jerked his thumb over his shoulder and began walking backward, even as he said, "Um, yeah. So. I'm going to get us two roomsâ€¦"

Petunia stared hard at him for a long, long minute, and then turned to Regulus and Hermione. Before she could say anything, Hermione blurted, "We're going to go scout the town! Yeah!"

Regulus glanced at Hermione, then wisely kept his mouth shut, moving a few steps away from her and Petunia.

Petunia ground her teeth â€“ making Hermione cringe â€“ but nodded. "I guess I can talk to some of the townspeople. We can meet up at the pub in a bit."

Exhaling, Hermione sent a wobbly grin at her older sister. "That sounds great! Thanks, Tuney!"

She spun on her heel and made it two steps before Petunia reached out and grabbed Hermione's arm, tight. She whipped her sister around and, with narrowed eyes, hissed at Hermione, "Just because you're walking away right now doesn't mean we're done talking! Don't go and do anything stupid like â€“ like â€“ getting yourself blown up!"

"Blown up?" echoed Hermione in amusement. "Just what do you think I'm going to do?"

Petunia huffed and threw her hands in the air. "I don't know Hermione, I'm not a witch, am I?"

"It'll be fine, Tuney," soothed Hermione. "We're just going to poke our noses around. Right, Reg?"

Regulus held both his hands up in the gesture ofÂ don't get me involved in this.

"Fine," sighed Petunia, after a moment. "Two hours. Pub. Don't be late."

"Yes, mum," agreed Hermione, and Petunia stopped away, hitching her tote bag up further on her shoulder even as she threw her shoulders back and tossed her long blonde hair over her shoulder. Immediately, they watched as she honed in on a lone woman outside the grocer's, and the way her winsome smile and journalist persona came to the forefront.

Soon, the two women were talking animatedly.

Regulus gave a low whistle. "Merlin, she's good."

"Let's see if we're just as good at Riddle Manor," replied Hermione.

They weren't. The Manor wasn't quite as dilapidated as Hermione had anticipated, but it was boarded up and dusty and had a vague smell of mold. But it was also obvious that no one had been inside â€“ magical or otherwise â€“ for decades.

Regulus and Hermione returned to the B&B, meeting Petunia outside. She had their room numbers and keys and led them up the dark staircase to the second floor and their rooms, which shared an adjoining sitting area. Sean was waiting for them, with take-out.

"It's not very flavourful," he mourned as he handed out newspaper-wrapped fish and chips, "Because this is about as exotic as Little Hangleton gets."

Petunia snorted into her chips, dousing them with vinegar. "This place is aÂ cesspool," she declared. "The people are distrustful, petty, and suspicious."

"But you seemed to be chatting up that Muggle woman when we left," pointed out Regulus in confusion, brows furrowed even as he absently bit into his salted chip. He made a face.

"Sure, for a bit," sighed Petunia. "And then when I mentioned I was investigating suspicious deaths in small towns of Northern England â€“ I even hadÂ otherÂ research to back me up! â€“ she got all shirty with me. Spat something out about 'poor old Frank,' and then left in a huff."

"What about you two?" asked Sean, glancing between Hermione and Regulus.

"Bust," sighed Hermione, putting down her newspaper bundle in her lap. "The Manor is mostly boarded up, but whatever happened there years ago with the Riddles, it's faded magic."

"Nice house though," added Regulus, dabbing his paper napkin against the corner of his mouth. He then pushed away his finished fish â€“ having left the chips. "A bit small."

Petunia and Sean stared at him. Then, Sean turned to Petunia, sputtering, "A bit small?!"

Hermione stifled a grin, but it called Petunia's attention to her. Hermione felt a frisson of something sizzle up her spine and she gulped as her sister's blue eyes locked onto her.

"So, Hermione," Petunia began, putting her own meal down, "Do you want to explain things now?"

"Not particularly," muttered Hermione, looking away.

"Tough," spat Petunia, leaning forward toward Hermione. "Explain why James doesn't know what's going on. Explain whatÂ isÂ going on â€“ why you need so much information about Tom Riddle and why we're here."

Hermione shared a glance with Regulus, who shrugged. "It's your story to tell, Hermione."

Hermione scowled. "I thought you'd want me to keep quiet."

"I do," agreed Regulus evenly, "But because your sister and her husband are Muggles and can't protect themselves if someone finds out they know. Barty and I can. And we have."

"Does this have something to do with your kidnapping in July?" Petunia's eyes narrowed even as Sean leaned back and observed them with a casual air, although his eyes followed each person speaking with careful consideration.

"Kind of," sighed Hermione, turning back to her sister. She looked at Petunia for a long moment, taking in her sister's confidence, the ease she held herself.

She's already implicated herself by helping us with the information on Riddle from the Muggle side of thingsâ€¦Â thought Hermione, twisting her lips a little in a side-frown.Â She's already in danger by virtue of being my sister and an Evans.

"I don't think you're going to believe me," began Hermione carefully, looking at both Petunia and Sean as she spoke. "But bear with meâ€¦"

"Okayâ€¦" said Petunia, her mouth pulling down in a frown.

"I was born Hermione Granger on September nineteenth, in 1979, and died in 2026 at the age of forty-sevenâ€¦"

Hermione gave a watered-down version of her life, and then recapped how she grew up an Evans, her time at Hogwarts, and then what she knew of Tom Riddle, the Dark Lord Voldemort â€“ including why she was in Little Hangleton with Regulus, hunting for artifacts. James and his original fate were also touched upon â€“ although she kept the information about his wife secret for now (that was something she would share with Petunia when it was just the two of them) â€“ and how she wanted to change things.

At the end of the discussion, Petunia was blinking back tears, having migrated to sit next to Hermione â€“ pushing Regulus out of his seat on the couch â€“ and holding her sister tight. Sean, sitting opposite them, sighed heavily and hung his hands between his legs with his elbows braced by his knees. He shook his head and said, despondently, "Just when I think I'm getting the hang of magic, you throw something like this at me, Hermione."

Hermione gave a tiny, wet laugh.

"Welcome to my life, mate," replied Regulus, turning to Sean. "Try growing up with her when she used to do weird things for weird reasons and Barty and I would haveÂ no ideaÂ why she was doing it."

"Shut up, Reggie," muttered Hermione, grabbing one of his cold, leftover chips and throwing it at him. The wizard squealed as it neared him, twisting out of the way and then loudly berating Hermione for throwing the potato at him, storming off to the bedroom to change his shirt, muttering about salt stains. Sean followed, laughing, leaving the two sisters alone.

"You're going to have to tell James eventually, Hermione," said Petunia quietly.

"I know," said Hermione, her shoulders falling.

"Soon," pressed Petunia. Her eyes were wide and imploring as she stared at Hermione. She squeezed her tightly, for a moment.

I know, thought Hermione, shivering a bit.

"So, if the manor had nothing, where are we going?" asked Sean, the first the speak the next day as the four of them, dressed in trousers and jackets, left Little Hangleton and headed back to the fork in the road by the train station.

Hermione made Sean carry a transfigured shovel but had cast a featherlight charm on it. Petunia carried her tote bag again, but this time was rereading the note she sent Hermione, thumbing through the pages quickly as she caught herself up on Tom Riddle. Regulus, leading them, nervously kept touching his hidden wand holster up his sleeve, casting wary glances around the gravel path.

"Because if you say, 'grave robbing,'" continued Sean with a scrunched face, "I'm out."

Hermione snorted. "No grave robbing."Â Not tonight, anyway.Â "But there's a chance we might need to dig around the Gaunt property."

"Gaunt?" asked Petunia, looking up from the notes. "Riddle'sâ€¦ mother, I'm guessing? A witch?"

"A squib," corrected Regulus, a rather serious look on his face as they neared the fork. "Someone born to two magical users but has no magic themselves. The opposite of a Muggleborn."

"The Gaunts were well-known in Pureblood circles until the turn of the century," added Hermione, explaining for Sean and Petunia's benefit. "Very inbred, very Dark. There's likely to be some types of traps around the property that had nothing to do with Riddle himself, so you two will stay back and let us do the heavy wand work."

"Fine by me," agreed Sean with a rather cheerful skip now that he knew he wasn't graverobbing. "Honestly, this is excitingâ€¦"

Petunia shot him a disbelieving look.

The group turned down the fork toward the Riddle house and the graveyard, but barely a minute into the heavily wooded area, both Hermione and Regulus stopped and shivered violently.

"What?" Petunia's voice rose in panic. "What's wrong?"

Slightly green in the face, Hermione replied, "Magic. It's reallyâ€¦"

"Inky," finished Regulus, gagging. "Similar to the Horcrux, but that's not it. There's decades of Dark magic in this forest."

"Wonderful," bit out Petunia, inching closer to Sean.

Hermione and Regulus shared a look, and then turned off the trail, to a small, overgrown one that they only seemed to see. Petunia followed Hermione, and Sean brought up the rear until they reached a clearing with a very rundown shack in the middle.

"No Muggle repellant," muttered Regulus, his eyes flicking everywhere. "I don't like that."

"Same," muttered Hermione in reply, glancing back at Petunia and Sean â€“ the latter who was swinging his shovel around idly, careful not to hit his wife, and whistling. Hermione grimaced.

Regulus inched closer, his wand tip glowing brightly as he muttered under his breath revealing spells and poking around at moments to check for other wards. Closer to the door he stopped a heavy scowl of distaste on his face. "Hermione! Come look at this."

Leaving Petunia and Sean near the treeline, Hermione carefully picked her way across the weedy and leaf-covered ground, stepping where Regulus stepped until she was next to him. She looked up at the door and went, "Eww," without thinking about it.

The skeleton of a snake rung from a single, rusty nail, in mockery of a charm or wreath, either end coming just below the frame. It was also pulsing a faint, sickly yellow until Regulus's wand.

"Spell?" asked Hermione. Distantly, she saw Petunia and Sean move along the tree line that surrounded the property, moving clockwise.

"Keyed to a Parselmouth, I think," answered Regulus slowly, flicking his wand. Immediately, bits of the sickly yellow lifted from the snake and coalesced into smoky swirls and patterns and runes that Hermione recognized.

"Key rune is there," she said, pointing at the floating PeorÃ° symbol, á›ˆ, as the lynchpin to the ward entry.

"What does it mean?" asked Regulus, who took arithmancy, not ancient runes.

"The Gaunts liked to play games," answered Hermione grimly. "It means hidden secrets, destiny, uncertainty. 'A source of recreation and amusement to the great'," she finished with a soft quote.

Regulus echoed her snort. "Wankers."

"Unless we want him to know what we're doing, we're going to need to find another way that isn't the front door," muttered Regulus, lowering his wand.

"There's a window back here!" shouted Petunia from the other side of the shack.

Regulus and Hermione exchanged a look and followed, coming around the shack to see Petunia and Sean still near the treeline, but this time, Petunia was on Sean's back, piggyback style, and slightly higher than eye-level to investigate a window â€“ really, a gaping hole â€“ that had only shutters and no glass. The elements could go directly into the building without any barriers.

Regulus had his wand work and went through the same checks as the front door, only to lower his wand shortly after.

"Nothing," he said, eyes wide and with wonder coating his voice. "Not a single spell!"

"I guess wizards think everyone will use the door," teased Petunia as Sean helped her down.

"Guess so," replied Regulus, in a daze. He shook his head, putting his wand in his sheath. He turned to Hermione, already lacing his fingers together. "Shall I give you a boost up?"

Hermione nodded, hands on Regulus's shoulder even as he crouched. She put the toe of her foot into the hollow his hands made and scrambled to get a purchase on the window ledge when he boosted her up. She then hauled herself up and toppled head-first, ass over teakettle, into the shack, landing on a moldy pile of discarded laundry that smelled like piss and shit.

"Ow," she whined.

"You okay in there?" shouted Regulus.

"Fine!" she shouted back, moving away from the pile and making a face as she tried to scrub her dirty hands on already dirty trousers. "Your turn!"

She wasÂ notÂ going to tell him what was going to soften his landing.

Regulus entered next, landing where she did.

"Oh, gross!" he spat, springing up immediately. Unlike her, though, he remembered he was a wizard and castÂ scourgify. Hermione hastily, and embarrassedly, followed, ignoring Regulus's smirk.

The shack was only three rooms: a large living and eating space, a washroom of some kind, and perhaps a single bedroom, although that part of the wall had collapsed, and the door was missing. They had fallen into the living area, opposite the front door, just next to an open arch that led to a large bathtub and porcelain washbasin. The pile of laundry they landed on would have come from the large washing tub, left in a pile for the wash.

With a shared grimace, Regulus began checking the room for spells and deftly bringing them up for Hermione to spot; she followed behind him as he moved, finding the keys in each spell as they deconstructed them, and then, together, they dismantled the interior wards: a flesh-stripping spell on the second floorboard beyond the front door; a blood-boil curse on the oil lantern; a withering curse on the bedroom wall that wasn't collapsed.

Once the two were sure they got everything, including dismantling the door ward from the inside, did they call Sean and Petunia in.

"Are we going to put them back up?" asked Regulus quietly.

"Before we leave, we'll work backward," confirmed Hermione, just as quietly, when Petunia eased into the room and made a loud sound of disgust, bringing a hand up to cover her nose.

Sean whistled lowly. "Wow, what died in here?"

"Hermione's dignity," snickered Regulus, pointing at the dirty streak on her trousers that theÂ scourgifyÂ couldn't remove.

"Fuck you," she said dryly.

"Soâ€¦ where's thisâ€¦Â Horcrux?" asked Sean, carefully pronouncing the foreign word.

Regulus pointed at the second floorboard, which had the flesh-stripping spell on it. "He wanted it close to the door because anyone who made it through would probably think it was hidden further in."

"Not a bad idea," agreed Sean, crouching by the floorboard. "Anything else on this?"

"We got rid of the spell," answered Hermione, carefully stepping aroundÂ whatÂ the spell was.

"And you want this to look like no one was here, right?" confirmed Sean, looking up at her and Regulus.

She nodded.

"Great. Pet, hand me the screwdriver," commanded Sean, pulling on a thick pair of workman's gloves.

The three came to a loose circle around him as he wedged the screwdriver tip between the two floorboards and began wiggling it back and forth. After a few tense moments, he popped the floorboard and nails on one side, and then quickly shuffled to the other end to do the same with the other side of the board. Then, he lifted the rotted board up, revealing a hollow crawlspace below.

"I'm pretty sure I saw a horror film that had a scene like this, once," said Petunia quietly.

Hermione sent her sister a withering glare. "Thanks, Tuney, that wasÂ justÂ what we all needed to hear right now."

"So long as we don't split up," said Sean cheerfully, even as he carefully set the floorboard to the side, nails pointed away from them. "They always do that in the movies, and then get brutally murdered!"

Regulus looked sick. "Muggles have strange entertainment."

"Well, excuse me," said Petunia, tilting her nose up the tiniest amount. "But whatever is down there, it justÂ feelsÂ evil."

Regulus stared at her. "You canâ€¦ feel something?"

Hermione blinked in surprise. "Tuneyâ€¦ you're sensingÂ magic. The Horcrux."

"IÂ am?" asked Petunia, mouth open as she looked between the two. Then, she looked down at the dark crawlspace and shuddered. "That'sÂ what evil magic feels like?"

"What does it feel like?" asked Sean curiously.

Petunia wrapped her arms around herself and shivered again. "Likeâ€¦ being constantly cold. The kind of bad, cold ache you get when you can't warm up after a frigid day. Like you're ready to burst into tears for no reason and don't think you'll ever stop â€“ like you're not good enough forÂ anyoneÂ and you'll be alone f-forever â€“ and you'll just sink into a p-pit of d-despair and anger and j-jealousy because your sisters are better than you atÂ everythingâ€”"

She broke off on a choking sob, alarming Sean.

"That's the Horcrux!" cried Hermione, "She's being affected by it! Sean, take her outside,Â now!"

Sean nodded once and caught Petunia around her waist, bodily lifting her as her face crumpled and she began crying against his neck, wrapping her arms tight around her husband. Sean moved quickly to the door and then all the way to the treeline from what they could see, murmuring to Petunia as she calmed the further away, she was from the Horcrux.

"Bastard," muttered Regulus darkly, using aÂ lumosÂ to peer into the darkness of the crawlspace. At the bottom was a tiny velvet pouch, which he summoned with anÂ accio. Neither touched the pouch, Hermione instead manipulating it withÂ wingardium leviosaÂ to twist the pouch until the opening as at the bottom.

A gold ring with a black onyx gem fell. There was a singleÂ pingÂ of metal hitting the floorboard and then another as it bounced and came to a rest between the two magical users. The metal glinted off theÂ lumosÂ from Regulus's wand.

"That's it," he said, mouth pulled tight into a frown.

Hermione nodded and pulled out the vial of basilisk venom. The bottle was barely half-full now, after destroying several Horcruxes. Hermione held it out to him, in invitation. "Your turn?"

Regulus nodded, handing Hermione his wand. The light dimmed the tiniest amount as she took it, and then pulsed a bit brighter when she sent some of her own magic into his wand.

The wizard rolled his sleeves up, unstopped the vial, and then hovered above it for a moment â€“ and then the HorcruxÂ wailed, a swirl of dark greyish, malevolent smoke burst from it, sweeping up leaves, debris, and dirt inside the shack. TheÂ lumosÂ from the wand barely penetrated the smoke, blocking Petunia and Sean from Hermione's sight.

It formed a tall man, around Sean's age; it was Tom Riddle, older, with slicked-back hair and a cruel gleam to his eyes, which flashed red. "You dare, you filthy blood traitor!"

He took a step forward, a snarl on his face. "You dare bring Muggles to destroyÂ me? You are a traitor to all wizard-kind! You will be disowned, disavowed Black â€“ you will have your nails ripped, your flesh stripped, you very being cursed as youâ€”"

"DO IT NOW, REGULUS!" shouted Hermione, bringing an arm up to block the dirt from getting into her eyes.

What Riddle was saying wasn't anything he hadn't heard before â€“ things Sirius had heard his entire life. If his brother could take what was dished out,Â so could he.

"Brave like Sirius," he whispered to himself and then tipped the rest of the bottle over the ring.

Riddle howled as the venom hit the onyx gem and burned down and around the casing, into the gold. The smoky visage of Tom Riddle burst at once, sending a shockwave of dirt and debris to all corners of the room and leaving Hermione's curly hair a mess with streaks of grey in it from the dust.

Regulus looked worse, like a bag of flour in washed-out grey had exploded in his face. His wavy hair was almost sticking up on end, and he looked more like James with his messy hair.

But the Horcrux was gone, with just the stone left. Whatever curse that was on it previously had been eaten up by the venom, but to be sure, Hermione grabbed Regulus's hand as he reached for it, using his wand to test for anything insidious lingering.

When the spells came back clean, she let go of his hand and he picked up the gem with one hand and took his wand back with the other, doing a doubletake at the gem when the light of his wand hit it a certain way.

"Hermione," he breathed, eyes flicking back and forth between her and the gem, "Is â€“ is this â€“ what I think it is?"

He angled the gem so she could see the triangle and bisecting line in it.

She bit her lip and slowly nodded.

He exhaled, loudly. "This is a â€“"

"ARE YOU TWO OKAY?" shouted Sean, interrupting them.

"Can youÂ pleaseÂ come out now?!" added Petunia, plaintively.

Regulus closed his fist around the gem, keeping it in his hand even as he began to build back up the spells Riddle had cast. Hermione used the discarded tools Sean and Petunia had dropped from her tote bag to put the floorboard back in place, even using the hammer on the nails.

By the time she was done, so was Regulus, and he added the flesh-stripping spell to the board as the last from the inside; they exited the shack together, and he added the spell to the door and snake, hoping that no one would notice how much weaker his Dark spells were than what had originally been there. Perhaps â€“ if Voldemort came to check â€“ he would think the spells eroded over time.

"You're both soÂ dirty!" cried Petunia, reaching for her handkerchief, and wetting it with her mouth. She reached for Hermione and hauled her close, using the wet corner on her sister's cheek.

"Ohmigod, Tuney!" cried Hermione, squirming and trying to wriggle her way out of Petunia's tight grip. "I'mÂ nineteen! You can't just do that to me!"

"Hold still, you've got a spot here," her sister muttered, ignoring her.

"What's that, mate?" asked Sean, pointing at the rock in Regulus's open palm as he stared down at it.

The teenager jerked, startled. He glanced at Sean, then Petunia, and finally a mulish Hermione who had submitted to her sister's mothering. "It'sâ€¦ it's a Deathly Hallow."

"A what now?" asked Sean, frowning.

"It'sâ€¦ from a wizarding fairy-tale," began Regulus, slowly. He seemed unsure. "About three brothers who cheated Death."

"So, someone made a token from the fairy-tale?" asked Petunia, letting Hermione go. "Likeâ€¦ maybe how we make gingerbread houses like inÂ Hansel and Gretel? Or the phrase, 'if the shoe fits' for Cinderella?"

"The story says that anyone who has possession of all three Hallows becomes the Master of Death." He looked at the gem. "Grindelwald searched for these during his reign as a Dark Lord during the war. Apparently, he had a wand â€“ the Death stick, the Elder wand. PeopleÂ worshipÂ the Hallows. I've seen tokens and icons to them, especially in Dark households, butâ€¦ thisÂ feelsÂ different."

Unsurely, Regulus glanced at Hermione. Petunia and Sean looked at her, too, and she sighed, running a hand through her very unruly hair.

"It's the real deal," she said quietly. "Harry had all three in the future. I'm not sure if they ever did anything for him by the Battle of Hogwarts, but he had everything: the wand, the resurrection stone, and the cloak."

Regulus's eyes narrowed. "A cloak? Likeâ€¦ anÂ invisibilityÂ cloak that Potter owns?"

Hermione's eyes rolled skyward â€“ absently noting that the sun was going down â€“ howÂ longÂ had they been in the shack?! â€“ so she didn't have to answer.

"Cloak, stone," muttered Regulus, staring back at the deceptive onyx gem in his hand, "And a wandâ€¦ that Grindelwald last hadâ€¦" He groaned. "Dumbledore's got the wand, hasn't he?"

Hermione did not answer that, but it was enough that Regulus groaned again.

"I don't get it," said Sean, looking at Regulus and Hermione. "What's so special about these Hallows?"

"Legend says that whoever owns all three is the Master of Death," explained Hermione, trying to hide the derision from her voice. "They have dominion over Death itself. The cloak can hide from death; the stone resurrects dead spirits for you to communicate with, and the wand is undefeatable."

"And Potter has the cloak?" added Sean, unsurely. He wasn't sure if he had followed that line from Regulus well, and he was still getting to know his sister-in-law better than vague family gatherings, but he was beginning to know her gestures and facial expressions. "And this is the stone?"

Petunia was staring at it. "How does it evenÂ work?"

"You turn the stone and think about who you want to contact from the other side," explained Hermione absently. "But Harry was never sure if it just brought shades thatÂ lookedÂ like who he wanted, who told him what he needed to hear â€“ or if they were real."

"This is a journalists' dream," muttered Petunia, tearing her eyes from the stone, eventually. She shuddered and took a step back, away from it, and closer to Sean.

"Look, Hermione," began Sean, "If Potter has the cloak, and this is the stone thingy, then you should probably have it."

"What?" three voices cried out.

Sean held his hands up. "Hear me out. Even if it's not true â€“ this whole Master of Death thing â€“ it's worth having, right? A cloak that can hide you from anything, even death â€“ and a stone that you can talk to the dead with? If thisâ€¦ uh, Dark Lord Tomâ€”"

Regulus snorted because the idea of Lord Tom versus Lord Voldemort seemed far less dangerous and the name was beyond humiliating â€“ he could kind of see how a teenaged Riddle wanted an anagram of his name for shock and awe.

"â€”had this, and learns of the other pieces, he might want them, right?" finished Sean.

"He's already split his soul to be immortal," added Petunia, feeling a bit better as she began to enthusiastically speak. "Being the Master of Death seems the next logical step."

Hermione bit her lip, staring at her sister and brother-in-law, and then Regulus. He wordlessly held out the hand with the stone on his palm.

"Take it," he urged. "It'll be safer with you than anyone else, Hermione. Keep it in the Potter line. The Potters were Peverells, you know."

"I know," she answered, voice soft. She knew. With a sigh, she took the stone, pocketing it and zipping the pocket up so it wouldn't accidentally disappear on her. The weight of the stone in her pocket was noticeable, for such a tiny thing, and Hermione felt more than the weight of the piece â€“ she felt the weight ofÂ expectationÂ andÂ destinyÂ on her.

"Well, I think that's about enough excitement for me," stated Sean, forcing a smile on his face as he brushed his hands together, dusting them off. "Shall we head back to the B&B?"

The others gave a chorus of agreements; Petunia remained by the treeline with Hermione; Sean went to the back of the shack of Regulus, wand lighting the way, to pick up the forgotten and unused shovel. Once all their pieces were collected, and Regulus and Hermione did one last sweep to ensure all the spells were back up, they turned to trudge through the dark forest that surrounded the Gaunt shack at the bottom of the hill the Riddle manor lorded over.

They had only walked a bit in when a loudÂ snapÂ broke through the quiet of the forest.

Sean and Regulus immediately stopped â€“ the two were at the front â€“ causing Petunia to bump into her husband's back. "Ow, Sean, whatâ€”"

"Sshh!" chided Sean, not even glancing back. He and Regulus were looking around warily, and Hermione palmed her wand, turning so she was back-to-back with the two young men, Petunia sandwiched between them.

Crack.

Hermione spun, facing the sound; Regulus had his wand up, pointed at the sound.

Snap.

The third noise came from their other side, and Hermione pursed her lips, turning with Regulus so both, with wands out, were facing both sides. Sean gripped the shovel tightly.

Before Hermione, a pinprick of light spread into a bright halo. She blinked back spots that danced in front of her. The halo of light dimmed somewhat, and Hermione's mouth dropped open. Familiar burnt orange hair, a long face dusted with freckles, and that nose were as familiar to her as Harry's emerald eyes and messy black hair and scars.

Ron?Â She wanted to ask, but the hard look on the wizard's face stopped her as he emerged from between two trees, absently brushing aside one low-hanging branch with brown leaves stubbornly clinging to it. A few fell at his action, one clinging to his dark trousers.

As familiar as the man seemed to Ron Weasley, there was something inherently more dangerous to him that reminded her a bit of Charlie, a bit of Moody. She wracked her brain, her barely-there memories, for who the Weasley man was.

"Well, well," he drawled, grip tightening on his wand. "What do we have here, Gid?"

"Two baby Death Munchers taking some unsuspecting Muggles for a stroll in the spooky, dark forest, Fab," replied the other masculine voice from Regulus's side, causing Hermione to turn her head a bit to see an identical looking man â€“ although this one had longer, waver hair than the closely-cropped locks of the wizard before her.

Oh,Â thought Hermione, realization crashing on her. Her knees wobbled even as her breath hitched.Â Oh.

Gideon and Fabian Prewett.

Then, her eyes widened. Gideon and Fabian Prewett â€“ who were killed during the first wizarding war by Death Eaters.

"Oh, shit," slipped from her mouth, unbidden.

Fabian Prewett â€“ the wizard holding his wand to light them up â€“ gave a tiny smirk. "Oh shit, indeed, little witch. Nowâ€¦ why don't you step away from the Muggles, careful like, and put down your wands. So, we can have a littleâ€¦Â chat."

{TBC...}

All What Is in Between

Chapter Notes

HPWiki says Gideon was alive until July 1981 at a minimum, due to taking a picture with Marlene McKinnon, but you knowâ€¦ artistic licensing at play here. There is also NO MENTION of their careers, so while fanon usually has them as Aurors, Iâ€™ve decided to change things up. I retroactively went back to my earlier chapter that had them as Aurors as well and removed that.

On my Tumblr, I have face-claims for many of these characters we donâ€™t see or know about in canon (book and film). Feel free to pop by to look at them! These are part of my ongoing pureblood family tree, which is now up to approx. 1300 people!

Also had a review with someone upset that Hermioneâ€™s telling people the truth. I was surprised! In many time travel stories, the people closest to the time-traveling Hermione turn on her and get upset for not saving Lily, James, etc. when they finally learn sheâ€™s from the future if the secret is revealed. Wellâ€¦ what happens when she does or is actively doing something about it? When does she tell people ahead of these nail-biting situations? How does that change the story? What happens when people also know? Are they suddenly held responsible when things go wrong because of the knowledge they now have?

PS: props to those of you who caught the Hamilton reference last chapter ğŸ˜‰ As a reminder, the quotes at the beginning from TV shows and movies (all of which are excellent, so if you havenâ€™t watched them yet, DO SO. Quarantine is the best time, after allâ€¦) are [mostly] relevant. Not just because I love them all or theyâ€™re about time travel.

Trigger warning: graphic (?) death in the first section.

See the end of the chapter for more notes

Yesterday is Tomorrow (Everything is Connected)

TWENTY-THREE

You're gonna have to have to forgive yourself for what you've done, for what you're going to have to do. There's a beginning and there's an end, always. All you and I are ever going to have is what's in between...

â€“ James Cole (Future) to James Cole (Present),Â 12 Monkeys

October 1979

Fabian Prewett â€“ the wizard holding his wand to light them up â€“ gave a tiny smirk. "Oh shit, indeed, little witch. Nowâ€¦ why don't you step away from the Muggles, careful like, and put down your wands. So, we can have a littleâ€¦Â chat."

Neither Hermione nor Regulus moved. Regulus, because he was glaring at Gideon Prewitt whoÂ clearlyÂ knew who he was (Dorea's genealogy lessons were paying off: Molly, Gideon, and Fabian's mother Lucretia Black was Regulus and Sirius's father's sister. They were cousins), given the hard stare the redhead was giving Hermione's friend.

For Hermione, though, she froze; Fabian and Gideon Prewitt were odd concepts of names and images of people she and her friends had never met nor heard much of except in some passing stories from Molly and Arthur. Harry had Fabian's watch, but the two were just another in a list of meaningless people who were part of the first Order of the Phoenix who died trying to stop Voldemort.

To see them, in the flesh, so to speak, was something Hermione did not anticipate. Caradoc Dearborn had been an anomaly, and with their escape, she hadn't paid much attention to him or evenÂ spokeÂ to him. Fabian, however, was staring at her, waiting for her compliance or a reply.

Or, given that he thought she was a Death Eater, perhaps a spell or evil cackle. She wasn't too sure.

"Hermioneâ€¦ who are these wizards?" asked Petunia, quietly, from between her, Regulus, and Sean. She was clutching her tote bag tightly to her chest, staring equally as hard as Fabian was at them, although Petunia's eyes were narrowed, and her lips were pinched.

Fabian blinked, his wand falling a fraction. "Wizardsâ€¦? You know about magic?"

Petunia's stare and facial expression easily broadcast how stupid she thought the wizard was. "Obviously."

"Thenâ€¦" trailed off Fabian, looking from Hermione to Regulus and back to Petunia, "Whoâ€¦ why are you with Black?"

"He's my little sisters'Â best friend," bit out Petunia, stepping to brush her shoulder with Hermione, side-by-side in a show of solidarity. Hermione's heart beat faster, and she suddenly understood why Regulus didn't want her to tell Petunia and Sean â€“ neither had wands, they were Muggles, what could they do against two older, Moody-trained wizards with wands and grudges? â€“ but another part of her nearly burst with pride.

Fabian's wand lowered more. His blue eyes jerked over at Hermione.

"I don't believe this," burst out Gideon from behind. "He's aÂ Black! This area is saturated with Dark magic â€“ Fabe, c'mon, you don'tÂ believeÂ this hippogriff dung, do you?"

"I might be a Black," interrupted Regulus scathingly, "But you also have a Black in your precious Order, don't you? Or has my brother's informal adoption by my great-aunt and herÂ PotterÂ husband made him greater than my family's value of an Ancient and Noble house?"

"Potter's are light-oriented folk," snapped Gideon, brows furrowed in anger.

"If that's the case, then there shouldn't be any worries here," added Sean carefully, shifting his weight a bit and tightening his grip on the shovel's handle as all eyes swung toward him.

"â€¦ what?" grit out Gideon.

Sean tipped his head in his sister-in-law's direction. "That's Hermione, my wife's sister. Who is married to JamesÂ Potter."

Gideon's eyes darted to Hermione and she gave a tiny, limp-wristed wave from over her shoulder. "Hello."

"Oh," said Fabian, his wand lowering completely. "Wellâ€¦ umâ€¦"

"You're bloodyÂ kidding!" Gideon stared hard at Hermione. "What in Merlin's name are you doing outÂ hereÂ of all places with Muggles?"

Hermione blinked innocently at him and gave her best doe-eyed look. "Sightseeing?"

"Pull the other one!" Fabian snorted, mouth twitching into the tiniest of smiles.

Petunia sighed. "I'm a journalist. I'm investigating an unsolved murder, and Hermione wanted to come along in case things went poorly. Of course, my husband was going to come along, and then Hermione thought it would be best if Regulus came as well since James is at work this weekend."

That was a good cover story,Â thought Hermione proudly. It even hinted mostly at the truth!

Gideon was still suspicious, his eyes narrowed; Fabian, on the other hand, seemed to be taken by them and was even nodding along unconsciously. He peered over Hermione and Petunia to catch his brother's eyes.

"Gid, I really think that they're alright," he began. "They're notâ€”"

"Avada Kedavra!"

Hermione pushed Petunia to her knees as a vivid green spell soared over her head, toward Fabian. Petunia screamed even as Fabian cursed loudly and threw himself behind a tree, hisÂ lumosÂ failing. The clearing they were in plunged into darkness except for the bright green from the killing curse as he let the spell hit and shatter the trunk, sending woodchips and any stubbornly clinging leaves flying.

Regulus had his wand out and was conjuring a golden shield, Sean at his back and facing the other direction with Gideon already sending return spellfire in the direction of the killing curse. There was more multicolour spellfire from that direction, leaving Regulus and Gideon as the defenders and protecting Sean.

From in front of Hermione, a tall figure with a hood pulled low to their nose appeared from the darkness, between the twisting bare branches of the trees around them, already casting, his wand tip red and pulsing.

Hermione flicked her arm to the side, runes running up and down her jacket's sleeve, forming a long, glowing orange cuff with the runes rotating around the interlocking symbols and inside their individual banners. The orange illuminated her face just as the pulsing red from the wizard's wand eerily cast shadows under his hood.

The wizard let the spell fly, and Hermione brought her arm up to protect her face. The spell hit the runes with a loudÂ ping!, shaking her arm, but it ricocheted off back at the wizard, who swore and dodged it. His hood fell, revealing a middle-aged man: very pale-faced, with dark curly hair, and a sharply blunted chin.

He scowled, and Fabian popped out from behind the tree and shouted, "Expulso!"

The man dodged the spell, laughing darkly. "Is that all you've got, Prewett? You reallyÂ areÂ just a glorified parchment-pusher!"

Fabian's face hardened, and he silently sent a spell at the man; he again, dodged, closer to Hermione. He didn't notice her, focused as he was on Fabian who lobbied another spell at him to dodge, and Hermione snapped her wand up in her other hand not covered by her runes, knocking him back with a knockback jinx.

It connected. He grunted as he tripped backward, slamming hard into a young tree that bent and then broke in half, sending him tumbling with his legs in the air.

"Oh, for Merlin's sake, Pyrites!" sneered the man fighting with Gideon, gasping for breath between his words. He apparated, his pop echoing loudly in the forest, and appeared next to the broken tree, reaching down to yank the fallen man up.

Regulus and Gideon whirled, Sean behind them, to face the two Death Eaters as a united front. Regulus's golden shield was providing enough light to illuminate the small area: the path she, Petunia, and Sean were on; some of the grass behind them and bush that Regulus and the Prewetts stood by, and the first row of thin trees the Death Eaters stood clustered around, like thick tree trunks themselves.

This man was not wearing a Death Eater mask; he had tanned skin, blond hair, and a hard, square face with narrow eyes. As it was, she didn't know either of the men â€“Â they must only be for the higher-ranking members that Voldemort wants to protect from the public so no one knows who they are,Â Hermione thought.

What sheÂ didÂ know, was that between her, Regulus, Gideon, and Fabian, there were four wands and the Death Eaters only had two. This was not the night the Prewett brothers died, she realized with relief in her body, making her vaguely limp.

"Snyde," sneered Gideon, naming the other man. "Bit far from home, innit?"

"I could say the same to you, Prewett," the blond wizard bit, beady eyes darting over the large group. His sneer deepened when his eyes lingered on Petunia and Sean. "And consorting with the filth? What would your dear ol' mum have to say about that?"

"Oh, I don't know," interrupted Regulus, making the two Death Eaters look at him. "Auntie Lucretia was always a bit more open about her beliefs than mother's side of the Blacks."

Pyrites blinked; mouth open. "Regulus Black!"

"In the flesh," the younger wizard replied, dryly. "Now, I believe my cousins asked you what you were doing here."

Hermione bit back the smile that threatened to appear. Regulus publicly calling the Prewetts his cousins were more than just fact â€“ it meant he was siding with them, a united stance against Voldemort's campaign in which the Blacks â€“ Sirius, Regulus, perhaps even Orion â€“ were supporting the patriarchal Black line, including Orion's sister and her Prewett children. They were aligned, allies, and despite what Walburga's side of the Black family did through Bellatrix or even Narcissa, Regulus and his side would not stand for it.

"What areÂ youÂ doing here?" a new voice cried out in shock, stepping out from behind the blond. He too was blond, with curly hair, and awfully familiar. Hermione froze as stared at the wizard, also in black. He was gripping his wand tightly, but nervously with the way he stared at Hermione and Regulus â€“ his former year mates, and in Hermione's case, housemate.

"Wilkes?" she gapped.

"You know that wizard?" muttered Petunia under her breath, brushing up against her sister nervously.

Sputtering, Hermione managed to whisper back, "We were in the same house at Hogwarts. We shared a dorm."

"Evans," greeted Wilkes, nodding in her direction. The blond man â€“ who looked somewhat like Wymond Wilkes, now that Hermione saw them standing side-by-side â€“ clasped the ex-Ravenclaw's shoulder. Wilkes winced.

"Wy! You didn't tell me you knew Hermione Evans," the man grinned, although it was a nasty expression. His eyes locked on her. "You'll have to excuse my nephew and his poor manners. Rosier! Why don't you introduce us all to your old classmates?"

"Rosier?" muttered Regulus from just behind Hermione, his tone growing more irate as he spoke. "What is this, a Hogwarts reunion? Is Travers going to show up now? Albert Runcorn? Oliver Avery?Â Clancy Brown?"

Hermione resisted laughing as he finished at a near-growl â€“ Regulus had finished his Hogwarts career without securing a date with Calypso Fawcett, who ended up dating Brown instead.

Evan Rosier was another classmate of theirs, along with Wilkes, but he had been a Slytherin and, according to Regulus, shy and unassuming. The fact thatÂ twoÂ of their year mates were along with Pyrites and Wilkes' uncle was enough for Hermione to cringe; this was an initiation for them. Evan sulked out from behind the two older men, tall, gangly, with a head full of curls all Blacks inherited. His hands were stuffed in his pockets and he slouched, reminding Hermione a bit of Barty when he got sulky.

"Evans," greeted Rosier with a mulish pout. "Regulus."

Both Regulus and Hermione gapped at the Ravenclaw and Slytherin, equally, even as Wilkes' uncle squeezed the wizard's shoulder, making Wilkes tense and gasp out, "What are you doing here?" he then eyed the two redheads. "And withÂ them?"

Regulus and Hermione shared a glance.

"Helping my sister with her job," she finally said, settling on Petunia's lie. There was a tiny prickling of unease, but Hermione brushed it away. "We ran into the Prewetts here."

"Here? Not much to see, is there?" Pyrites looked around the dark forest, eyes wide in mock surprise. They narrowed on Hermione. "Of course, there is theâ€¦Â alluringÂ scent of magicâ€¦"

Hermione hid a wince. That was one way to explain away the stink of Dark magic that permeated the forest from the Gaunt family's rituals and spellcasting over the decades.

"Yeah, well, you know," Regulus drawled blithely, sounding far too like Sirius for Hermione's comfort, "You get a few duds when it comes to vacations. Nothing here at all to see: ten out of ten wouldÂ notÂ recommend."

The weight of the stares of those in the forest was heavy on Regulus. Behind them all, Sean clapped a free hand to his face and moaned, "Oh, Jesus, that wasÂ soÂ badâ€¦"

Regulus flushed, pulling a bit on his jacket as he straightened it nervously. He muttered, "Yes, wellâ€¦ I panicked."

Pursing her lips, Hermione turned back to Rosier and Wilkes, eyeing her former year mates. She began shuffling Petunia closer to Sean, and down the dirt path, they had taken from the path that led to the Riddle house and cemetery. The prickling was worse, like eyes on her back. It made the small hairs at the nape of her neck tickle.

"Listen â€“ we were just out for a stroll. We don't have any conflict with you, soâ€¦ we'll be on our way."

Wilkes closed his eyes, relief shining on his face, but his uncle squeezed his shoulder again and stepped forward. "But we have so much to talk about, Evans! Like â€“ how you left Malfoy Manor so quickly."

"Not much to talk about there," replied Hermione carefully, her eyes moving between the two older wizards. Rosier and Wilkes didn't seem interested in participating â€“ which made Hermione wonder justÂ whatÂ Wilkes had seen or done since he last tried to talk to Barty about joining â€“ which meant that Snyde and Pyrites were the two to watch.

"I beg to differ, lisonok."

Hermione inhaled sharply, her entire body freezing as the masculine voice drifted toward the group from behind. SheÂ knewÂ that voice; sheÂ knewÂ that wizard, very, very well, and had hoped it would be years before she ran into that specific Death Eater again.

Slowly, she turned even as the prickling she felt from earlier hit her full force, as dark eyes framed by tousled hair and a long face slipped between the thin trees. The wizard's shadow was as smoky and ephemeral as a ghost until he emerged facing Sean, just paces away.

"You,"Â breathed Hermione, her voice lost in the ambient noises of the forest and the rustle of leaves from a breeze.

Nearby, Regulus glanced at Hermione in worry from between Petunia and Gideon. There were very few people who could reduce Hermione to who she was from before, and his cousin was not in front of them.

The man was tall and lean, older than Hermione, with longish dark hair and pale eyes against a lean face. He wore wizard's robes that were different to what the British wore; they had more of a military cut to them in the sharp angles on the robes that were cut off at the waist, with tails; his trousers tucked into well-worn boots. His eyes fixated on Hermione.

"I am afraid we have not had the pleasure," he began, his voice accented. His mouth tipped into a smile â€“ if one could call it that. "Although I am aware of you, Miss Evans. I am Antonin Dolohov."

He finished his introduction with a tiny, sharp bow.

"Potter," snarled Hermione, instinctively. "It's Potter."

He inclined his head as he straightened. "Yes, I heard you were recently married. My congratulations."

Hermione barred her teeth in a silent snarl, and the man continued to speak, even as Regulus inched toward Hermione.

"When my Lord spoke of your magic and talents, I was intrigued. I had so wanted to be there that evening to see your abilities." His eyes glittered. "Perhaps you would do me the honour of showing me now?"

"Hermione," warned Regulus, under his breath.

"Gladly," she snapped, ignoring her friend. Her wand jutted out and nonverbally, she cast; the ground beneath Dolohov's feet turned from dirt to sand, immediately sinking him to his knees.

That seemed to be the signal for the free-for-all: Snyde and Pyrites immediately launched forward with their own spells, both at Fabian and Gideon. Regulus was forced backward, away from Hermione to defend Fabian, while Gideon â€“ and Sean, nearby â€“ were immediately on the defensive.

Wilkes and Rosier lingered behind the older Death Eaters, carefully prowling around for openings in which they slunk their own spells through, only for Regulus to throw himself forward in a desperate bid to block, or Sean used the shovel to catch the spell.

But Dolohov was clever; he apparated out of the quicksand to solid ground several feet away, causing Hermione to keep on her heel to face him. She launchedÂ incarcerousÂ at him, ropes flinging themselves from her wand to bind the wizard, but he burnt them, using the smoke from the ropes as cover to apparate closer to her until he was an arms' length away. His eyes, pale, were cold and focused on her.

Hermione gasped, up close to one of her two personal demons from her last life. But she wasn't a sixteen-year-old girl, untrained, anymore. Despite that, instinct overtook, and she slapped the wizard.

He blinked in shock, and Hermione took a cue from his playbook, and apparate several feet away.

Dolohov's eyes snapped to her new location. A glint of amusement appeared, and he apparated â€“ landing just shy of her new position, and with a spell already flying toward her.

Hermione spun and disapparated. She appeared behind him, shouting, "Expulso!"

He sensed her and knelt, the spell flying above him and disappearing down the path into the darkness that led back to the Gaunt shack. Glancing at her over his shoulder, he snarled and cried, "Avada Kedavra!"

Hermione twisted the earth below her feet into the same smooth wall of earth she once used to block Snape's attack on James when they were teenagers at Hogwarts; the killing curse impacted the wall and sent bits of dirt and clumps everywhere. A cloud of dirt blocked her vision.

A wind charm sent the dirt away, but the space where Dolohov was, was empty. She blinked.

"Behind you, lisonok," a cold voice breathed against her ear.

Hermione's heart slammed hard against her chest and she disapparated, blindly, appearing several meters down the path and away from the others.

Dolohov caught her wide, panicked eyes and grinned. He disapparated.

Spinning, Hermione's eyes darted everywhere for the Death Eater. When he didn't immediately appear, Hermione knelt and placed both hands flat on the ground, sending her magic through the earth in search of any ley lines or magic to connect to. She could feel the inky darkness of the Gaunt shack behind her, and there was no way she would tap into that magic to help â€“ it felt like tar was clogging her throat and she wasn't even calling it to her. There was a faint trace of magic closer to the Riddle grounds, but it felt jagged, and it took Hermione a moment to realize it was Voldemort's, fractured and raw from when he killed his father and grandparents and made a Horcrux.

Instead, Hermione closed her eyes and let her magic sweep over the others: Fabian and Gideon were two, warm bright embers in the dark, equal in power and strength that flared and waned like a candle flickering as they fought. Regulus as a steady presence of thick water, cool and steady as he kept his wits about him and continued to cast with precision and focus. Petunia barely registered, but was a tiny bubble, while Sean was a dull, empty space in her senses.

Snyde and Pyrites were dark blights, nowhere near as dark as others she had encountered, but felt disgusting, like one smelling rotten egg when not expecting it. Wilkes and Rosier were tainted, but nowhere near the older wizards' magic: they instead felt like a clear evening sky, dark but with enough light from the moon and stars.

But where was Dolohov?

Her magic spread out a bit further, licking at the base of the nearby trees, andâ€”

Above!Â Hermione's eyes popped open and her head jerked up. Dolohov caught her eyes from where he was attached to one of the thicker, older trees, using sticking charms to keep himself against the trunk.

His wand was pointed at her, and with a grim look, he cast something familiar: a rough purple spell, moving quickly, raced down at her.

Hermione froze for the tiniest of moments and then threw herself forward, rolling out of the way as the spell hit the earth behind her in a small crater, sending dirt everywhere.

A pop made her dodge left, even as Dolohov followed her, sending spell after spell. Hermione alternated between castingÂ protego, summoning physical branches to block his spells, or outright dodging, until she was once again in the fray of the others, close to where Petunia stood behind Regulus, clutching her tote bag.

Rosier seemed unsure of what to do, unsure of working alongside others â€“ not the way that Hermione could battle with Regulus and Barty at her back without worry â€“ and struggled to find openings to cast at Regulusâ€¦ or it was he just didn't want to hit his old Slytherin dormmate.

But he did cast a spell, one Hermione recognized as a schoolyard levelÂ tarantallegra. Regulus instinctively avoided it, but Petunia didn't know what it was and didn't have the experience of dodging flashes of light and spellfire the way the others did. Petunia let out a shriek, twisting out of the way of his spell with wide eyes.

Her response to the fighting was the throw her tote bag toward Rosier. He wasn't expecting it â€“ his eye went wide at the sight of the neon green, fringed bag flying at him â€“ and it smacked him, hard, in the face, given it was filled with their notes, the Horcrux, and Petunia's odds and ends. He let out a loud exhale and hit the floor, falling backward into a prickly bush.

"Pet!" Sean swung around, the shovel flying with him as he did so.

At Sean's side, Gideon went under the wide swing of the shovel, tripping backward and away from Pyrites as the wizard sneered at him, wand up and snapping out of the first syllables to his spell.

However, Sean continued with the swing, something wild and wide in his eyes, and Pyrites didn't have time to dodge or castÂ protego. The metal end of the shovel connected with his head and Pyrites collapsed, like a puppet whose string had been cut. Blood pooled under him and Hermione could only see it from the faint flashes of spellfire, causing the liquid to glisten.

"Holy shit!" gasped Regulus, breathlessly. Gideon froze for a second, staring down at Pyrites, and then transferring his stare at Sean â€“ although the Muggle didn't seem to notice or care.

Hermione ducked under a spell, absently, and scrambled toward Petunia. She was squatting, arms over her head with her eyes closed. Hermione fell to her knees, next to her sister, and touched her shoulder.

Petunia shrieked again, and this time Hermione dodged her pen. "Whoa! Tuney, it'sÂ me!"

Petunia's eyes peeled open. "Hermione?"

"Yes, hello," replied Hermione, sighing in relief. "Are you okay?"

Sean fell to his knees then, on Petunia's other side, and dropped his bloodied shovel. "Pet!"

"Sean!" sobbed Petunia, falling into his arms.

He and Hermione shared a look over Petunia's head, and Hermione quickly swivelled and stood in one motion. Hermione placed her bare palm on the trunk of the tree nearest to her. Runes and symbols in green raced up and down the bark from where her palm was placed, and behind the markings, the tree began to wiggle as though alive.

Then, its branches swung down, and its roots pulled up and out of the earth. The tree came alive, groaning under the strain of moving. Wilkes cried out, stumbling back over his feet and into his uncle.

Snyde sneered, his wand arm moving in harsh slashing cuts; the red of aÂ reductoÂ emerged, one spell after another as he battered against the tree. Each hit sent the tree reeling back, but only a little, as it recovered and continued.

Fabian took advantage of Snyde's preoccupation, his own spells causing the wizard to curse and split his attention between the tree and Fabian.

"Wymond! Do something, boy!" shouted Snyde.

Wilkes stuttered through a spell, barely effective as hisÂ bombardaÂ only managed to send one limb fly from the tree.

The tree paused, briefly, and then one of its branches launched forward, sharp, and thin, toward Wilkes. Like the Whomping Willow, it wrapped around the young wizard's ankle and lifted him off the ground, flinging him through the air, crying.
