"Oh, for Merlin's sake!" Snyde turned on his heel and used the cutting curse to hit the branch that had his nephew, and Wilkes fell to the earth, hard, groaning. He then summoned the young man, turning on his heel again to face Fabian, whose aim was true.

His cutting curse cut through the space between him and Snyde; but Snyde had summoned Wilkes, and let the spell continue to use him as a human shield. The cutting curse hit Wilkes in the chest, racing up to his neck.

The Ravenclaw classmate of Hermione's made a soft sound â€“ something she heard over the general noise of their fight â€“ as his eyes went wide and his face, pale. He then fell to his knees, and then back.

"WILKES!"Â someone shouted. It took Hermione a moment to realize it was her, just as Rosier shouted, "Wy!"

"Until the next, lisonok."

Hermione's eyes pulled from Wilkes' body to Dolohov. He lowered his wand, casting a cold look around their battle: Sean and Petunia, partially hidden by Gideon; Fabian, his chest heaving even as his eyes focused on Wilkes' body; Regulus, who was casting to keep Snyde from moving toward them; and Rosier, who had dropped to Wilkes' side.

Dolohov's pale eyes lingered on Hermione for a moment; she shivered. His lips turned upward in the tiniest of quirks, and he reached out to grab Rosier, kneeling by Wilkes.

"Whatâ€”" Rosier's sentence was cut off as Dolohov apparated them both, the pop loud. Snyde swore and followed, not even pausing to look at his nephew, gasping on the ground.

Those who remained barely breathed, frozen until Hermione darted forward and she was at Wilkes' side. His eyes focused on her, wide and terrified, as blood bubbled out from Fabian's curse. His neck was the worst, sending the blood gushing out, quickly.

Regulus swore as he appeared next to her, conjuring cloths. Hermione plucked them from the air, pressing hard against the neck wound. "C'mon Wilkes. Stay with me."

She looked up at Regulus. "Can we get him to St. Mungo's?"

"Why would youâ€”" burst out Gideon, his voice thick with anger, but he broke off when Fabian placed a hand on his brother's shoulder.

Regulus, who had been staring at Wilkes, moved his eyes at Hermione and said nothing.

"Reg?" Hermione's voice strained and cracked as she stared at him. When he slowly turned away, Hermione inhaled sharply and turned back to Wilkes, who was staring at her.

He tried to raise a trembling hand, and Hermione caught it, clutching it tightly. "It's going to be okay, Wilkes."

Wilkes' mouth opened and he wheezed something she couldn't make out. His mouth closed and he tried again, his voice thin and whistling. Blood dribbled down his chin. "Whhâ€”whhâ€”Wymond."

Hermione sniffed. "Okay. Okay. It's going to be okay, Wymond. I'mâ€¦ I'm right here."

His blue eyes were cloudy with pain, and his body shuddered. He strained, gasping, "He'mione."

"Wymond?"

But his eyes clouded over, and then the blue dulled. His body relaxed, and the grip Wilkes had on Hermione's hand eased, slipping from hers until it hit the ground, a soft thud.

Hermione sniffed again, and asked, thickly, "Wymond?"

Regulus reached out and carefully closed Wilkes' eyes.

Somehow, by unspoken agreement, the six found themselves at the local pub in Little Hangleton, not wishing to expend the energy to either Apparate out to London or summon the Knight Bus to take them â€“ plus Petunia and Sean â€“ elsewhere.

The pub itself, the Hanged Man, was dingy and dirty and empty except for the usual crowd of men who stared blearily into their pints and kept to themselves in the darkened corners of the low-ceiling pub. The six wearily sat at a table near the front window, Hermione and Regulus allowing Gideon to take the most secure position with his back against the wall, while they took the others by a column facing the bar. Fabian, Petunia, and Sean were left with the window at their back.

Sean ordered them all pints, despite the early time, and collected them with Petunia's help, distributing the glasses to everyone. No one spoke: Fabian stared at his drink, and Regulus's head kept slipping down toward his chest as he nodded off, only to jerk back up every so often. Hermione stared at the blood on her hands, in her lap, and out of sight from the barkeep.

There was a weary, exhausted feeling in the air for the group after what they had just experienced, but it was Fabian who cleared his throat first, and tentatively said, "Soâ€¦ we don't tell anyone about this, right?"

Hermione turned curious eyes on the short-haired redhead. "Don't you need to tell Dumbledore?"

Gideon scowled at her. "How do you know about that?"

"That you're part of his Order?" Regulus yawned. "Kind of obvious, cousin."

"And what wereÂ youÂ doing out in the forest?" prodded Petunia, leaning forward over the table toward the two twins. "You never said."

Fabian answered first, ignoring his brother's hiss. "We've been combing quadrants for Dumbledore â€“ checking areas for dark magic. We mark them up and then send a team to do recon in the area if there is anything lingering. It was our first time in Little Hangleton and what happens but us coming across you lot."

"So, it was all by luck?" asked Sean, blinking. "You weren't sent out to find Hermione and Regulus?"

Fabian and Gideon shared a glance, with Gideon turning back to them, brows furrowed. "Um, noâ€¦?"

Hermione exhaled in relief.

"And really," continued Fabian, eyes darting between the four of them, "We really didn't come across anyone but dark wizards, did we? I meanâ€”" he broke off and shared another look with Gideon, this one a bit grim "â€“we'll probably have to tell Dumbledore we had a fight and Wilkes isâ€”"

This time, Regulus inhaled sharply. Hermione's hand clenched in her lap and she stared down hard at them, the dried blood on them drawing her gaze. Petunia reached for her sister and placed a clean hand over Hermione's. Hermione looked up at her, and Petunia's eyes were soft when she squeezed her hand.

"Yeah," mumbled Regulus, turning to look out the thick, warped glass of the pub's window, blinking rapidly. He and Wilkes had not been friends â€“ nor dorm mates the way Hermione and Barty had been with the wizard, butâ€¦ - he gave a tiny, delicate sniff.

The group fell to silence again, but then Sean picked up his pint, held it out, and Hermione and Regulus, upon realizing what he was doing, copied him. Petunia was next, and then Fabian. Gideon followed last, a sour look on his face as he did so, but said nothing as the group held their glasses aloft for a silent toast.

They each took a sip.

Then, Fabian turned to them, and asked, voice rift with curiosity, "Yes, but whatÂ wereÂ you doing out there?"

Hermione put her glass down and leaned across the table, closer to him. "Can you keep a secret, Fabian?"

The redhead mimicked her, leaning across the table, and nodded earnestly.

"Good." Hermione's lips spread into a tiny smile. "So can I."

He scowled and Gideon snorted into his glass. The other twin chuckled and asked, "Why the bloody hell aren't you in Dumbledore's Order?" his eyes slid to Hermione and then Regulus. "Especially given your husband and your brother are involved."

Hermione leaned back and shrugged. "Honestly? I don't really trust Dumbledore."

"You don't trust the greatest wizard, ever?" asked Fabian, stupefied.

"I trust that he's trying to stop the war," said Hermione carefully, "But I don't think he's going about it the best way. I think he's limited by his position and those in power in the Ministry, but I think he has you running out toÂ reactÂ instead ofÂ act. I also think he keeps things from his members, only telling them what he thinks they should know instead of everything theyÂ shouldÂ know when going into a situation."

Gideon was looking at her, hard but curious-like, and slowly nodded.

"I can see that," he finally said, slowly. "And that was what made you go off on your own?"

"Who said we're doing things on our own?" bit out Regulus immediately, eyes fixated on his cousin.

Gideon's eyebrows rose. "Well, aren't you?"

"I can neither confirm nor deny such action," rejoined Hermione, carefully keeping her eyes on Gideon.

He slowly nodded.

Petunia cleared her throat. "So, Fabian, Gideon. What do you do as a career when you're not out trying to save the magical world? That one wizard said something about a parchment-pusherâ€¦?"

Fabian groaned and Gideon snickered. "Fabe's a curse breaker."

Hermione's mouth dropped open.

"But he spends most of his time doing research for Gringott's instead of out on site," continued Gideon, "Hence the 'parchment pusher' epithet." He paused and then looked around the table. "As for myself, you might have noticed my suspicious behaviour toward you. It is becauseÂ IÂ am a junior investigator at the Daily Prophet."

"You're a journalist?" squeaked Petunia, eyes wide. "So am I! I was the one who found the information that led us hereâ€”"

And like that, Gideon and Petunia were off, shooting questions and replies and forth, with Sean eagerly invested in the conversation as he asked for clarification from the magical side of things.

"â€”figure out this Dark Lord that's bothering everyone, anyway, his father was a Riddle and his mother must have come from here," Petunia was saying.

Gideon, who was in the process of taking a drink, choked and the ale came out of his nose even as he held a hand up to block it. He stared at Petunia. "What? You-Know-Who's father was aÂ muggle?"

Petunia hesitantly nodded, looking unsure if she should be disgusted at the brown liquid dripping from Gideon's nose or not.

"AndÂ youÂ found this out?" continued Gideon, eyes wide. "By just doing research on the muggle side of things?"

Amused, Hermione commented, "It's amazing what a partnership can do when you share things."

Gideon and Fabian made noises of agreement, but Hermione's eyes had slid away as he caught Petunia's stare. She wilted the tiniest bit, seeing Petunia's thin eyebrows shoot toward her hairline with the most unimpressed look Petunia could ever create.

Hypocrite, the look seemed to say.

Hermione sighed.Â I know, she wanted to reply to Petunia, but Sean was off telling Gideon and Fabian what he knew of the situation regarding Voldemort, the Riddles, with Regulus carefully following along to stop him if he needed to.

Hermione knew she would have to tell James soon â€“ but the question was, when would be the best time to tell her husband that she had lived a previous life in the future and knew things that no one should have ever known? All that she, Barty, and Regulus were doing?

When would she stop being the brainy Hermione Evans, Ravenclaw, and dig deep and bring out that Gryffindor courage that Hermione Granger was known to be instead?

Halloween, 1979

James was snoring heavily beside Hermione, one arm thrown over her midsection. Her bladder was making itself known, but Hermione was still bleary and headachy from the excessive alcohol she had consumed at the Halloween party she and James had thrown the day before and had no desire to move from the bed, find something to put on to cover her naked self, or to leave the warmth of the bed.

Even if her bladder kept insistently pulsing. She'd wait until James moved first â€“ or a miracle happened.

A silver streak flew toward them, coming through the wall. Hermione shrieked, throwing James's arm off her; the lights on the wall, all gas, lit themselves as Hermione began moving, leaving their bedroom in a soft, orange-tinted glow from behind heavy, thick glass.

James, himself, woke with a snort due to Hermione's heavy handling. Unsure of what was going on, he threw himself off the bed, summoning his wand directly into his hand. He was in a crouch, blinking as he tried to focus on the glowing bird hovering in the air at the foot of their bed.

"What the fâ€”"

"James. A large magical disturbance is occurring at the Rolling Stones," said Dumbledore, his voice coming from the phoenix Patronus. "All Order members are being called in. Come at once. Be prepared."

Hermione blinked as the bird dissipated in a burst of silver stars, glitter falling to the bed and floor but not leaving behind any remnants. She turned slowly to James, who seemed more awake now, despite the heavy scowl he wore. His hair was messier than normal, stuck up in all directions.

"Have you seen my specs?" he asked, a sour note in his voice as he stood, completely unashamed of his state of undress. "I can't see themâ€¦"

Hermione wordlessly summoned them and then banished them at him. James saw the glint of light and caught it like he would catch his snitch. Once the glasses were on, Hermione saw that his eyes were bleary and bloodshot. They were both still hungover.

James roughly scrubbed at his face. "Fuck. Voldemort attacking now? Couldn't he have waited for the weekend?"

Hermione snorted, curling up and bringing the bedsheet over her head. "It's Halloween. He's making a scene because he's a drama queen."

James snickered, although it was a sleepy sound. There was a noise as he yanked on clothes, trying to wake up. "Real inconsiderate of him but sounds right. Can I call him that to his face?"

"Mmhmmâ€¦ but be prepared to not come home if that's the case," hummed Hermione, nestling further into the cozy warmth of the bed. "Or call him 'Tom.' He'll hate that."

James paused, but Hermione could not see the startled expression on his face, being no more than a lump in the middle of their bed. Instead, he smoothed down his shirt and reached for a leather jacket, eschewing his robes for maneuverability.

Fondly, he reached for the lump, poking at it until he found her foot and yanked her down the bed some. Hermione sputtered, throwing the covers off her head to glare at him, her curls going in all directions and looking far worse than his bedhead did at the moment.

James grinned. He leaned down and gave her a light kiss on the temple, and then another peck on her lips. "Don't wait up. I'll be fine."

He let his hand linger as he drew back; Hermione reached for him and yanked him down for a very wet and messy kiss. "Don't die," she muttered, eyes half-closed and crusted with sleep. "I'll be wroth if you do."

"I'll do my best," snickered James, and then left their room. She barely heard the pop of his disapparation from the receiving room; instead, she brought the covers up and rolled onto her back. Blinking, she stared at the ceiling and drummed her fingers on top of the bedsheets.

She was awake, now.

With a huff, she threw the covers back and dressed, muttering under her breath as she went to the kitchen to start the kettle. Tea would help. Tea would get her mind off the idea of James going to fight with Dumbledore's order. Where did the Patronus say they were again? She frowned, the name coming to her. The Rolling Stones. Had there been a skirmish in her time there? She could barely remember.

Hermione waited for the water to boil in the kettle, absently seating herself at the table in the kitchen. She went through the routine of pouring the boiled water into a teapot, adding the loose leaves into a bag and then putting the bag into the pot, and then letting the tea steep before pouring.

She didn't drink, though; she cupped her hands around the warm mug and stared out of the kitchen sink window, into the darkness. When she next blinked or became aware, the soft light of dawn was creeping across the floorboards and her tea was cold.

With a frown, Hermione cast a warming charm on her tea, and the teapot, and glanced at the kitchen clock. James had been gone for four hours.

Without realizing it, she continued the pattern, cupping her hands around the mug and staring out the window with absent glances at the clock, watching the minutes and hours tick on, and on, and onâ€¦

It was nearly eleven when she felt the wards around the townhouse shift. She rose to her feet, turning to face the hallway. James staggered through into the kitchen, blinking at her in her pajamas and the mug on the table.

He was dirty, covered in sweat and grime. His robes â€“ the dragonhide ones she got for him not so long ago â€“ were singed in a few places and had deep gouge marks, but he wasn't holding himself gingerly or could have been too badly hurt. There was the starting of a bruise by his chin, swelling his bottom lip â€“ but otherwise, he was alive, and home, and that was all Hermione cared about.

Hermione threw herself at him, her arms around his neck before she realized what she had done.

James laughed but staggered back on his heels. His voice was hoarse when he chided, "Oof! Well, I missed you, too, loveâ€¦"

Hermione pulled back enough to kiss him soundly. "You're safe. You're fine."

"I am," he replied, face soft. "So are the others, your sister, too."

Hermione sighed in relief, eyes sliding over his bruised chin. "I have some dittany and bruise paste for that if you'd like."

"Yeah, I'd appreciate that." James closed his eyes. "Moody wants me to still come to my evening shift."

"Bastard," muttered Hermione, turning. She grabbed James's hand and pulled him to her chair, pushing him into it. He gratefully sank into the chair with a soft moan of delight, even as Hermione bustled around the cabinets for the pastes.

As she did so, James peeled out of his dragonhide jacket, gingerly. He hissed as it pulled at a few open cuts on his arms â€“ the longest on his left arm, along his wand holster, like someone had tried to slice it from him.

"That doesn't look so good," muttered Hermione with a frown.

James grinned. "You should see the other guy."

She raised her eyebrows in response but sank to her knees next to him with the bruise paste on the floor. Using a clean towel, she dipped a corner of the towel into it and then began to gently dab and apply the paste onto James's chin.

He sighed as the paste began to absorb into his skin and the swelling went down a bit. He slid down the seat a bit, completely relaxed, and a glance at his face showed that James had his eyes closed and his mouth was the tiniest bit slack. Hermione smiled and went back to work, examining his chin and his swollen lower lip.

Once the area was coated with a shiny residue, Hermione turned to his arm, turning it over gently to better access the cut.

"Tergeo," she murmured, directing her wand along his arm and siphoning the blood and dirt off of him, directing the blob to the sink. Once the area was clean. she used the other end of the towel to avoid double-dipping and began to gently dab at the largest parts of the cut.

James hissed as Hermione dabbed the dittany on his open wounds along his arm but didn't pull away. He seemed boneless, slumped in his seat with his hazel eyes unfocused but staring unerringly at her hands as she worked.

"We could have used you."

Hermione froze but did not startle at the sound of his voice. She did not look up at James â€“ she didn't want to see the accusation in his eyes â€“ and instead stilled her hands, resting on his warm arm, staring at the bits of red on the towel.

Finally, she said, quietly, "It wasn't my fight."

James huffed, indignant. "Wasn't your fightâ€”"

"YouÂ knowÂ why I couldn't be there," she interrupted quietly, changing a glance up at him. He looked tired, blackish marks appearing under his eyes from a lack of poor sleep and the remnants of his hangover. His mouth was pulled down in a frown, and there were the faintest lines around it.

He's only twenty, thought Hermione, hysterically. Far too young for stress lines; far too young to be dead in two years.

"But you'reâ€¦ your abilities, your strength," muttered James, a bit desperate as his eyes darted around her face, frantic. "The report from Malfoy Manor â€“ the spells you cast â€“ how youÂ survivedâ€”"

"I know," soothed Hermione, brow furrowed. She bit her lip and settled back on her heels, a bit away from James, but still close. She peered up at him. "But you're playing the 'what if' game, James. What if I had been there? What if I used my transmutation skills? What if Voldemort focused on me?"

James shuddered at the thought. It was bad enough that he and Lily had teamed up to fight Voldemort directly, sloppy with their combined hangovers since Lily had been at their townhouse hours earlier for their party. They had barely managed to hold him off, but not before he had completed a ritual and killed a dozen Muggles.

If Hermione had been thenâ€¦ would Voldemort have been playing with them? Or would he have gone straight for her, knowing what she was capable of? Knowing what damage, she and Regulus and Crouch had caused the last time they went up against him?

"I'm doing my part," continued Hermione, softly. "Just like you are. I'm still fighting him, James. It's just looking a bit different than what you do."

James leaned back in his chair, tilting his head back as he exhaled. Peering at her through slitted eyes even as his glasses slid down his nose, James murmured, "When are you gonna tell me what you're doing?"

Hermione's shoulders slumped. "It's hard to explain." She paused. "It's hard to believe."

James placed his free hand over hers, still pressing the towel into his cuts, already healing under her dittany. "I'll believe you. You must know that â€“ I'll believe whatever you tell me."

She huffed out her own laugh, under her breath. "I'm no Gryffindor, James. I'm working up my courage to tell you."

James' head came down. His eyes were wide. "But soon?"

"Soon," she nodded.

December 1979

Hermione wobbled the tiniest amount as she and James Apparated into Cokeworth by the abandoned quarry a few minutes from her parents' house. Immediately, James was at her side, hovering, concerned. "Are you alright?"

"I'm fine," replied Hermione, closing her eyes, and inhaling as she tried to banish nausea. She peeked one eye open and saw James's frown. "Well, I will be."

"We can make our excusesâ€¦"

"No!" cried Hermione, turning to James. "I promised Tuney we'd be there! Moral support!"

James rolled his eyes, muttering, "Moral support, my arseâ€¦"

They waited a few moments longer and then began walking into the small, dingy town, with Hermione telling James a bit more of her childhood and what it was like growing up the youngest of three girls â€“ and precocious at that.

As they passed a tiny park, she said, "And this is where Snape broke a branch on that willow tree and it nearly beaned Tuney in the head. She screamed and wasÂ notÂ happy with Lily for remaining friends with him after that. It was definitely worse after the letter Dumbledore wroteâ€¦"

"Dumbledore wrote a letter?" asked James curiously, swinging their joined hands between them as they turned away from the park and to the side streets that led to the Evans rowhouse.

Hermione nodded. "Petunia wasâ€¦ jealous that we had magic and she didn't. She wrote to the Headmaster, begging to attend. He did write aâ€¦ nice letter back in response, but Lily and Snape found it when they were snooping in her room. He made fun of her, and thatâ€¦ that was just about it between Lily and Petunia. They still haven't really recovered."

"Blimey," sighed James. "Makes me glad I'm an only child â€“ but let's be honest: Sirius is my brother but other thanâ€¦" he trailed off and glanced at Hermione, clearing his throat. "We've never been that bad."

Hermione hummed her agreement, turning onto her old childhood street. She waved to one neighbour she knew but didn't stop until they were outside her parents' house, the last one on the street before the empty field at the edge of town. There was the barest hint of snow dusting the ground, but she knew that would be gone by the next day, replaced by rain.

"Should we knock?" asked James.

Hermione shook her head and opened the door, shouting, "Mum! Dad! It's us!"

Petunia reached them first, barrelling toward them down the narrow hallway from the kitchen at the back of the rowhouse. She flung her arms around Hermione so hard that she stumbled back a step.

When Petunia released her, she was beaming, and her eyes were wet. Hermione rolled her eyes. "You're not going to be able to keep this secret until dinner if you continue to act like this."
"Aren't youÂ excited?" gushed Petunia, reaching out to squeeze Hermione again. Her eyes darted off to the side. "Oh, hello, James."

Amused at being forgotten, James hid a smile, even as he hung his coat up on the rack by the door. He reached for Hermione's as he replied, "Hullo, Petunia. Where's Sean?"

"Living room."

James nodded, pressing a kiss to Hermione's cheek as he took her coat, hung it up, and then disappeared through the partially closed door to their left, entering the living room to warm greetings from Sean and his father-in-law. It sounded like there were a few more people in there, too, prompting Hermione to turn to Petunia with a quirked eyebrow.

"Uncle Duncan and gran and grandad," she answered, taking Hermione by the arm, and pulling her down the hall to the kitchen. "C'mon, we're almost done and with you here to help â€“ well, it'll go faster, and then we can eat faster, and then we can share our news."

Hermione rolled her eyes but allowed herself to be tugged along. In the kitchen, her mother was darting between checking a sauce on the cooktop and the roast in the over, despite a timer counting down for her.

"Hi mum," said Hermione.

"Oh, Hermione, love," greeted Rose as she turned, hugging her daughter. "It's so lovely to see you. Now we're just waiting on Lily â€“ I hope she'll be here, soon."

"I'm sure she will," soothed Hermione. "Apparation makes it easy to be fashionably late when you instantly pop from place to place."

"It sure is convenient," sighed Rose, turning back to the food.

"Can I help?" asked Hermione, bringing her wand out.

Curious, Rose nodded, and Hermione gave a few jabs and swishes toward the pots and stirring rod, and then toward the countertops covered with dirty mixing bowls, cutting boards, and cutlery. Immediately, the bowls moved to the sink where the tap turned on by itself and the water was immediately boiling hot â€“ dish soap was added â€“ the scrubber submerged and began scrubbing the dirty dishes, that once clean, floated toward a hovering dishtowel. The towel wiped the bowl down and then floated it to the correct cupboard, all to Rose's amazement.

Petunia looked smug from where she stood by the doorway. "See? Didn't I tell you, mum?"

"Well, we are certainly going to be ready for lunch earlier than I expected." Rose turned from gapping at the magic in her kitchen to fretting as she turned toward her daughters. "I do hope Lily will be on time, now."

With final checks and preparation to be made â€“ with Hermione placing warming charms on dishes so they remained warm and fresh as they were set on the table â€“ the entire family migrated to the dining area off the kitchen, loudly appearing in clumps and groups as people carried on conversations. Lily snuck in as people were seating themselves, a bit pale in the face with her straight red hair down and hanging a bit lanky. Despite being dressed nicely in a fashionable frock, Petunia and Hermione shared a concerned look.

Bowls and plates were passed around as the meal began, Leonard and their grandfather Humphrey at the two heads, carrying on a conversation across the entire length of the table with Sean and Duncan debating the validity of a recent horse race (with James watching in amusement); Rose and their grandmother Marie were casting concerned looks at Lily, but saying nothing as Marie asked Petunia about her career and if she had written anything that was published anywhere.

Petunia and Hermione sat side-by-side, with their husbands next to them, taking up one entire side of the table; across from them, in bracketed by their grandmother and mother, sat their uncle Duncan and Lily, whose face grew paler and paler as the conversation and meal continued.

Eventually during a lull in conversation about halfway through the meal, while everyone was moving toward full stomachs and picking at the food on their plates, Rose turned toward her eldest and youngest daughters, and asked, "So, Pet, what was the big news you wanted to share with everyone?"

Under the table, Petunia's hand reached out and clutched at Hermione's, tightly squeezing even as she turned to Sean and they shared a smile. She turned back to Rose. "Well, mum, dad, it's actually something Hermione and I want to shareâ€”"

Across the table, Lily swallowed a burp, her chest heaving as she went bone white.

Petunia paused.

Everyone's attention shifted to Lily as she heaved again. Her eyes went wide, and she frantically scanned the table, reaching for the nearly empty serving bowl of collard greens. She yanked the bowl toward her. Her face went green, and she vomited into the bowl.

Beside her, their uncle Duncan began laughing, even as he fished out a handkerchief and passed it to his niece. Rose turned to Lily, crying, "Lily! Lily, darling, are you not well?" while Leonard blinked in shock, and then heavily buried his face in his hands, resting his elbows on the table.

Using Duncan's handkerchief to wipe away some vomit lingering around her mouth, Lily, pale-faced but no longer green, and sweating just the tiniest bit, looked up at everyone staring at her and morosely announced, "I'm pregnant."

There was a moment of silence. Then:

"What do youÂ mean, pregnant, Lily, you're notÂ married?"

"Pregnant! Lily!"

"Are you bloodyÂ kiddingÂ me?"

"How long have you known, Lily?"

Hermione sat, her hand still tightly gripping Petunia's, although at this point it was more to keep her sister in her seat from lunging across the table and stabbing Lily with the fork that was in her other hand. Sean must have seen the murderous look and the fork because he quickly did a doubletake and then pried it from Petunia's grip, setting it down on his far side.

Beside her, James had his mouth open in shock, but under his breath, he muttered, "Mischief managed."

Hermione immediately turned to him with a glare. Sheepishly, he turned his gaze back to his plate, although he was hiding a smile.

Across from them, Lily was silently crying, sniffling as Rose wrapped an arm around her. "I justÂ happened, mum, I didn't plan for it! Honest!" she gave their grandparents a bit of a stink-eye when she muttered, "And this is the nineteen-seventies, gran! It's nearly another decade, I can have a kid without being marriedâ€¦"

"My God, Lily, what will the neighbours think? Is this the influence of that â€“ that â€“Â that schoolÂ on you?" their grandmother cried, hand fluttering around her chest. "Oh, my heart. My poor heart."

"Oh, mum, stop it, you're being so dramatic," muttered Leonard, although the words were a bit garbled coming through his hands.

Marie sniffed. "Well, she'sÂ yourÂ daughter, Leonard â€“ have a bit more respect for the situation she found herself in and the damage it will causeâ€”"

"So, girls," Rose tried to inject some cheerful levity in her voice as it loudly carried over the table, even as she turned to Petunia and Hermione, "Pet, what was it you wanted to say?"

Petunia took a few moments to compose herself, although her chest was heaving and her nostrils flared in anger as she cut a nasty look toward Lily, who slouched in her seat. She let go of her tight hold on Hermione's hand but kept her icy glare on Lily when she said, her voice hard, "Sean and I are expecting."

"Expecting what?" asked Duncan.

Rose gasped, her eyes wide. "You're pregnant, too?!"

Leonard groaned.

Rose's eyes drifted from Petunia to Hermione. James smugly placed his arm around the back of her chair, his goofy, lopsided grin coming out as he announced, "Us, too! I'm going to be a dad!"

Stunned, Rose looked around the table at her three daughters, and stuttered out, "You're all pregnant? At the same timeâ€¦?"

James blushed, his ear tips going red when he muttered, "I'm pretty sure it was the Halloween party we had at oursâ€¦ IÂ knewÂ Sirius did something with the punchâ€¦"

"This wasn'tÂ quiteÂ how I wanted to announce it," bit out Petunia, eyes still lingering on Lily before she addressed the rest of the table. "Hermione and I found out together and we wanted to share it together, too."

"Oh, but that's just darling," gasped Marie, the lines on her face deepening as she smiled. "Three great-grandchildren all at once! Oh, Petunia, sweetheart, when are you due? Hermione, love?"

There was a lingering smell of vomit at the table now, mixing in with what remained of the potatoes and meat. It was highly unpleasant, and Hermione's nose twitched against the smell, and she wasn't sure if it was the question or the smell that made her stomach turn when she answered in a small voice, "July. We're all due in July."

Petunia's glare immediately turned to concern as she turned to Hermione.

"Well," boomed Humphrey, speaking for the first time since Lily threw up, "Congratulations are in order, then. Duncan, do you still have those cigarsâ€¦? Perhaps us men should celebrate the fathersâ€”"

"Oh, but what about Lily?" fussed Rose, turning back to her. "Are you seeing someone, Lily? Who's the father?"

"Yes, Lily," added Petunia, voice hard. "Who's the father?"

Lily blushed almost as red as her hair.

A horrifying thought crept across Hermione's mind and she immediately blurted, "GoodÂ God, please tell me it's not Snape."

At her side, James choked on the drink he just took.

"Snape?" echoed Leonard, "You don't mean that skinny boy from Spinner's End, do you?"

Coughing, James put down his glass and managed to say, "Just â€“ just to say â€“ but Snape is a person of interest in Hermione's kidnapping, so,Â pleaseÂ tell me you haven't seen himâ€”"

"It's not Severus!" burst out Lily, crossing her arms. "Merlin â€“ it's not anyone's business! We're not even dating! It was one time!" She blushed. "Okay, maybe more than one timeâ€¦"

"I didn't need to hear that," groaned Leonard.

"Um, Lily, dearâ€¦" Rose looked around the table and her eyes caught on the bowl of vomit. Her nose wrinkled. "Let'sâ€¦ let's clear the table and take this to the kitchen, girlsâ€¦"

"I've got it," offered Hermione, bringing out her wand.

Marie gave a sniff, but Humphrey took that as a signal and stood, Leonard quickly following him, hauling James to his feet. "To the back garden, men."

Startled, James shot Hermione a glance, but Sean was behind him, ushering him forward, and they, along with Humphrey and Duncan, quickly vacated the dining area and went through the backdoor into the back garden, leaving Hermione space to magic the dishes away to the kitchen.

As Marie and Rose turned to Lily to interrogate her, with Petunia adding her own acerbic opinions, Hermione sat back, lost in thought.

WasÂ thisÂ what Harry had meant, back in the Room of Requirements? That he was always going to be born and that Lily was still going to be his mum?

What did itÂ meanÂ that she, Petunia, and Lily were all pregnant at the same time (also: she was going to hunt down Sirius and find out what he put in the punch, and whether any of the other couples were expectingâ€¦)?

Knowing that her due date was July 1980 was worrisome enough, but with three Evans sisters all expecting, plus the way things were lining up for her, had a frisson of fear settle in Hermione's stomach. She may have destroyed almost all Voldemort's Horcruxes, but she also had (theoretically) two of the Deathly Hallows. The Room's construct of Harry had spoken to her with a weight that sounded like a prophecy. Between her and James, they had defied Voldemort a few times.

Things were going too well â€“ the scales were going to tip soon, and Hermione wasn't sure just how things would shake out when they did.

{TBCâ€¦}

Chapter End Notes

Lisichka: little fox (Russian), or so say websites for pet names in Russian

Â 

EDIT: Nope, means "fungi" which is ridiculously hilarious to me. Anyway, thanks to daisy_om who corrected me that "little fox" should be lisonok, which I have now replaced accordingly. Thanks!

Aug 2021 Edit: Ummm... people seem to think that Sirius drugged like, everyone at the party. So. Just as an FYI and clarification: he did not. Sirius spiked the drink with a disgusting mix of alcohol and got everyone so drunk that birth control methods did not work. That is all.

Who You Are Tomorrow

Chapter Notes

Aug 2021 Edit: Ummm... people seem to think that Sirius drugged like, everyone at the party. So. Just as an FYI and clarification: he did not. Sirius spiked the drink with a disgusting mix of alcohol and got everyone so drunk that birth control methods did not work. That is all.

Thank you to the AMAZING cptnvers who sent this to me on Tumblr! The Evans sisters! ğŸ˜ğŸ˜ğŸ˜

Yesterday is Tomorrow (Everything is Connected)

TWENTY-FOUR

Whoever you are today is not who you have to be tomorrow.

â€“ Dr. Cassandra Railly,Â 12 MonkeysÂ (TV show)

December 1979

The air smelled like the cigars James, Sean, her uncle, father, and grandfather had smoked in the backyard after dinner, the sharp scent lingering around the door and patio set where the men had either stood or sat.

Hermione found Petunia glowering in the darkness; thin arms wrapped around her chest. She was sitting on the tiny stoop step between the house and patio stones, an air of malice hanging around her.

"You okay?"

Petunia didn't twitch her head in recognition of Hermione's voice, but she did sigh, the exhale leaving her body making her slump further until her chin was pressed against her knees, tucked tight around her. Hermione took that as a sign of invitation, but gave Petunia her space, opting to sit at the patio set instead. At that angle, she was able to look directly at her sister and back into the house.

"It as supposed to beÂ ourÂ moment," muttered Petunia, a pinched look to her.

"I don't think it was planned, Tuney," said Hermione carefully. "She threw up. It wasn't like she could control that."

"She could've used magic," replied Petunia mulishly.

"It doesn't work likeâ€”" Hermione snapped her mouth shut. Okay, so puking pasties weren'tÂ yetÂ invented by the Weasley twins, but there was no guarantee that someone else hadn't made a treat or candy that could mimic that in the 1970s. Although Hermione was certain Lily was not the type to go around creating prank products.

Petunia sighed, resting her chin on her knees as she turned to face Hermione. "Aren't you upset?"

"I think I'm more upset thatÂ you'reÂ upset," answered Hermione. "I'm fine with coasting along. I could've waited to tell mum and dad."

Petunia looked at Hermione, then, and opened her mouth â€“

"Can I join orâ€¦ or is this a 'you two' thing?"

Hermione glanced up from Petunia at Lily, who hovered in the doorframe, the backdoor partially open and one foot on the patio stone and one still instead. Petunia twisted around to stare at Lily, a heavy glare forming on her face.

Reaching out, Hermione nudged Petunia's legs with her toe.

Petunia turned back to her youngest sister, glowering, but said nothing. Hermione took that as an implicit "okay," and smiled at Lily. "Come join us."

Hesitantly, and still looking a bit peaky, Lily slipped through the door and hovered closer to the house, leaning against the side of it.

The three were silent, with Hermione glancing between Lily and Petunia often, a tiny frown on her face. Finally, she asked, "So â€“ are we going to talk about it, or what?"

"What's there to say?" muttered Petunia, shooting a glare at Lily.

"What?" their redheaded sister sputtered. "What did I do now?"

"What did you do?" echoed Petunia, shrilly. "I had this â€“ this entire plan â€“ and you just, you just-!" she mimicking gagging.

"Oh,Â so sorryÂ that I disrupted Perfect Petunia's grand plan!" snapped Lily in retaliation. "BecauseÂ everythingÂ must be exactly as Petunia says, doesn't it? That's how it's been our entire lives: Petunia says 'jump' and I don't have the chance to say 'no'; it's all 'how high?'"

Affronted, Petunia gasped and reared back. "How dare youâ€”"

"How dare you!" shouted back Lily. "Nothing was ever good enough for you after I got my Hogwarts letter. Just because of it, being different from you, you thought me a freak!"

Their father stuck his head out of the backdoor, warily looking between his three daughters. "Everything alright, girls?"

"It's fine dad," said Hermione, trying to make a smile appear on her face. "Just Tuney and Lily hashing out some old hurts. I'll put up a privacy spell so no one can hear them shout."

Leo looked a bit concerned but nodded. "Alright, sweetheart."

Once he was gone, Hermione sent a sharp glare at both her sisters. "I'm fine with us discussing this and getting it done and over with, but let's be a bit more careful with the accusations in a Muggle neighbour, shall we?"

Petunia sniffed and Lily grumbled, but they agreed, and Hermione hastily threw up a modified ward based off Snape'sÂ muffilato, which Lily seemed to find impressive, given the look she sent her little sister.

"You're such a hypocritical bitch, Tuney," muttered Lily. "You scorn me for being this freak with magic, but you're all buddy-buddy with 'Mioneâ€”"

"To be fair," began Hermione quietly, "She did ignore me for years, tooâ€¦"

"That's not the point!" shouted Lily, hands coming up to grab at her hair. She let out a tiny scream of frustration. "Tuney had this grand plan, this idea of how we would be together and if anything, or anyone, god forbid, causes her ten-year plan to derail, she's a bloody nightmare!"

"I doÂ notÂ have a ten-year plan!" Petunia stared hard at Lily.

"Really?" asked Hermione, eyebrows up in disbelief. "So, you haven't already planned your future kid's next few years, including already which nursery they'll attend?"

Petunia flushed a heavy red.

"I just don't get it," whispered Lily, eyes red-rimmed as she looked at the garden stones. "What did I do that made you both hate me so much?"

"I don't hate you!" retorted Hermione in shock.

"Nor do I," replied Petunia, brows furrowed in confusion.

Lily stared balefully at them. "But youâ€¦ you both spend your time together, do everything together. I never get invited, I'm always last to find things outâ€¦ it can't be magic, because you're fine with it around Hermioneâ€¦ what is it?"

"Have you looked in the mirror?" muttered Petunia, causing Hermione to elbow her in the side. "Oww!"

Stricken, Lily's eyes looked between the two. "Truly?Â I'mÂ the problem?"

Hermione sighed. "It'sâ€¦ it's not that simple, Lily. Both Petunia and I have issues as well, so it's not all on you."

"It's mostly on you," interjected Petunia. At Hermione's glare, she shrugged. "What? It's true. As kids, she got away with everything. She was our parents' darling. Perfect Lily, the one we should both emulate. And then when she got her magic, she had that Snape boy violate my privacy â€“ magic was always something bad for me then."

"I said sorry for that!" protested Lily, scowling. "And that's not fair, Petunia. You're still punishing me for something I did as a child!"

"Oh, well. Let's talk about when we grew up." Petunia sniffed haughtily. "You'd invite that boy over for Sunday dinner and he'd put frog spawn in my pockets or call me names and you never said anything! You pickedÂ himÂ over your own family! You laughed when I found the frog slime in my pockets â€“ I saved upÂ monthsÂ for the notes to be able to afford it!"

Lily was aghast. "I didn'tâ€”I didn't thinkâ€”"

"That's kind of the problem," said Hermione quietly. "You thought a lot revolved around you, Lily. You didn't think about Tuney's feelings."

"I didn't know she saved up for it!" protested Lily. "That's not fair!"

"You neverÂ asked, did you?" sniffed Petunia. "You were never around anyway during the summer â€“ always going off with that Snape boyâ€”"

Lily moaned. "Why do you dislike him so muchâ€”"

"Everything he did was either to get or keep your attention, or keep your attention off others," continued Hermione calmly. "Think of his rivalry with James and his friends â€“ and, and, despite falling into a crowd that would become Death Eaters, he still thought to maintain a friendship with you, calling everyone else mudbloods."

"What's a mudblood?" asked Petunia curiously, looking between the two, her long blonde hair swinging as her head moved.

"Dirty slang for impure and not worthy of magic," answered Lily quietly.

"It was a double-standard. Friends with you but you were the mudblood exceptionâ€”"

Lily rolled her eyes. "Oh, come off it â€“ like you and Black didn't have the same thingâ€”"

"RegÂ neverÂ called me a mudblood," replied Hermione firmly. "Ever."

The sisters fell silent, each eyeing one another carefully. Finally, Hermione sighed, slumping her shoulders. "Look, every time I tried to invite you to do something, particularly after Petunia and I made up, you didn't want to meet us. So, I stopped inviting you and it was just me and Tuney who met up or spent time together. That's why we're closer."

Pained, Lily murmured, "I'm sorry."

Hermione shrugged. "It happens."

"You were mean and cruel about Hogwarts," said Petunia, a hard glint in her eyes. "I wanted to beÂ withÂ you. I wanted to keep us all together, and then you had to make fun of me. By making fun of the letter I sent Headmaster Dumbledore, you made fun of the fact that I loved you so much I wanted to go to the same school even though IÂ couldn't."

Lily grimaced. "That wasn't â€“ that wasn't what I meant or thought ofâ€”"

"But it was what Snape thought," sighed Hermione. "'Ooh, look, the stupid muggle with no magic wants to pretend to be a witch! What a riot!'"

"He was a bad influence on you," muttered Petunia stiffly.

Lily glanced between her two sisters. "Did neither of you think about how it felt being me? The first with magic in the family, and there I was, prime to take Petunia's role for you, Hermione. To show you everything that I loved about the world â€“ but you weren't interested."

Petunia turned away quickly so that Lily couldn't see the face she was making.

Hermione shrugged. "I wanted to do my own thing. I always have. Why would Hogwarts change that?"

"You could have told me," scowled Lily.

"Oh, please," groaned Hermione, "You were so enthused about the idea, constantly telling me how much I would love Gryffindor. You kept pushing on me whatÂ youÂ were interested in and whatÂ youÂ loved instead of thinking about me."

"And back to Lily thinking only of herself," muttered Petunia.

"I don't think of myself!" Lily stamped her foot in frustration. "I have friends â€“ I'd do anything for them â€“ and I'm outgoing, all the teachers at HogwartsÂ lovedÂ me â€“"

"You would do whatever you could to make mum and daddy love you," spat Petunia, just as Hermione said, "Yeah, no, you were a teacher's pet, Lily, of course, they were going to love youâ€”"

"I got up in trouble, too," she muttered mulishly, pouting at her older and younger sister equally, crossing her arms. "I'm not perfectâ€”"

"You justÂ pretendÂ you are and it's kind of aggravating," said Hermione slowly and carefully. "No one is. Goodness knows I am very aware of my faults, and Tuney's. You just pretend to not have any and then impose on the rest of us these lofty, impractical expectations."

"I thought expectations were Petunia's thing."

Hermione stifled a snort. "You both do that."

Petunia rolled her eyes, fighting against a smile and Lily left a few giggles out. It diffused the tension between them.

"I can't forget what you did," said Petunia slowly, "But I can forgive it going forward so long as you don't do the same mistakes."

Lily shyly looked at Petunia from under her lashes. "You'll tell me if I'm repeating bad habits?"

Petunia sniffed. "Of course."

"Truce?" Lily held out a hand toward Petunia. Hermione's breath caught and she held it in as she watched with wide eyes.

Petunia eyed the hand and stood from the patio steps. For one moment, Hermione thought that she would not take Lily's extended offer when she knocked Lily's hand away. Lily gasped, but then Petunia was leaning in and hugging Lily, eyes closed.

"You'll always be my sister, even when you're annoying me," Petunia murmured. "Even if you annoy me forÂ yearsÂ on end."

Lily gave a wet laugh, hugging Petunia back tightly, her fingers digging into Petunia's bony shoulders. "I'm sorry â€“ I wish we hadn't drifted so far apart that it came to this â€“ that I didn't seeâ€”"

Petunia scoffed, drawing back a bit. "I'm sorry I let my pride get the best of me. I am the oldest â€“ I should have spoken to you about my feelings."

The two sisters smiled wobbly at one another, and Hermione sniffed, blinking rapidly to hide her own tears of happiness. Petunia and Lily turned to her, Lily laughing as she held a free arm out invitingly. "C'mon, 'Mione, it's your turn too! Join in the hug!"

Hermione did not need a further invitation and stepped forward, breathing in the scent of her two sisters as their hair mingled red, brown, and blonde when their foreheads touched: Petunia and Hermione cheek to cheek and Lily's forehead resting against their chins.

They remained like that for some time, basking in the feel of each other's arms. Hermione knew she was hopeful that Lily and Petunia would mend their rift; they hadn't in the previous timeline, and it badly showed in how Harry had been treated. If the worst were to happenâ€”

No,Â she thought,Â I won't think that way. Not right now. Not when we're like this.

After a few more moments, petunia drew back, rubbing at her arms. "I think I'm going to go inside now and tell Sean I'm ready to go to his parent's."

Lily and Hermione both made affirming noises, and Petunia bid them goodnight, leaving the two witches standing on the patio stones in the cool evening air, no longer smelling of cigars. After a moment of watching Petunia inside the kitchen disappear through the door and down the hallway, Hermione turned to Lily with a questioning brow raised.

"What?" asked Lily.

"Really, though, it's not Snape, is it?" asked Hermione with a slightly green hue to her face.

"GreatÂ Merlin, Hermione!" Lily cried, glaring at her. "Why does everyone think it's Severus?"

Hermione rolled her eyes. "Gosh, I wonder why."

Lily scowled. She turned away to stare at the muddy field next to their house, stewing in her anger until eventually, she sighed, and her shoulders slumped. "I had hopedâ€¦"

"Hoped?"

"That afterâ€¦ when we made up in the library," continued Lily quietly, lost in her memories. "We, well, after graduation we kept up a correspondence and even saw each other a few times. Butâ€”"

Hermione made a noise of interest.

"But after you were attacked at Malfoy Manorâ€¦" Lily shook her head, tears in her eyes when she turned to Hermione. "How could I justify his actions? I had spent so many years, so much time and effort into telling everyone I knew that he wasn't all that bad â€“ that Severus wouldÂ neverÂ do those thingsâ€¦ and thenâ€¦ he did. He tried to â€“ to maim my own sister."

Hermione chewed on her bottom lip. Tentatively, she offered, "I do think you're the exception to his rules, Lil."

"I shouldn't be." She shook her head, eyes sad and downcast. "The things he's done, and what he's yet to do in the service of a mad manâ€¦" She turned to Hermione. "He had every opportunity to move beyond his hurts and never did."

"Some chips on the shoulder are just too big to ignore, I suppose," offered Hermione quietly.

"That's not the answer," replied Lily, a bit heatedly. "It's never the answer."

The two were quiet for a few minutes, just breathing in the cold December air despite not feeling the cold from their warming charms. Their breaths puffed out before them, and Hermione spent the time with her head tilted back, looking up at the stars.

"You always knew, didn't you?"

Hermione turned to Lily, to find her sister watching her carefully. "Hmm?"

"You avoided certain people, all your life," continued Lily, a tiny frown on her face. "Severus was one of them. Ever since you met him, you disliked him or went out of your way to ignore him. You always knew he was going to be trouble."

"Maybe not trouble," replied Hermione carefully, "But I had a feeling that he wouldn't be the type to change." Hermione gave a tiny laugh. "The power of love can't compel someone to do good things, Lily."

"I thought it might heal him," she sighed.

"Only he could do that," said Hermione, heaving a sigh of her own. She nudged her shoulder into her sister's. "And 'sides, it's not your job to heal him."

Lily fell into silence then, for a little longer, before muttering, "I'm going inside. Are youâ€¦ are you coming?"

"Not yet," answered Hermione quietly. "Soon."

Lily nodded, and stood from the chair, placing a warm hand on Hermione's shoulder, only to draw her in quickly for a hug, despite their sitting and standing positions. Lily's floral scent invading Hermione's nose, and for a brief, shining moment, it was like being six again and her big sister was hugging her, for no other reason than she could and wanted to express her love. Then Lily was gone, and Hermione was left outside.

It wasn't long after Lily returned to the warmth of their parents' home that the backdoor opened again, and a heavier set of feet made their way toward her. James heavily sat in Lily's seat, separated from Hermione by the wrought iron table.

His face was shrouded in the darkness, with the only light coming from the kitchen window behind them and the backdoor, illuminating his unruly black hair and shadowing his eyes. But Hermione knew he was looking at her.

"I think I've always known," he began slowly, carefully, and Hermione turned to look at her husband.

He didn't move to take her hand or move in any way. He was still, like a statue, but there was something hot, knowing, in what she could see of his hazel eyes.

"I think I've always known," he repeated. "That something was justâ€¦ different about you. I never really thought much of it, because at first, you were just the incredibly intelligent, rude, younger girl who was tutoring me in Arithmancy. But you'd say something or have this look in your eyes â€“ and I would think to myself,Â she knows more than what she's saying."

Hermione tilted her chin down in a single, acknowledging nod.

Triumph lit in James' eyes and he rushed to continue. "But you weren't a politically minded Slytherin, so that was weird. You weren't scheming, like mum. And then we'd talk more, and we'd do more, and I got to know you better and it didn't matter that you wereâ€¦ different. Then, we were dating andâ€¦ I found myself falling in love with you."

He laughed, finally moving as he brought a hand up to cover his mouth. "Actually, it wasn't so much as falling as utterly tripping, given how I made a fool of myself."

"You were hardly a fool," Hermione lightly admonished.

"It felt like it," he replied shaking his head. "And when I would think I had you all figured out, and then I would see you using magic like I've never in the Room of Requirements, or when you out-duelled Voldemort's supporters. Or how you justâ€¦ knew things about other people."

Hermione pressed her lips together, refusing to speak.

James turned his body to face Hermione's. "I thinkâ€¦ after Crouch and Reg's reaction to the Godric's Hollow house, and then your reaction to the Headmaster's offer, I thinkâ€¦ I think I knew. I just didn't want to admit it, becauseâ€¦ well, even with magic, it'sâ€¦ farfetched." He gave a tiny laugh.

Hermione swallowed a lump in her throat, and she hoarsely asked, "What do you know?"

"You're a seer," said James carefully, eyes tracing Hermione's features, "But given how much you hate divination, that can't be it. So, if a seer is out, the only way you'd have all the knowledge and experience you do is if you're already done all this before, Hermione."

Hearing the truth from James's lips was like a sledgehammer in Hermione's chest. She closed her eyes, pained, and wondered if this was the moment, she'd lose her husband, lose the solid rock he'd become over the years, the foundation of which she based her hopes on that she could fix things, that if she could changeÂ just one more thing, that she wouldn't see her sister lying dead at the base of a cradle, that James wouldn't be gone from the world.

She cleared her throat, opened her eyes, and spoke the truth. "Yes."

James froze. "Yesâ€¦?"

"I'veâ€¦ I've done this before, butâ€¦ not how you're thinking," she admitted quietly.

James exhaled, loudly, leaning back in the chair. He blinked and ran a hand through his hair. "I â€“ wow â€“ I'dâ€¦ I never thought you'd actuallyâ€¦Â admitÂ it."

Hermione sent him a scathing look, and at it, he blanched.

"I thought I was going a bit mad, thinking it, to be honest," he said, with a tiny cringe. "So, uh, thanks for clearing that up."

They sat in silence for a bit.

"Will youâ€¦ will you tell me about it?" James quietly asked, eyes boring into her.

"It's not a happy story," Hermione repeated the words she used for Regulus and Barty, for Petunia and Sean.

"It's your story," replied James firmly, reaching out and taking Hermione's hand. "That's good enough for me. Andâ€¦ I want to understand."

Hermione blinked rapidly, trying to ignore the tears forming, and sniffed. "Alrightâ€¦"

Like with her sister, with her best friends, Hermione began retelling her life as Hermione Granger, growing up in the 1980s and her two best friends, Harry Potter and Ron Weasleyâ€¦

By the time she finished, James had wordlessly renewed their warming charms twice, and the lights in the house behind them had all been turned off but the kitchen, signalling everyone else had gone to bed or left. The stars were still out, and the air was still chilly, but the moon was further across the sky than when she first began, and there was a tired air between them as she finished.

James remained silent the entire time, listening to her recount her experiences, not once asking questions although she could see them burning in his eyes. Whenever she got to a harrowing part about herself or Harry, he'd grip her hand tightly or grind his teeth, but never spoke.

Finally, he said, "Crouch and Regulus already know, don't they? Andâ€¦ Petunia?"

"Yes."

There was a tiny quirk to his lips, a gleam in his eyes. "So, I'm the fourth."

Hermione paused. "Erâ€¦"

James frowned. "Wait, I'mÂ notÂ the fourth to know?"

"Erâ€¦ wellâ€¦ I meanâ€¦" Hermione cleared her throat, eyes darting away from James. "Sean knows because Tuney knows."

There was a scowl on James' face. "So, I'm theÂ fifthÂ to know? Hermione! I'm your husband!"

Hermione winced. "Yeahâ€¦"

James' scowl deepened and he withdrew his hand and pout and cross his arms across his chest, slouching in his seat as he sent her a dirty look.

Backpedalling, Hermione rushed to soothe his ego. "To be fair, Tuney and Sean only knowÂ partsÂ â€“ they don't know everything. And LilyÂ definitelyÂ doesn't know anything. If we're basing it on that, then you're the third."

James stared at her for a bit longer, grumbling under his breath before he spoke. "â€¦ fine. I'll take that."

He stewed for a moment longer, and then turned to her, eyes alight with some smugness. "That's much better than fourth or fifth. Hermione, I don't think I'd have been able to handle it if you told others. EspeciallyÂ SiriusÂ before me! Could you imagine?"

There was something in his eyes that made Hermione's breath catch: something fierce, but curious, but also determined. He looked around the Evans' back garden. "Soâ€¦ do you want to stay here and talk, or can I ask you all the questions I have from the comfort of our bed?"

Relief spread through Hermione's body and she physically slumped in her seat; eyes closed. When she opened them again, they caught James's and his turned molten as he caught her expression.

"Bed. Definitely."

Hand on hers, they both stood from the chairs and with a sharp, loud crack, disapparated to their townhome. They got to James's questionsâ€¦

Eventually.

Petunia met James and Hermione a few days before New Years' outside the Haberdashery in the alley between the two tall buildings. She was clutching her purse when James and Hermione apparated in, a pop signalling their appearance. She inhaled sharply upon seeing them and then sniffed.

"Is this it then?" asked James, a sparkle in his eyes visible from behind his glasses even as he rocked back and forth on his heels in excitement.

"Oh, she finally told you, I see," commented Petunia.

James grinned. "Kept her upÂ all nightÂ answering questions."

Petunia's eyes narrowed between the two. "It's a wonder you only got pregnant now, Hermione."

"Shut up," the curly-haired witch said without heat, turning to the nondescript door. She pressed a hand flat against it and murmured, "Jelly babies and a TARDIS."

"A what?" asked James.

Petunia sniggered. "Really, Hermione?"

Hermione shrugged. The door under her hand glowed a muted golden colour and then faded. There was a click as the door unlocked. "It's not like an enemy of ours is going to know that, will they?"

James pestered Hermione for what she meant â€“ and left Petunia up to explain a television show they watched when still living at home,Â Doctor Who, to him. It left James baffled about the idea of a time and space travelling alien.

Then they were up the stairs and through the second door with another password ("Abracadabra," which made James shudder) and into the large sitting area of Alphard Black's haberdashery workshop. Regulus and Barty were already there, Barty scarfing down take-out and perched on his haunches on a chair while Regulus stood with his hands in his robe pockets before a large, empty space of wall next to the door.

Both turned to greet Hermione and then paused at seeing those with her. Hermione's voice was quiet when she said, "James knows, and Tuney wanted to help."

Barty nodded, taking it in stride.

Regulus eyed them both. "Help how?"

"Well, I brought more information I found on Tom Riddle," began Petunia, reaching into her purse and withdrawing some folded sheets of A4. "I thought we could add it to what I sent previously."

Between her and Regulus â€“ and James, with his transfiguration skills â€“ they began setting up an information board, using sticking charms on sheets of paper and photographs Petunia, as well as Regulus and Barty, had collected regarding Tom Riddle and his Death Eaters. Newspaper clippings on mysterious deaths, transcripts, and handwritten notes about Wizengamot sessions, even James's additions from Auror reports, all began to spread across the wall. Pieces were connected by string and make-shift post-its, with hastily scribbled thoughts. There was an entire section on his horcruxes and the two that were left: the diary and cup.

James had his over robe off, and his shirt sleeves rolled up to his elbows, revealing his hairy arms. He had an ankle resting across the opposite knee in a languid pose. Hermione had trouble drawing her eyes away when he leaned back in his chair and asked, "How are you planning on getting these?"

Regulus sighed. "Well, after the Malfoy Manor fiascoâ€”"

"Is that what we're calling it?" muttered Barty, moving to flop heavily onto the leather couch next to Hermione. He hooked an arm around the back and used it as leverage to turn and face Regulus.

"â€”there's no way we can plan anything around that," finished Regulus with a glare. "So, we should focus on the cup."

"Which isâ€¦" Petunia trailed off, thumbing through her hand-written notes, "In the bank?"

"Gringotts?" said James, incredulously as he leaned forward, both feet hitting the floor. "You're planning on robbingÂ Gringott's?"

"'Rob' is such a dirty word," said Regulus, tilting his nose up the tiniest amount. He buffed his fingers on his robes. "'Liberate' is much better."

James pursed his lips to hide his grin. "Right â€“ so, how do you plan onÂ liberatingÂ the horcrux from Gringott's?" He cut a glance toward his wife, who was frowning in concentration with her fingers steepled and pressed against her mouth and her eyes staring unseeingly on his chest. "Surely you're not planning Polyjuice, two-point-oh."

Petunia slowly turned her head to stare at her sister while Barty chortled next to Hermione. Regulus looked pained. "I'd really rather not see Hermione looking like cousin Bella."

"I thought I did a good impression, at the time," muttered Hermione, blinking as she came out of her stupor. She sighed. "But no â€“ the Polyjuice plan only worked because of the situation at hand, and once we went through Thief's Downfall, it washed away all enchantments, anyway. It was a desperate plan during desperate days."

"We're not quite there yet, either," added Regulus. He eyed her. "But if we do need you, it'll be to take Polyjuice againâ€”"

"Absolutely not!"

Everyone's eyes shot to James, who had jumped to his feet. His eyes were hard on his best mate's little brother. "Polyjuice isÂ notÂ happening!"

"But Hermione has the most experience with itâ€”" protested Regulus again, frowning.

"No!" James was adamant, a scowl now pulling at his mouth. "It's not safe!"

From the corner of his eyes, he saw Barty leaned toward Hermione and mutter, although it was loud enough for everyone to hear, "I thought you said you told him everythingâ€¦?"

Hermione, however, was focused on James, a grim look on her face that made her seem much older.

"But-!" Regulus tried one last time, but this time James slashed a hand down aggressively when he spat to the room at large:

"I'll not endanger my unborn child, Black!"

Immediately, both Regulus and Barty sharply inhaled, turning as one toward Hermione with wide eyes. Barty had drastically paled, eyes skimming Hermione's form and her oversized jumper, peering intently at her midsection like she was about a balloon in size.

Regulus, however, had a tremble to him and his lips when he asked, "Is it true, Hermione? Is Potter speaking true?"

Hermione gave a tiny dip of her chin.

Regulus shakily exhaled, his eyes closing. Then, when they opened, they were molten silver. "This is over, now."

What?Â "What's over?"

"This. It's done."

Hermione stared at Regulus, and he waved a hand around the room and at their information board, where Petunia still stood, a silent witness.

"Excuse me?" Hermione's voice was icy when she moved off the couch to stand.

Regulus stood firm though, meeting her eyes and ire, even as sparks began to climb through her curls. Petunia's mouth dropped open in fascination and surprise.

"You're pregnant, Hermione," said Regulus carefully, but there was a hint of Black arrogance to him, and he sounded eerily like his father. When he threw his shoulders back and tilted his chin up and looked eerily like Orion Black, too. "You can no longer join us on the hunt to destroy these. You have an heir to think of â€“ and you've told Barty and me what we need to know. We'll finish this."

"The hell you will!" Hermione spat. "You wouldn't evenÂ knowÂ of this if it weren't for me!"

"You're pregnant, you shouldn't be near such dark magic!" retorted Regulus sharply.

"I'm not an invalid!"

"You're aÂ liability."

Hermione reeled back, hurt across her face.

"Whoa," interrupted James, physically separating himself between Hermione and Regulus, both of who were breathing heavily with flushed faces. "Calm down, both of you."

He shuffled Hermione back to the couch, and she sat, stiffly. He knelt before his wife and glanced between her and Regulus, often. Regulus moved to the bar in the far corner of the room, well away from them.

"Regulus has a point about the magic, love," said James carefully, catching Hermione's dark eyes as she glared at the youngest Black son. She then transferred that glare to James, but he was immune to it by this point. "But Hermione also has a point that she got you this far, Regulus."

"Compromise?" piped up Barty, inching closer to Hermione's side, eyes darting from her to Regulus and back. But it was clear he was going to listen to Hermione with how he was positioned on the couch, hovering on the seats and tense.

"Hermione and Petunia can both provide information given they are both expecting," offered James, causing Barty and Regulus to glance at Petunia in surprise. She limply waved a hand and then turned her back on the drama, pretending to intently inspect the board. "While the three of us can do the magic part. And we'll keep it away from them, too."

"That sounds fair," agreed Barty with a tenuous grin at James.

Success!Â thought James. He had finally found a crack into Hermione's best friend accepting him.

"Very well," agreed Regulus, stiffly through barely moving lips. He proceeded to then pour himself an alcoholic drink of some kind in a short glass, swishing the liquid around.

Hermione sighed. "Fine."

They were all silent for a bit.

"So. Uh, Gringott's, yeah?" muttered James, awkwardly.

Hermione sighed, again. "We have an in we can use."

Regulus perked up. "We do?"

"Dirk," replied Hermione. "He works in the Goblin Liaison Office in the Ministry. He can help us."

James's lips curled into a smile and Regulus nodded, once, as though that was an acceptable solution.

Only Barty seemed put out, pouting, "So no plan to steal a dragon? Boring."

January 1980

The Ministry had not changed since the last time Hermione had stepped foot in it â€“ a few decades in the future and a few decades in her past. There were still memos zooming above her head, the walls were still a pale gold, the carpet beneath her shoes was plush, and there were nervous glances made by harried and worried witches and wizards that kept their heads down as they rushed from one location to the next.

Voldemort's reign of terror was beginning to sink in now: sometimes, he'd attack â€“ on equinoxes, on other special days â€“ but mostly? To sink his claws in the people he needed to change policy, to learn the information he wanted, he would have his Death Eaters kidnap and torture (like they'd tried with her, Regulus, and Barty), or would place others under the Imperius curse. Trust was at an all-time low in the Ministry, and it was no wonder that Barty's father was pushing for stronger measures against Death Eaters.

But the Goblin Liaison office was a bit less tense than anywhere else. Perhaps it was because dealing with goblins on a daily was a thankless and terse job, but the people there were entirely too cheerful for Hermione when she stepped in, looking around for Dirk.

She spotted his dark head bent over some parchment at a desk in the middle of the office, partitioned off by familiar muggle-looking cubbies. As a new grunt, Dirk's office was in a terrible location of high traffic and next to a gurgling rubbish bin that burped at her when she strode up.

Leaning against the cubby wall, Hermione grinned, "Seems like those eight N.E.W.T.s really paid off."

Dirk startled, glancing up as his glasses slid down his nose. Spotting Hermione, he snorted and rolled his eyes. "It was less the N.E.W.T.s and more the fluent Gobbledegook I speak."

He rolled his chair back a bit and asked, "What brings you by, Hermione?"

Hermione grinned at her friend, eyes roving his desk: the messy parchment, the discarded quills and one tipped over inkpot; a few sealed scrolls in letterboxes on the far side, and the enchanted memo paper on a tiny shelf. Tucked in a corner, shadowed by the shelf, was a framed photograph from the Halloween party she and James had thrown that past October.

"May I?" she asked, pointing at it.

Dirk nodded, passing it over.

"Oh, wow," she breathed, taking it in. "I hadn't even realized someone was taking this."

The picture itself was busy: there were several people in the frame, but they were all stationary despite the wizarding nature of the image. It was easy to tell each person, though, despite their costumes: the Evans sisters were goddesses, Hermione and Petunia in togas and Lily in an owl mask; James had antlers to represent his animagus, as did the other Marauders; and here and there dotted others in masks and feathers.

Hermione was curled at James' side, laughing at something Petunia and Sean expressed. Sirius was warily looking around behind James, near the food, with Peter egging him on; Remus was listening to something Lily was saying as they, along with Dirk and Marlene, were listening intently, with Dirk having the most intense look on his face as he paid attention.

It was everyone Hermione had come to grow to care about, in some shape or another, in one image.

"It was a pretty chaotic night," agreed Dirk with a grin. "I'm certain Sirius spikedâ€”"

"â€”the punch? Oh, yeah," finished Hermione with a grimace, glancing at the photographic version of Sirius glancing over his shoulder and then winking at the camera. "This is lovely, though. Are there any more copies? Who took it?"

"Braithwaite took it," answered Dirk, "That mousy looking Hufflepuff? The one that was friends with Diggory and Smith â€“ I think there was a conversation about New Years' partiesâ€¦?"

Hermione gave a tiny huff of a laugh. "I know her. I'll ask for a copy or some others of the evening."

"Sounds good," agreed Dirk, leaning back in his seat. "Now, why don't you tell me why you're really here?"

Hermione widened her eyes. "What makes you think I'm here for something?"

"Cut the crap, Hermione," retorted Dirk. "I know you. So, what is it?"

"Fine," scowled Hermione, moving from the wall to step closer. She furtively looked around, and while his coworkers were busy with their own work, she lowered her voice. "I need to retrieve something from a Gringott's vault without getting killed."

Dirk began laughing, even going so far as to slap a hand against his thigh. Then, it trailed off when her face didn't change. "What?"

"I need toâ€”"

"I heard you the first time, but I had hoped someone slipped me an experimental potion to hallucinate," snapped Dirk, face hard. His eyes darted around the room. "Are you suicidal? RobbingÂ them?"

"It's important."

Dirk rolled his eyes. "So is yourÂ life! What would Potter sayâ€”"

"He knows about this," interrupted Hermione calmly, making Dirk snap his mouth shut. "We had another plan, but it was considered too risky. So, I thought I would ask you how we could get the goblins on our side without robbing them."

Dirk sputtered, "Y-your s-sideâ€”"

"What do they want that I can give them?" continued Hermione, ignoring her friend. "I won't give them wands â€“ but the artifact I need is potential goblin-made. They can have it once the Dark Magic is purgedâ€”"

"You're having a laugh." Dirk's eyes were round.

"C'mon, Dirk, give me something here," pleaded Hermione, lowering her voice and stepping closer. "I need something. They don't meddle in wizard affairs but they are greedy little money-grabbers, and everyone has a price."

Dirk's eyes narrowed. "Why are you so adamant about this? I know you're notâ€”" he took a deep breath and looked around the room, lowering his own voice to just above a breathy exhale, "Part of Dumbledore's Order, so why are you so interested in this artifact in Gringott's?"

Hermione paused, her hand coming up to rub at her aching collarbone. "It's to stopÂ him."

Dirk froze. "You know how toâ€¦?"

Hermione gave a slow, tiny nod.

"Is that why he went afterâ€¦?"

She shook her head. "He doesn't know."

Exhaling shakily, Dirk fell back into his muggle roots. "Jesus Christ, Hermione. Jesus, Mary, and Joseph â€“Â what have you been up to?"

Hermione's mouth flattened into a tight line. "What we've had to."

"Crouch and Black," groaned Dirk, slipping in his chair and resting his head against the back. "Of course."

"What about speculation?" offered Hermione, back to the topic. "A month of arithmancy to predict muggle stocks for each minute in the vault in question?"

Dirk shook his head. "You don't get it â€“ they don't care about that. You're magical, I'm magicalâ€¦ even me going to them outside Ministerial purview would be just as bad, Hermione. It can't be done. They won't accept any deals unless it's significantly tipped in their favour and then they'd just kill you anyway after delivery."

Hermione's mouth turned further down into a deep frown.

"Honestly, the only way into the vault in question is to have the owner or a family member go in and retrieve the item," sighed Dirk, running a hand through his messy hair. He peered at her. "Is there someone you can ask to do that?"

Baby Lestrange, her mind supplied instantly, a sour thought that echoed on her face. "Yeah."

"Then you need to get them on your side and have them retrieve it," said Dirk.

"Is that your expert advice as a goblin liaison?" asked Hermione seriously.

He nodded. "It's the only way."

Hermione sighed.

"Sorry," winced Dirk. "I know it's not what you wanted to hearâ€”"

She shrugged. "I didn't want to rob the place or breakout on dragonback, so I guess this works. I'll make it work."

Alarmed, Dirk weakly echoed, "Dragonback?" but Hermione was already thinking ahead, ignoring him. She gave him a tight smile.

"Thank you for your help," she said, patting him on the shoulder. "I appreciate it. I know we haven't really spoken recently, so we should catch up with lunch."

Even though his heart was thundering with the idea of Hermione robbing Gringott's and escaping on a dragon, Dirk managed to weakly nod and gasp, "Sounds good. There's a good sushi place I knowâ€”"

Hermione shook her head. "Sorry, can't. No raw fish for me until late summer."

"What? Why?"

Carefully, Hermione's hands fluttered around her midsection, Dirk's eyes dropping to follow the movement. He stood suddenly, chair rolling backward. His eyes were wide when he whispered through bloodless lips, "You're pregnant?"

"Blame Sirius and the punch," groused Hermione. "Not only was I pissed out of my mind, I'm sure whatever combination he used frizzled out any magical forms of birth control. Tuney and Lily are also pregnant, and so is Alice Longbottom â€“ and all three were at the party."

Dirk's face paled. "Oh â€“ oh, wowâ€¦"

"That's a word for it," Hermione rolled her eyes. "Thanks again, Dirk. I'll owl you and we'll find somewhere else for lunch."

As she walked away, she heard Dirk weakly say goodbye behind her. She bit her lip, her brain processing and coming up with plans to bring Rabastan to their side. It looked like it was Regulus's turn to helm a mission.

On a Thursday morning, Regulus left the Haberdashery with a scowl on his face while Barty, James, and Hermione remained behind. Barty was offering baby names, playfully, like he didn't know that Hermione already had a name in mind while James was enthusiastically rhapsodizing about what a great Quidditch player his child was going to be.

By Thursday evening, as the sun was going down and the three were becoming antsy, Regulus, scowl in place, returned to the Haberdashery, a pale- and shame-faced Rabastan trailing him silently.

Barty slowly stood. "What is heâ€”"

Rabastan reached into a cloth bag at his side and withdrew Hufflepuff's goblet, placing it on the coffee table in front of the couch where its golden stem gleamed in the room's light even as the fireplace rippled and dimmed.

Hermione blinked while James looked between the goblet and the younger Lestrange. "I â€“ what â€“ that seemed a bitâ€”"

"Too easy?" finished Barty grimly. He was staring hard at the youngest wizard in the room. "You don't say."

"He was already feeling bad about the portkey last summer," sighed Regulus, throwing himself into his usual armchair. "And was attempting to drown his guilt in a seedy Knockturn bar when I found him. Was easy enough to sober the kid up when I told him I needed his help."

"And you went along with it?" asked Hermione, looking at Rabastan in confusion. "Just like that?"
